description:
Bouncers are always friendly :)

Chicken nuggets are delish! They come with three sauces: mustard, bbq, and sweet n sour.

The drinks are made with love and never taste watered down. If your drink doesn't taste good, it means you chose the wrong thing for your taste - just get another one!
author: Susan C.

description:
5/5 for atmosphere 
1/5 for staff - they were impolite 

That balances out to a 3!
Please step up your customer service and I'll come back all the time and give you a 5 for a place that has so much potential.
author: Cody C.

description:
I have been here for drinks and this time around I tried out the dinner menu. 

The Joy of Cooking themed book and cocktails named after SF restaurants is awesome. I highly recommend the Liholiho cocktail.

The food was delicious! We ordered the Kale salad (could easily feed 4!), guac with elote and their homemade chicken nuggets with 3 diff sauces. The ambiance is quaint. My only complaint is that the lighting is REALLY dim. Hard to read the menu and take pictures of the food/drink (LOL!). 

If you want to get a table, seating is upstairs, wait at the OFFICE door and a waitress will put your name down. We waited about 20 minutes and got drinks downstairs at the bar in the meantime.
author: Angela D.

description: Pretty crowded at 7 PM on a Tuesday night :D Sometimes when I see an interesting cocktail in  a bar, I like to challenge myself and try to make it at home - but the drinks here have too many very complicated ingredients which come together beautifully and I just decided to try them here ! I got something with sesame seeds on top which was so good, among my party we tried 6 different cocktails and all were great.Don't expect to get a seat though!
author: Anju J.

description:
Always great to come back and see what amazing inventive thing they're doing with the menu

I've gotten to try stuff from their very first Pantone menu, the vinyl menu, the Dr Seuss menu, and now the joy of cooking inspired drink menu

This one is special because it uses other restaurants as inspiration for drinks.

Got the Theorita which had a chocolatey base to it and a nice chocolate garnish

Also got the Liho Liho which is rum based 

Food has really been revamped here.  They've simplified it to be smaller bites that go well with the drinks you get.  

Kale salad is a huge mountain of leaves, chunky avocado and toasty sunflower seeds.  Actually difficult to finish given how much they give you but it is very nicely dressed

Chicken nuggets at 9 piece was right size for 2 people.  Crispy on the outside, meaty on the inside.  The sauces are just like you'd get at McDonald's except somehow heightened.  The bbq sauce is tangy and thick, the sweet and sour has a nice chile taste, the honey mustard has a nasal kick

super crowded and boisterous as usual.  get in early to avoid crowds!
author: Marshall Y.

description:
I came to here on a date on a Friday night- his idea. Here is were you come get fancy, extra, doing the most cocktails and you won't regret it!

They have an impressive drink menu--- I remember reading duck fat washed tequila?! It was very intriguing! There drinks are named after restaurants in SF (possibly solely mission district- super cool!) I ended up getting a beer-mixer- I forgot the name! It was tasty- pretty sweet but good. 

My date and I decided to head upstair in the restaurant area for some privacy and order some food. There was plenty of seating and much quieter up there. Candle lit and cozy- perfect for a date. He said the kale salad was the best around. I was pretty hesitant because your girl LOVES kale salad and I can make a pretty mean one. The kale salad arrived and it was... the best kale salad around. It was so good, so fresh, and so crisp! Enough dressing on it to tax out that kale bitterness but also not swimming in dressing- the perfect balance that's hard to achieve. LARGE serving- we couldn't finish- great for 3 people. 

I've been dreaming of that salad and will be back for that and to try that duck fat wash tequila drink.
author: Marcie A.

description:
My only regret about this place is that I don't live in SF and I can't come every time the menu changes.  Well, maybe this place will give me the incentive to keep visiting...

I love a revolving/evolving menu and I like how playful they are with said menus.  Investing so much into a concept by getting special menus, changing the glassware frequently, etc. is something I'd aspire to in my own business, if I had one.

The drinks were good and the service from the bartender was good.  It was a pretty busy night and I think the bartender we were in front of handled it fairly well.

The food was terrific.  Frito pie?  Yes, please.  The pickled jalapenos and carrots made it.  MADE IT!  The beef tartare was excellent as well.  Super acidic (which I love! I hate when it's too oily and you can feel that the meat is raw) and nicely fried wonton chips.

I even got hit on at this bar, which never happens to me ever!  So I'll definitely have fond memories and look forward to the day I can go back.
author: Christina R.

description:
I absolutely love this place. Their drinks are always really good and you can't go wrong with their infamous trick dog and manimal fries. 

They updated the menu to this cool "Airlines" theme and gave us a pin of wings that reads "Trick Dog Airways." Super cool. 

But dang it sure gets crowded in here! I've been here twice and each time was packed. Also there's nothing too special about the interior, hence the minus star. I think if Trick Dog moved to a bigger space, it would definitely make it more comfortable and become a go-to bar/gastropub to frequent in the city!
author: Jayne S.

description: Trick Dog was a spot that so many other bartenders in San Francisco told us we must check out and we could totally see why, cocktail bar, lots of inventive drinks, people behind the bar who do this for a living because they have a passion for crafting these drinks, super cool but also super expensive. I was drinking champagne and my boyfriend was drinking a specialty cocktail with milk in it, which was wild and delicious and our bill was hefty. Hefty my friends. Anyways, this joint really has no outlets I just have to make note of. We were relying on Uber and Yelp to get us from place to place as we had never been in this city before and had absolutely no idea how to get from place to place so when my phone died I would just plug it in to whatever bar or restaurant we were at in the moment but literally nothing. So, the super awesome bartender was more than happy to take my phone for me and plug it in behind the bar, which I thought was awesome. They had an upstairs loft type area and there happened to be a private party going on up there so we didn't explore but I could tell from below that it was cool. They share a bathroom with the business next door and while the place was super busy, the bartenders were pretty attentive and working their butts off back there. This was the day of the Folsom Street Fair (don't even know if I'm saying that right, first timers remembers) and so the place was packed out. They let you bring your dogs in here! I mean, Trick Dog, right? But I was perfectly content petting this dog and drinking my Champagne. If you're into craft cocktails with a super cool lounge vibe, come here!
author: Samantha S.

description:
Wow. Trick Dog really amped up my standards as to what a bar should really be.

The first time I came to Trick Dog, I was a bit weary of it. Came here on a whim based on a recommendation of the person I was with at the time, and let me just tell you- do not let the weird-ish location stray you away from going here!

Trick Dog is located in a quite strange location, somewhere in between Potrero Hill and the Mission. Finding Trick Dog can be extremely confusing as well since there is no signage whatsoever as to where it is, but once you are inside, be ready for your world to be elevated!

Of the three times that I've gone here, two have been on a Friday, and the other day has been on a Saturday, service, drinks, and food have always been impeccable. If you are only looking to get drinks, I would strongly advise you to arrive early as these past times that I have gone, it has been near impossible to be able to find a place to sit, and it gets pretty crowded to even stand as the night progresses. Do note that if you wish to eat, there is an upstairs section where you can sit, and which rarely has a wait :)

The allure of Trick Dog for me not only lies in how inventive they are when it comes to their drinks, but also how well executed their drinks are. The first and second times that I went, they had a "Trick Dog Airways" cocktail menu, which included drinks which were inspired from all over the world! I had a chance to try the GDL, the YQG, and the SYD. The most recent time that I went, Trick Dog had a "Joy of Cooking" menu, and I ordered the Liloliho Yacht Club. Each of the drinks that I have tried at Trick Dog have been so diverse, but so amazing in their own way! Although drinks can get a bit pricy here (average $15 per cocktail), it is clearly worth it once you take the first sip of your drink. 

I have also had the pleasure of eating at Trick Dog with one of my close friends, and we ordered their kale salad, their Baja fish tacos, and their French fries. Let me just tell you, their kale salad is what dreams are made of! I did not have a chance to try the Baja fish tacos or the French fries, but my friend was highly satisfied.

PSA- I'm not sure if Trick Dog always does this, but for their "Joy of Cooking" cocktail menu, they partnered with La Cocina SF (a non-profit in the Mission District whose mission is to cultivate low income food entrepreneurs), and are helping them raise funds. I truly love all that Trick Dog is about!
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
I'm not sure what happened to this place but the drinks need an overhaul-attitude has always been awful but at least the drinks were good.  I know the mixologist scene is supposedly highly regarded but part of being a bartender is hospitality.  This place gets a zero for hospitality and the drinks are unbalanced and messy.
Not a huge fan
author: Michelle J.

description:
Trick Dog is known for their drinks and constantly changing (and themed) drink menu. This time it was airline themed. They even had a "frequent flyer club" where you become a member and get some kickbacks. We came for dinner with a group of four. We had about a 45 minute wait which wasn't bad.

The seating area is lofted above and overlooks the bar area. The building itself is pretty rad. I think it's a converted wear-house space with a couple of other restaurants also inside. 

The food overall was pretty good. I got the Trick Burger with fries. The fries were great and crispy. The Trick Burger was fun and unique. My wife got the Kale Salad which was the largest Kale Salad I have ever seen. And it was amazing! The service was all around great as well. 

The drinks are premium prices but the food is pretty fairly priced. Overall a great spot!
author: Aaron B.

description: Great little spot with good service and interesting drinks... will create off menu if desired and sitting at the bar afforded a view of the creation process...   speakeasy atmosphere, would definitely return
author: Tazeen L.

description:
Somehow, my boyfriend and I always end up here when we get really drunk. Probably because we know that a) this is the best place to get more drinks and b) this is amazing drunk food!

Who doesn't think a burger shaped like a hotdog is the best idea ever when they're drunk? Hell, I even think it's the best idea sober! But no joke, the food is great, and they have everyone's American guilty pleasures but with a unique twist, like the manimal style fries and the square shaped chicken nuggets. You really can't go wrong!

Also, the cocktail menu is so good, and it seems to change. I remember when I first went to Trick Dog they had some sort of candy theme, and I got a really good drink that had sour patch kids in it (my favorite). Now, they have an airline theme which I think is probably my favorite cocktail menu ever. Each cocktail represents a different location. My personal favorite is the Seattle-Tacoma! But they're all super intricate and well thought out, so head on over to see for yourself.
author: Claire C.

description:
3.5 stars. 5 for the drinks, go mixologists! 4 for the price, $16 for a cocktail is too much imo. 2 stars for the insanely busy bar that took me 30 minutes just to make my way to the bar and order... Seriously?!

It was cool, but the location, price and insanely busy evening doesn't entice me to go back to be completely honest.
author: Mandi W.

description: In my opinion they have great cocktails and constantly refreshing cocktail menu. Not a very convenient location in Mission District.
author: Madhu J.

description:
I like to give places 5 stars when there's something unique about it. So what was unique about Trick Dog?

Well I already knew I was going to like the vibe when the "bouncer" outside was a rad looking chick as opposed to the usual male appearance. The menu is displayed in the form of one of those escape pamphlets you find on a plane, except with cocktails listed. It's fun and cute when you're coming in for the first time and want something different than your typical bougie bar. Be prepared for the possibility to stand - this place doesn't have a ton of seating.
author: Allie L.

description:
My sister comes here a lot, this was my first time, and unfortunately: My last time for ONE reason. :/ 
I came here with my sister, her partner and a lady work friend. Nice ambiance! I'd recommend the Delfina! It was pretty busy and we were originally planning on ordering food, but had to stop after ordering drinks. 
One of the servers (Ray? Blackish/white hair) made us feel uncomfortable. He came off as condescending/kinda sexist (being 4 women, we think he treated us differently). We didn't appreciate that at all and won't be coming back because of him. 
Plus, we think he was high/on drugs. His eyes were red and he smelled. 
Trick Dog we'd like to come back, but that server gave us a bad experience. Otherwise great, sorry.
author: Sara G.

description:
We tried the hick dialogue, lunatic bog, jurassic fog- all just a bit too sweet for me. Ordered one off the back page that was a riff on a rusty nail, and an off-menu penicillin cocktail. Both just meh.  

Really wanted to love this place. Totally appreciate the clever menu, friendly servers, great old-school tunes. The food looked good (though we didn't try any since we had dinner plans). Sadly, our sampling of 5 cocktails didn't impress, so doubt we'd return.
author: Ryen B.

description:
Trick dog is my favorite cocktail bar of all time!

What sets them apart is the craft of their drinks. They change their drinks every 6 months or so and each iteration has cool and novel ingredients. Think peanut butter, peppercorn, green pepper, and malted milk. The magic is that they somehow layer the taste profile in such a way that you taste the flavor of the hard liquor in the cocktail but instead of the bite of alcohol later on, you get the flavor one of the ingredients. You can say that is the art of cocktail mixing, yet, Trick Dog does this at a very high level. Just watch the bartenders to appreciate this. 

Then, there are the cocktail menus. They change their menus with their drinks and each menu has a theme. It was alien sightings a few years ago (each cocktail was named after aliens), then it was presidential campaign pins, then San Francisco murals. The amount of thinking that goes into the naming of drinks and menus is impressive. 

The venue is spacious but minimally decorated. The ambience is at Trick dog is the less impressive of its aspects. Their drinks are good that the drinks more than compensate for anything and everything else. 



I have had the chance to try numerous drinks from old-fashioned to 

cocktails here that really stood out. Drinks with green pepper
author: Doruk B.

description:
Every time I make my way out to Trick Dog, I'm reminded of how much I love this spot. It's a little bit of a trek to get out this area, but if you're looking for a hidden gem, this is def the spot to go to. 

First of all, if you're in for dinner/snacks, get the kale salad. Even if you don't like kale. Seriously. Haha. The kale cesar salad here is the best kale cesar salad I've ever had. And I love a good kale cesar, so I've had a bunch. I could never figure out what makes it that extra special, but my guess is their dressing. It's like nothing else you've ever had. Tangy. Creamy. Eggy. Is that a word?

And then for their drinks and service. Again, every time I come back, it's a little bit of a sweet surprise to see true mixologists making beautifully crafted cocktails. True artisans. And each bartender is the same. I was amazed at how well-trained they were at efficiently taking orders (more than a handful at a time). Cheers to Trick Dog! 5 stars :)
author: Jennifer L.

description: I came here on a whim looking for a pre-dinner cocktail since I had some time to kill before meeting friends at Farmhouse down the street. Luckily, I arrived and was able to grab a spot at the bar. I love how the drink menu has an airplane theme and the cocktails are based on airports around the world. Given that Japan is my favorite country, I had to go with the Kyoto cocktail, which was amazing! I also got a veganized version of the roasted cauliflower and it was fantastic. The only thing that would make this place better is some outdoor seating!
author: Jana B.

description: my gf and i stopped by at trick dog on a monday after climbing at mission cliffs and im so glad we did! the place is not crowded at all at 10 PM on a monday - amazing. we grabbed two seats at the bar and proceeded to peruse the drink menu, which changes regularly. it was so cute this time - based on restaurateurs in sf.  this is only my 3rd time at trick dog, and i forgot how much i liked this place. we tried 3 cocktails, and the fried pickles and beer tartar - not cheap, but nice little treat. cant wait to be back!
author: Christina L.

description:
Trick Dog is a very good bar with very good food. 

Important: A few times I've been there the bar has been PACKED, but getting seated upstairs at a table has been instant. So keep that in mind- I expect the host would really prefer you order some food up there, but it's all worthwhile. I've been able to sit a group of four on a Thursday night at 7pm with no wait. 

There isn't too much to add that isn't covered ad infinitum, so I'll endorse these sentiments: Beautiful space, excellent (and off-beat) cocktails, a kick-ass menu with rotating themes (like 'Children's Book' one season and 'Airline Safety Guide' this season) all of which are fantastic, witty, and gorgeous to look at). Very busy. 

A shot+beer combo is a dollar CHEAPER than just the shot if you choose a Budweiser as your beer, which got a laugh out of me. 

Great, unpretentious food presented pretentiously with surprisingly relaxed prices.
author: Jim M.

description:
You're in for a delightful treat if you enjoy a creative cocktail and gourmet small bites. Highly recommend getting their  $6 orgasam shots as it might just be the most delicious shot I've ever tasted. 
It's a bit small and gets crowded easily downstairs so come have your drinks and a small bite ($10-$15) upstairs with your cocktails. 
-loved: chicken nuggets, orgasam shots and squash toast, story book menu
-Servers: *****
author: Ankita C.

description: Fun bar in the Mission where they name their drinks after different airports all over the world and have a simple layout of the airport on their menus as well.
author: David K.

description:
We happened to be in the neighborhood for dinner and wanted to grab a drink. One of my co-workers sent me a list on Yelp of his favorite bars in the city. So when I pulled it up in the app, I realized it was right around the corner from where we were. So off we went.

It was decently crowded at about 6:30ish and as we were there, the crowd tapered off. The bartender handed us what looked like a children's book. I quickly realized that it was the cocktail menu with all of their drinks that rhymed with "trick dog". I often find in craft cocktail bars, that the bartenders are not always the friendliest. Not the case here. We dealt with three different bartenders that were incredibly friendly, and happy to talk with us. 

I decided on the Frantic Frog since it had my liquor of choice... whiskey. The cocktails were delicious. I even tried my wife's Attic Gulag that had an amazing presentation. Equally as good. We found a spot at the bar pretty easily and went for a second round. As I said before, the crowd thinned a bit at we were there. Which is a good think in my book.

Really cool bar in a city full of cool bars. If I'm in the neighborhood again, Trick Dog will see me again!
author: Will B.

description:
one of those places where one wanna go back! But go back before the rush hour to secure some space :)

They have a rotating menu every 6 months. And the cocktails are just amazing! However, the food thing starts after 5, so if you reach before that, you can get food from the coffee place next to it. 
The bartenders are knowledgeable about the drinks and they have a greaat selection of whiskeys!

Superb for big groups!
author: Subha J.

description: I remember when they had cocktails named after different airports! It was so fun! One drink came in a teddy bear shaped glass jar. They change the menu after every few months so always check before you go.
author: Phee F.

description:
I've heard a lot about Trick Dog and had it bookmarked for a while, so I was really excited to finally check it out and try their innovative cocktails. 

My group of 3 arrived on a Friday evening around 6:45 pm and it was pretty packed. For some reason I was expecting it to be bigger with more seating, but it was a fairly small space with limited seating along one side of the wall. The crowd also meant it was hard to hear ourselves unless we shouted to each other, which made conversation difficult. There is a small area upstairs with tables, but when my friends and I tried to head up to order some small plates to share, we were told that you had to order more substantial food in order to sit up there. The upstairs was super empty except for one group that had just gotten seated, so that seemed like a bit of a waste to me.

It took a while, but finally we were able to grab a menu from the bar and peruse it. Right now their menu looks like a children's book which made it fun to flip through and look at the illustrations. There were a couple options that sounded promising, but I ended up going with the Broomstick Backlog, which is Tanqueray gin, Suze, apricot, white miso, lime, and Kimino yuzu soda. All cocktails are $14.

Everything in the drink sounded absolutely delicious except for the Suze which I had never heard of, so I was surprised and disappointed when the cocktail turned out to be much more bitter than I had expected. I'm slowly coming to realize that my taste buds are more attuned to bitter tastes in food than the average person, so the bitter flavors in this drink drowned out the sweetness of the other delicious sounding ingredients. I was so sad!

We left after one drink as the bar was too crowded for us and went to chill at another bar on Mission where there was actual seating and where we could actually hear ourselves.
author: Dianna H.

description:
After a long and fun-filled evening indulging in fine drinks and food, Trick Dog has to be one of my favorite places in SF to piss the night away (Ref. Chumbawamba). I came early evening on a Thursday and the bar area was already packed. I was concerned the service was going to be slow but to my surprise, the bartenders were very attentive and quick to consistently make drinks and take orders. Thus, the wait for a refill was always minimal. 

After perusing the awesome children's book style drink menu, I started the evening with a slew of mixed drinks. I typically don't order too many mixed drinks but the cocktails looked mightily appealing and the bartenders appeared to be the mixologist type. The Frantic Frog, Bolshevik Blog and the Jurassic Fog were the drinks I opted for and they were all very tasty. My fave would be the Frantic Frog since I prefer whiskeys but nothing to take away from my second fave of the three, the very refreshing Jurassic Fog. All drinks weren't overly sweet nor overly spirit-forward. Just perfectly balanced. 

As hunger started to trickle in, I was already at the bar so there was no need to get a table upstairs. I tried the Manimal-style fries, Chicken Tricknuggets and the Kale Salad. Hands down they were all exceedingly tasty. As the food came out I switched up my drinks to whiskey neat (unfortunately, not on the highest floor of the Bowery). They have a great selection of spirits and especially whiskeys so I was very pleased. 

Trick Dog is located in the outer Mission area so it embodies that local feel. They also rotate their menu (every 6 months I hear?) so take a look at their current menu and pay Trick Dog a visit. With their mouth-watering food menu, delicious drinks, a great playlist, along with friendly and attentive staff, I'll definitely return for another gratifying evening.
author: Chris B.

description:
I loved the concept of this bar. Every season, the cocktail menu changes based on a theme. At the time we went, the theme was airports so each drink was named after a famous airport. How cool is that??? The cocktails were also very creative and came in their own special glasses.

It was the first bar we went to on our bachelorette crawl. The bar was half empty so it was very comfortable and relaxed for us. We ended up ordering food and fell in love with the gigantic kale salad they serve. Believe me, it was massive! We were the happiest girls chomping on it.

I would love to visit again when I'm in town just to check out their new drink menus!
author: Katherine C.

description:
Slightly dark, discreet bar in the Mission. I don't remember seeing a sign, but the crowd and sounds of chatter made it easy to find (right next door to Sightglass). It's trendy. Super hip. I mean, the most  popular dish appeared to be a pile of Kale. Only in SF. 

No complaints here because this place is really rad, and the Berenstain Bears-ish menu book sets the tone. The cocktails are imaginative, playful, and well-executed. But I insisted on a little Fino (sherry) to sip on. It was perfectly chilled and got my belly ready for our dinner just down the street (Flour + Water). Wish we had more time to linger over another drink and watch people eat kale.
author: Jon S.

description:
If I had come at off-peak hours, this place might be worthy of 5 stars. But brace yourself if you want to be hip and hit this place up weekend time.

Came at around 9 PM on a Saturday, to what I thought was a packed house. I would later be proven wrong, as by the time we left an hour later, the place was even more crowded and there was a line waiting outside to enter.

If you can, grab a table not at the bar, because otherwise people will be crowding around you all night to order. Likely though, you won't even be able to grab a table, so if one opens up, go go go (sorry girl I swiped a table from). If standing, find an area where people won't be constantly pushing to get by. Does this sound like a madhouse? It is.

The menu is a cute idea, themed like a picture book. However, that also means when its crowded, it'll take you that much longer to figure out what damn drink you want to order and actually get it.

I might sound bitter, but honestly, the drink was pretty worth it. I got the Last-Picked Demagogue-- if you like mezcal, this is the cocktail for you. Smokey flavors intermix beautifully and it looks classy, unlike some of the other drinks served with crushed ice.

Overall, a place to check out if you're in the area, but if you actually want to have a conversation and catch up, hit up one of the many other bars in the area.
author: Angela C.

description:
One of my top 3 favorite bars in San Francisco. 

I've tried 4 different menus now and they've all been fantastic. 

Election / Murals / Seuss / Aviation 

I can't even pick a favorite because they all owned. 

I also love that you can buy the menus because the presentation is honestly everything. I'm sad I missed the astrology and pantone themed menus, but I look forward to coming back here every time they switch up the menu. It's absolutely worth it. The drinks are unparalleled. 

Hungry? Order the kale salad. Trust me.
author: Nikki I.

description: Pretentious is the word that came to mind here.  Maybe it was just the Asian on Asian judgement crime at the bar...which was odd cause dude and company were not too pretty.  Totally out of Trick Dog's control but if that is regular...would disappoint.  Moreover...our bar tender was not inviting at all.  While I don't expect much...her first impression did not impress...but fortunately a couple of the cocktails did...but the others did not.  Yes I was that torn...but I will visit again to potentially update this review.  Their location and environment is no doubt inviting...and i have yet to taste their amazing looking food so more to come...
author: Edmundo C.

description:
Oh Trick Dog, how do I love thee?  Let me count the ways...

One.  
Award winning bar ...and it's evident!  Their cocktails are exquisite with a balanced blend of flavors and the right amount of alcohol.  Their cocktail menu themes are brilliant!  The latest two themes (Election and the Mural Project) displayed modern creativity with a sense of amusement and community.  Trick Dog is masterful in keeping their customers interested with unique and inspired concoctions.  Some of my favorites were Drill Baby Drill (Wild Turkey rye with a kick and a nice large ice cube), and another Election themed drink...Didn't Inhale (a bittersweet Japanese whiskey blend).  More recently, the Vogue has caught my tongue for a refreshing starter, and I usually end the evening with their strong Strider.     

Two.  
Bar food for any mood.  Whether you're drunk, almost drunk, or just plain hungry ...any of their "upscale bar snacks" on their food menu can satisfy any kind of drinker, or non-drinker. 
 With a crunchiness that's second to none, their thrice-cooked fries are a must here!  Plain or loaded Manimal style (cheese, scallions & sauce), these fries are perfect for any day ...not just FRYdays!  Another dish that's great for sharing would be their Kale salad.  This refreshing dish is piled high, very high with just the right amount of flavor throughout.  Their Trick Dog and Chicken Tricknuggets aren't your ordinary hot dog and chicken nuggets.  The quality of these "tricked out" dishes is obvious in every bite.  
Quick tip: They don't serve food when they open at 3 pm.  The food menu is available after 5 pm.

Three.
The music.  Love that old school 70s-80s vibe!  And some early 90s R&B too!

Four.  
Baby and dog-friendly. On some of my daytime visits (4-6 pm), I've noticed a few pups chillin under the tables and around corners.  I've also noticed a few toddlers lounging around, with their parents of course.  The music and semi-loud atmosphere can sometimes be calming ...for everyone! 

Five.  
Service with a smile.  Never had complaints about service here.  Staff is extremely nice and very efficient, even on busy nights.  Not only are drinks perfectly executed behind the bar, but the delivery is flawless.  


There you have it.  Five stars for one of my favorite bars!
author: Bobby L.

description:
Excellent cocktails and food.

I was able to get a seat for one at 1800 on Monday, but it got pretty crowded soon after.

The yqg has an iced cubed with bruleed sugar on top that gives the cocktail a scent somewhere between marshmallow and cotton candy.

The bartenders both said the trick dog was their preferred food, and I would agree. The tuna tostada was pretty good as well. I wouldn't personally get the fish tacos again.
author: Lucas D.

description: Best kale salad I've ever had. Drinks are overpriced but always good.
author: K S.

description:
I had the good fortune to come by Trick Dog when they had their SF mural artists-inspired drink menu. Despite it being fairly early in the day, the bar was already packed, and I could see why. The space is trendy and open, and the bartenders seem to know their trade very well. The bouncer's gorgeous husky greeting patrons outside the door didn't hurt either. 

All cocktails were priced at $13 (a little pricey but I think the quality justifies it). I tried the Mel Waters (Bulleit rye, blueberry bitter aperitivo, madeira, black pepper, rose hip) and my partner tried the Jeremy Fish (rum, chai liqueur, dry vermouth, Luxardo Bianco bitter, acid phosphate, mango bitters). Both were very complex and well-though-out drinks, and I'll probably never encounter a similar cocktail at any other bar. I was especially impressed that the chai notes were very prominent in the Jeremy Fish.
author: Jen L.

description: I came here on a Friday after work and it was really busy!  The bartenders are still attentive though.  Just fyi there's no sign in the front, but easy to hear all the people inside socializing.  They have different bar menu themes.  This time they had international airports for their drinks.  I ordered a glasgow and windsor.  Both were very good with 1 ice cube.  I never had a carmelized ice cube before, it gives out so much flavor with a touch of sweetness.  Great place to chill and hang out!
author: KB B.

description:
As soon as you walk in you are handed a hard cover story book only to quickly realize that said book is a cocktail menu. Talk about class!

This place is packed and full of smart people. This is an assumption, but if you've made it to Trick Dog it's because you know that you can get a delicious craft cocktail for a reasonable San Fransisco price in less than 5 minutes. 

I went rogue and ordered a round of drinks that weren't on the menu. My tasty liquid gold treat was a tequila mule, which the crafty cocktail guru made with a delicious smokey tequila that warmed my soul on this windy evening. Not only did this talented bartender bust our the three drinks I ordered, but he also mixed and mingle them with 3 other parties of beverages that other groups had ordered. I kid you not, this man was a well oiled craft cocktail creating machine.

This place has booze down to a science.
author: Taylor S.

description: Cute concept - the menu changes every month with a theme that they incorporate throughout their drinks! Went in here to kill time before Central Kitchen. The bartender wasn't very knowledgeable - he didn't even know what time CK opened. Maybe he was new... or maybe he was dumb. I got a non-alcoholic drink that was refreshing. And then at the end we got wings (the theme of the month was Trick Dog Airlines). Nice touch.
author: Alison Z.

description:
Ambiance is always on the move. Super fun spot to start or continue a night for a few drinks with friends. I recommend to most new SF residence or anyone traveling here for the first time.

Very cool drink selection changes constantly as well!
author: Steve G.

description: Slow service. Lackluster cocktails. Beautiful menus, though. I was there on a Sunday and it was nearly empty and yet the bartender was still making a point to move slowly.
author: Lance H.

description:
4.5 stars. What a quirky bar! My friends and I came here right as happy hour started, thankfully when the bar was still empty. We were able to secure seats at the bar and order a few drinks. The bartenders are super friendly and conversational. Adds to the lively vibe of the place. 

When I went, there was a theme of "Dr. Seuss." The menus were Dr. Seuss style books, and the cocktails were named accordingly. They were interesting... and themed as well. For example, one was modeled after the flavors of a PB&J sandwich. What a great way to get customers to keep coming back! The books were also for sale, too.

They also have food on their menu, so we got fries for the table. The dipping sauces were incredible. I'd love to try their restaurant upstairs. It sounds like a fun experience, while still being able to enjoy their unique cocktails and wonderful customer service.

Even if it's not my all-time favorite bar, I'd want to come back to Trick Dog again and again to check out what new cocktails they're offering and what themes they're playing around with. Just make sure to get here early because it gets crowded super fast.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
If I wanted a 30 page menu I'd go to Cheesecake Factory. 

That being said, service and food was amazing. AMAZING.
author: Taylor S.

description:
The drinks are always delicious and inventive - with some of the strangest ingredients I have ever seen in a cocktail. Their menu constantly changes and it is always done in an artful way--from picture books to pantone swatches. They are so fun to read and look at - but make it hard to make a quick drink decision! :) 

Also do yourself a favor and order the kale salad!!
author: Shannon H.

description: My cocktail here was great as was the service. I'm giving a 3 star review because, in comparison to other bars that I've been to that make the World's 50 Best Bars list, the vibe/crowd didn't match up at this place. It felt more like an after work happy hour crowd than it did a top notch cocktail lounge. When compared to other spots on the global top 50 list, like Ben Fiddich, the Dead Rabbit, or American Bar, Trick Dog just didn't seem in the same category.
author: Michael C.

description:
Mmm. It has an interesting atmosphere considering it's a cocktail bar. Most of the cocktail bars I've been are a little more formal, less crowded, less noisy. So this kind of caught me off guard, having to fight my way to the bar to order a $14 drink as if I were in a sports or college bar. 

Besides that, we eventually managed to snag seats at the bar. Had 2 drinks each with a friend. They were pretty great, very inventive, and I did like the menu which was like a Dr. Seuss book filled with alcohol. Could be a bit stronger imho, sometimes felt like I was just drinking juice - which I'd be fine with if I ended up feeling a buzz but nope, not this time. The bartenders were good, one with a beautiful mustache. 

But as for ambiance, this is not really the place for me.. or cocktails. This seems like a place to be chugging beer, loud and crowded.
author: Myles C.

description:
We parked nearby for dinner and were drawn over to Trick Dog to check it out. It wasn't too busy when we first approached around 7, but when we came back after dinner, about an hour later, it was PACKED!

Decor is great with low lighting and wood finishes. I was impressed with the bartenders' abilities to recall and make orders while taking other orders in a very crowded, loud bar. 

They have a small food menu, but I had just finished dinner, so food was not on my radar. The drink menu is adorable. It's like a children's storybook with descriptions of the drinks accompanied by illustrations. One of my biggest struggles with "craft cocktail" bars is that I either don't know what's in the drink or what the final flavors will be based on the ingredients. Honestly, I can't always predict what the concoctions will taste like. They give a great summary of the ingredients and what each will taste like and the two drinks I tried matched really well with the explanation. 
 
Like I mentioned, it was packed but we found a stool and some area to lean and were comfortable while we had our drinks.
author: Christine B.

description:
If I lived closer to the Mission, I'd probably be here a lot - their food is reasonably priced, all of which seem to be proportioned in a non guilty way (HUGE salads with bite sized portions for the less healthy items, like chicken nuggets and fries).  They have also added a bit of their own creative flare to the flavors which I always enjoy.

Super cute drink menu.

Upstairs is where there's tables to dine at.  The service was slow and it was loud, but it's nice that it's away from the first floor crowdedness and noise.  Also, we walked in to get table seating when the bar was super crowded, so there's still hope to eat here without a long wait on a busy day!
author: Cathy U.

description: Was wandering the Mission District looking for a cocktail and I definitely came to the right place! I asked for a sweet drink and ended up with the Tantric Yule Log, which was yummy and got me tipsy! Just one drink kept me going for a solid hour lol Got to chat with some cute dudes too =)
author: Tracey M.

description:
All the kitsch on Trick Dog's website made me think, "Too cute. Too much whimsy. Thanks, but your menu-cum-children's book just ain't my thing." Well, I was goddamn wrong. Trick Dog is a very well-executed drinking and eating experience from the moment you walk in to your last slug of booze.

We arrived around 6:30 pm on a Wednesday night. The place was packed with beautiful, well-dressed young people who seemed much more Financial District or tech bro than I expected. But the riff-raff cleared out pretty quickly, and by 7:30 pm there were more seats at the bar, and the population density was very manageable.

The bartenders were all perfect 10 professionals: Super-attentive, engaging, and blessed with bionic hearing. Our first orders were taken by a bartender who was already working on a long row of drinks. But he made eye contact almost instantly from six feet away, handed us the children's book menu, and then somehow heard our orders over the 6:30 pm din. Trick Dog's acoustics may be misleading. It does indeed seem loud, but I never had trouble hearing direct conversation.

So, the drinks. We started with Lunatic Bog (rye, Cynar, oloroso sherry, milk chocolate and green peppercorn, served up) and Hick Dialogue (bourbon, ginger-pinot noir vermouth, Luxardo liqueur, and a "peanut butter & jelly sandwich" garnish, served up). 

The ingredients: WTF?! The results: sublime. Someone put some crazy F'ing attention into these recipes, and the results validate Trick Dog's stellar reputation. That PB&J garnish was an amazing addition: You could smell the peanut butter when you put glass to mouth, adding an extra dimension to the sip of cocktail. Really, super F'ing impressed.

Second order: Frantic Frog (a bourbon drink with Fernet Branca, some mint jelly and green strawberry, served with a jumbo ice cube) and Broomstick Backlog (gin, with Suze, apricot, white miso, lime, and yuzu soda, served long). These two were a bit less "showy" in terms of taste profile, but once again: very good, very deliberate, very special. 

I basically wanted to drink the entire menu. 

For food we had Chicken Tricknuggets, Kale Salad and the Trick Dog -- a hamburger served on a hot dog bun. The salad was ridiculously large, the nuggets were tasty, and the Trick Dog was really, really F'ing good. 

Bottom line: I'm a jaded, judgey, misanthropic San Franciscan. Didn't want to love Trick Dog as much as I did. But, damn, the cocktail creativity and super-friendly bartenders really deserve special kudos.
author: Jon P.

description: Excellent cocktails! Great space! Incredible service! Superior space! Toooootally broke the bank ;)
author: Kim P.

description:
This place is very SF - creative cocktails (starting with the menu), a menu of snacks including things like kale salad, and overflowing with hipsters.  

The menus are always fantastically creative and it's worth a visit just to check them out.  Unfortunately, I find the drinks are often over-worked and strange.  They execute the classics (martinis, etc) beautifully, but the seasonal drink menu is often hit or miss with me.

Food is good and portions are large, if you want kale salad or a creative twist on nachos.

If you want a seat, best to get there before 5:30pm.  It quickly becomes overflowing with hipsters and you'll soon be shouting your conversation at your friends. 

The staff is consistently nice and the prices are reasonable (by SF standards - $13 for craft cocktails with a million ingredients). I want to like it more but I usually leave wishing for more.
author: Rachel R.

description:
I hate to say it, but I just don't get the high ratings for this place. I came here for dinner and a drink with a buddy and we were both super underwhelmed. I ordered the Trick Dog, which is just a regular hamburger except that the patty is shaped longways and it's served in a small hot dog bun. It was $11 and I finished it in like five bites. 

The drinks were good, but they were like $14 each. Don't let the location and decor fool you, this ain't a dive bar. If you don't mind spending a lot on a nice night out, there are a ton of other great cocktail bars that have way better food for the money.
author: Cory D.

description: The kale salad is hands down the best kale salad I've ever had. OK, now that we're through that, this bar is great. They've got well-made drinks for an appropriate price and a full menu of snacks and meals. I adore the kale salad, but the manimal style fries were also amazing. Super good stuff, you should go too.
author: Ruobin W.

description: A Sunday Funday itinerary of different cocktail bars in SF had Trick Dog on the list. It has a cocktail bar vibe and the bartenders are friendly and knowledgeable. I always recommend chatting it up with the bartender if for no other reason to get a feel for the menu. These guys that time to build each drink and the fun part of a cocktail for me is the different balance of flavors in your drink. Of course most cocktails tend to sneak up on you so space your drink with food/water unless you are looking for the other side. I ended up trying the rum based Octavia. I really like the balance and the touch of basil and pepper. Trick Dog was actually not packed nor did it have a line on Sundays so if you're just looking to try some of their cocktails Sunday is a decent option. There are a few areas of seating and we had no trouble grabbing a table in front of the main bar. Trick Dog has a relaxed vibe (at least on Sundays) and if you're a cocktail person worth grabbing a couple drinks.
author: Sean F.

description:
One of the coolest bars ever, you'll find it nestled in a residential area, mostly frequented by locals who know where to find it on the border of The Mission & Potrero Hill neighborhoods.

Every six months, a new themed drink/food menu is prepared. The actual menu is a piece of art, sometimes printed as a Chinese Menu, a Dog Calendar, a collection of campaign buttons, or a book showcasing SF Murals. And each drink is a creative blend of ingredients in cool, custom made glassware and tiki cups. 

The food changes each time but there are a few constants: 
Trick Dog: like a Big Mac on a hot dog bun. 
Kale Salad: this creamy, crunchy, sour salad will forever change your outlook on salads and LIFE. 
Mini Tacos: served in sets of 3 or more- they change every 6 months
Manimal Fries: Like In N Out, but better. 

ALWAYS BRING YOUR ID. They are super strict and won't even let you walk in without proper ID (must be over 21)
author: Mitzi G.

description:
Love the mood setting and their steam punk wall lamps.

Asked the bartender for some AMFs and said they don't make it, so then he made me a substitute and got me finishing my drink real quick.

Thanks to a friend for recommending it, I highly recommend it too!

Would love to come back again for more!
author: Dominique G.

description:
Food: I asked our server about vegan options. The only vegan-friendly options were Brussels sprouts and some pretentiously named Frito-containing-chili (without cheese). I am on a pseudo-elimination diet and (TMI) didn't want to deal with gas after sprout or beans, so I asked for a side of avocado and a side of bread. Both ingredients are on the menu, just not together. I was informed the chefs don't make off menu items, so I asked for plain kale (since their salad has no other vegan friendly ingredients). When our server came back to the table, she said I could do salad with the animal-ingredient-laden dressing, but couldn't have plain kale. What kind of place doesn't allow for someone to order salad without dressing? It's 2018, and food preferences and allergies have never been more prominent. I let our server know I was no longer hungry... The other vegan at our table ordered the pretentiously named Frito-chili. Ten minutes later, arrived to the table in a Frito bag. I would expect the same plating from a food truck.

Service: Super awkward. I walked upstairs and sat down at the table as my friends made their way through the bar and climbed up the staircase. The server who was MIA during my venture upstairs reappeared about a minute after I sat down at a table to ask me if I was expecting 4 other people, since I was alone at the largest table. She seemed pretty annoyed and confrontational for it being our first interaction. She explained the menu but I'm not sure if she actually asked the kitchen to modify dishes or not.

Ambiance: Solid mix of try-hard and strange. It's a steampunk place with 80s music and air-travel-inspired menu.

Overall, one star. This is the first time I've ever sat in a place and sipped water for more than 5 minutes... I was there for maybe an hour (with company) and had nothing to eat or drink. With so many other options in the city that are willing to accommodate food allergies and preferences, there is no need to ever return to Trick Dog.
author: Shannon H.

description:
Super fun atmosphere! It could be hard to miss since there's no sign out front or anything. Myself and 3 others showed up just after opening (3pm that particular day) and it got very crowded within the first hour. Not sure if it was due to Carnaval or if it happens every weekend during the day. We were lucky enough to grab a table which definitely helped enhance our experience. 

I ordered a red eye (12$) and an el sully Mexican beer (6$). The cocktail was very good maybe slightly too sweet with the addition of pineapple juice. I'm a huge fan of the smokey mezcal flavor and it definitely showed in this drink. Normally I'd hesitate to spend that much on a drink but given the area, it seems standard. I've been here at night before and it gets extremely crowded to the point where you can't move that much. 

It's got a cool vibe but I would prefer to come here during the day. I'll be back for sure next time I'm in town.
author: Salil K.

description:
I get the hype for this place and perhaps if I lived closer I might come more often but I live just far enough that I would have to make an effort to come here and I just don't think it's worth it for me. 

While I did love their cocktail menu (when I was there it was a very creative seasonal "book" celebrating the street art of San Francisco) and my cocktail was in fact very good (and creative), I just felt like it was way too loud. I could understand this later on a Friday or Saturday night, not 6 pm on a Monday. It was crowded (usually an obvious sign that a place is worth visiting) but when there is already a lot of noise from conversation why have the music blasting too?
author: Tarah P.

description:
This review is based on three consecutive nights of attending this place. I have to say Friday and Saturday, all the female bartenders were incredible! Unfortunately, on Sunday, we didn't have a great experience. A bartender was extremely rude and seriously took a drink away from us because according to him "he needed to close the bar". The entire night my friend, had to pick up the drinks from the bar because no one bother to deliver the drinks to us, even though there were two only other patrons at the bar. The bartender yelled across the bar asking if we wanted to spilt the bill instead of walking ten paces in our direction to ask us the same question. 

The drinks are incredible, but unfortunately this place lacks good customer service and class, I hope they do better in the future.
author: Claudia H.

description: One stars for the creative drinks. However, the service was appalling. I sat in the upstairs dining area. They got 1 drink wrong and forgot another. Every time they came, they did not pause long enough to even let everyone order. Our table of 4 only ordered two drinks, and while we passed the menu to another person in our party, the server left, leaving 2 of us unordered. They offered no compensation to the 2 drink mistakes.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Fun and inventive cocktail menu with vibrant ambiance. Food menu is not bad either for a cocktail bar. Place is often super packed.
author: Sam M.

description:
Everyone already knows..  and while I have been making sure I hit this place every time I am in SF..  it is just pure 

Does get crowded after work with way too many backpack toting hipster wannabes, but then the crowd evens out and if you get a spot at the bar you can focus 100% on the Tricks.

Don't miss out on the quaint upstairs dining area, as their food is legit.  Chicken Nuggets and a kale salad, and always a tasty dog.

The menu is part of the allure, it changes every 6months..  and is worth a deep inspection itself.
author: Das K.

description: I'm a fan. Fun place, good drinks, great ambiance. I got there around 9pm on a Thursday night and the place was bumping. Music was good. Bartenders were super cool. Drinks were delicious and innovative.
author: Vicky L.

description:
Being somewhat new(ish) to The City, I am still looking for different hang-outs to call my own and fortunately I found the perfect spot: Trick Dog!

Having heard so much about it from s lot of the Mission-ites in the neighborhood, I figured I'd give it a whirl on a Wednesday night.  The theme of the menu was being in "the air" or on a flight with different cocktails named after airplanes and airports. Very cute set up. 

I ordered a Scooby Snack and had the equally cute bartender, Scottie, suggest a good cocktail to follow it.  

I love the ambiance and pricing of this Mission location.  It's got a hipster thing going on, but I didn't find it pretentious or bougie'-which could be because of time set by the attractive, warm, and humble staff.

Real sense of community as everyone is pretty inclusive making me--a very out black trans-woman--feel right at home.

DEFINITELY hanging here more.
author: Amanda M.

description: Great place for a drink. Enjoyed my old fashion. The space is tight so find your spot and enjoy.
author: Linette S.

description: Craaaazy good food!!! Everything on the menu is fire. Great beers, good service, great atmosphere!
author: Wes M.

description:
My friend Mariela found this bar and we decided to meet up for some after work snacks and drinks.  Trick Dog's menu has a political theme with classic political buttons on a paper menu, the idea was unique and asked about it. They switch up the theme of the menu, drinks and food every so often. 

So we sat at the bar, I ordered a HOPE cocktail to start and my friend ordered a non-alcoholic mixed drink. They were both good. To go with our drinks, we ordered Murica's Nachos - Corn chips, Oaxacan cheese wiz, roasted chili and tomatillo salsas, radish, pickled onion and added the black molé ground beef. These were huge and delicious. 

Second round I went for the Beer and Mezcal combo, because why not? We ordered the Freedom Fries, manimal style. Those were pretty fun, like a poutine of sorts. 

The drinks and food were good, I really enjoyed the uniqueness of this place. How it is always changing and revolving around fun new cocktails. Once the cocktail menu has been retired, they upload the recipe or ingredients for you to relive your cocktail. Fun!
author: Rebekah T.

description: Twice I've been there and love the vibe, decor, and drink selection. Sort of a hidden gem in this quiet neighborhood st. Diverse crowd, attentive bartenders and   decent bar style food.  Kale salad is ginormous enough for 5 people seriously good obnoxious. Upstairs drinks and food diners only.. downstairs fills up fast. Limited seating standing room mostly. If you are looking for something unique chill with great drinks, head here with friends after work and unwind. Very trendy cool hipster.
author: TJ S.

description: I don't remember all the drinks we got for my friend's birthday, but we loved the Optimist because it came in this amazing gold peacock goblet. We wanted to buy it for ourselves!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
This place is too expensive. I know it's SF, but come ON. 2 drinks and one kale salad, which yes, is huge and amazing, is cost equivalent to what you might expect to feed 2 people out on their first date, bevs included. 

Yes, the menu is witty and creative. Yes, the drinks that cost $15 a piece are tasty. Yes, there's an upstairs for more civil folk who want to have a decent place to sit while eating.

Apparently it gets super crowded here to the point of excessive discomfort because it's just so trendy, so go on a Tuesday when your friend from out of town visits to justify the ridiculously overpriced dranks and to feel cool for one night.
author: Sarah P.

description:
First things first, Trick Dog is awesome. Coming in on a Wednesday night I expected the place to have a few people hanging around the bar. Nope, not at all! This place was packed! 

We were welcomed with hard-covered story books, turns out those story books were their menus, with a page dedicated to each of their drinks. My gal pal ordered a round of drinks that weren't on the menu -- tequila mules, and even those were delicious. Since it was a busy night, the bartender or should I say cocktail guru, was whipping up at around 5 different drinks at the same time. It was impressive to say the least. 

If you're looking for yummy cocktails, come here, come here, come here!
author: Issabelle F.

description:
if you're lucky and slide in on a relaxed evening, Trick Dog is great for a quality drink and conversation with good company. the Vogue, while a bit more sweet than I'd anticipated, is a well balanced drink that hits the spot on a warm summer evening. I appreciate the restaurant's seasonal approach to their menu (food and drink) and the split levels allow you to choose the ambience you desire (in the fray downstairs or with a bit more privacy upstairs).

it's also worth noting that for a cocktail bar, the kitchen turns out some quality eats. the pupusas, fries, and soba noodles are all solid vegetarian options that leave you satisfied but not overstuffed, and the flavours compliment the drinks nicely. i'd definitely be here on the regular if i lived in the area, although i can imagine it gets hectic on fridays and saturdays (i came on a sunday).
author: Vicki L.

description: This place is incredible. Arguably the best cocktails in SF, cant say I have a favorite because they are always changing but the consistent quality gives you confidence to try new drinks. The food menu is simple on the surface but oh so good. Just a great spot.
author: Scott G.

description:
A bit pricey for drinks, but they were amazing cocktails, and in fact some of the best I've had in the entire Bay Area. Artsy, unique, flavorful, fun, and just all around awesome drinks.
The decor and staff are great and the music was freakin' rad (surf rock, 80's punk, and an entire Weezer playlist!).
The menu was fun to read and the 3 drinks I had were amazing. I had a drink that tasted just like an everything bagel, possibly the best tequila/chile/pineapple/hibiscus drink I've ever had, and a fun sorbet/champagne drink that was super tasty.
Absolutely coming back to try more of the menu!
author: Jeffrey S.

description: If I could only visit one bar in SF, I would choose Trick Dog!  The cocktail menu is a book that is updated every 6 months and sales of the book go to a charity - nice!  I've purchased a couple of the books - but the complex cocktails would be far to difficult to replicate at home.  There is something for everyone - including some delicious low ABV drinks.  We always get the fries (manimal) and kale salad. Dining upstairs is a great option when the downstairs is crowded. Excellent food, quick service, and not as loud as downstairs.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Great veggie options and drinks too. Kale salad, Brussels sprouts FTW, Frito-Pie, and the SQUASH TARTINE!!!
author: Nikhil K.

description: Came here from word of mouth from friends and wished we had visited earlier.  It was airline themed that day so drinks were very creative and good.  Best of all.. the knowledgeable bartenders and.. the mind blowing Chicken Nuggets.  Worth the visit for just those nuggets.
author: Gina W.

description:
Dogs on nuther level mmmm bb. Pour us some hi expectations with a coco cookie I would have jumped thru hoops 4 this. Flavor perfection.

Love us some.

San Flores spiced Tequilla hot hats
Tunstell & Plock Anejo Port white  chocolate tapache pineapple rye berries n lime that comes in fancy cup w funny face

Lay down roll over sit stay

Five stars +++ 7 Hearts
author: Lisa S.

description:
Awesome vibe! I've been here twice on weekends and it can get very packed. The place isn't huge, but the ambiance is really cool here. They have seasonal cocktail menus and are one-of-a-kind.

I'm here for the Manimal fries. We ordered a plate of the manimal fries and WOW. Imagine InNOut's animal-style fries but pushed to the next level. Perfectly fried, super cheesy, and tons of housemade sauce.

I'd come all the way back to it's distant location for just those fries.
author: Aaron M.

description: Switches up every year.. right now the sam Flores is winning. Kale salad. Kale salad. Trick dog. Kale salad.
author: Matt C.

description: Love this bar! The cocktails are some of the best I have had in SF, especially anything with fresh grapefruit. Also, the food is better than expected, and you need to try the kales salad, it is huge! All around a great spot and one of my favorites in the Mission! Would be there every weekend if I lived in the neighborhood! Must try spot for anyone that like a good craft cocktail and energetic vibe!
author: Trevor S.

description: Seriously some of the most creative cocktails I've had! It's a small space, but love the vibe here. The staff are usually really nice and try very hard to attend to everyone even when they are busy. Definitely one of the must-check bars in SF!
author: Nana L.

description:
One of the coolest and most unique cocktail bars in the city.  Went in June, when the drinks were themed from SF Muralists.  The Trick Dog Mural Project is a brilliant marketing ploy as well as a great way to get more gorgeous murals painted throughout the city.

I had the Vogue and tried the Tunstall & Plock.  Both were fantastic.  I liked the Vogue, though you couldn't really taste the bourbon.  The Tunstall & Plock was fruity and served in a really unique mug.  Love this place.  I can't wait to try more off their cocktail menu.
author: Nick D.

description: Trick Dog is one of the best and most innovative bars in San Francisco. The cocktail menu is always changing, every quarter, with a theme. The menu is impressive in itself. However, as notable as the cocktails are, and the bars place in the cocktail world, I'm surprised how this just feels like a neighborhood bar. It's always busy, filled with guys drinking beer from bottles, ignoring the ingenuity and brilliance of the cocktail menu. There is a long bar with some stools and about two or three bartenders. There are some stools along the back wall. The place is small. They also serve food, some snacks, including the Trick Dog. I've never tried the food here but it always smells good.
author: Ryan L.

description: Their cocktails are amazing but you will most likely be visiting at a busy time with loud music, long waits and tight spaces. If you order off the menu it is fine but if you have questions or order off the menu, it can be tough getting within earshot of your bartender. With that said, go during off-peak times for optimal experience.
author: E E.

description: This is such a cool spot! My local friends take their guests here and now I can see why! The menu changes every 6 months based on a new theme and I applaud the artistic inspiration with each drink! Every drink on the menu is so carefully thought up and a true delicate balance of spirit and truly original items. I can't wait to go back next and see what the creatiivity and try it out!
author: Lauren M.

description: Great food and memorable cocktails! One of my favorite bars in town! The menu card is creative and warrants a detailed read through. The ambiance is warm, pleasantly dim-lit, filled with people, good music and vibes that'll keep you there for a while. I enjoy the Friday night scene when it's near full. If we get lucky we'll find a seat right by the bartenders. Else stand and eat and drink and talk sounds good too!:). Some evenings we feel like a sit down experience and we go upstairs where they have tables to dine at, right above the bar:). It may be hard to spot the entrance, but it's part of the charm of this amazing bar! Cheers!
author: Prithviraj V.

description: This place is always way too packed. I've come here for HH after work and late night on a weekend. Both times it was so crowded we barely had room to stand and it was incredibly loud. You have to yell over the music and other patrons to hear your group. The menu and drinks are good but it's not a place I would spend a lot of time.
author: Kara J.

description:
Prepare for your taste buds to be assaulted...in a good way. Avocado in a cocktail? Garam masala? Yup! 

This place takes cocktails to the next level. Right now their drinks are all presidential themed for the election so I opted for the "I am Not a Crook" so that I could try garam masala in a drink. It's tequila along with peach, soda lime and a hint of the spice and is amazing- not super sweet and not overly tequila-y, which is always a huge plus in my book. I also had an "I like Ike," a fabulous concoction of gin, raspberry, lemon egg whites and vermouth.

The best part about this place is that you can also easily go for the bar tenders choice and have them make you something off menu. My friend went down this route and had nothing but great things to say.

This place gets PACKED as the night goes on, so make it your first stop of the evening so there's a chance of being able to move and to hear your company.
author: Elliott W.

description:
Love how chill the music was here, and fell in love with their steam punk wall lamps.

Asked for AMFs from the bartender but since they don't make it there, he made me a substitute and got me finishing my drink real quick.

Thanks to a friend for recommending this place, the staff was very kind & uplifting! Service was great~

Everyone is so mellow, I love it!
author: Domi S.

description: I came back to Trick Dog for my friend's birthday, and man, it is still crazy packed in here on Saturday nights! There is no cover, and the drinks are stiff and shots are cheap. My only complaint is there there isn't too much room to stand around and hang out as a big group. We got there around 9:30pm, and the upstairs area was still reserved for tables/dinner, so we were stuck downstairs. However, they do have a few seats available, and some bar stools towards the front, which is a nice option to have. I'd recommend coming here for some creative and plentiful cocktails if you're just looking to hang out with friends. However, it is super loud in here, so can difficult to actually have an actual conversation. There was no dancing that I could see, which is a shame since they played really good music. Parking wasn't too bad since we all parked earlier in this area for dinner, but street parking spots usually aren't too difficult to find with some circling.
author: Amy D.

description:
Trick Dog is one of those "neighborhood bars" that has outgrown its neighborhood. It's a great place; however, don't expect it to be a secret no one knows about. Everyone in SF knows about it. I do love the cool menu books with mural art. It does a great job incorporating the essence of the Mission.

On this last visit, I had a Bigfoot. A what? Yea, it was good. The bar gets pretty crowded, even on weeknights. Also, the door is not well-marked. If you think you're there, you are. (It's next to Central Kitchen).
author: Yi Z.

description:
Very disappointed in this place after hearing rave reviews and walking by regularly to see the place packed. We ordered three drinks. 

1. The first was some tequila pineapple juice tiki drink. It has some interesting herbal and spicy notes, but it was nothing special. This was the best of the three. 

2. The second was something Mezcal based, served neat with Cocchi Americano and several other wines or liqueurs. These ingredients didn't really compliment each other, it tasted like a cocktail made from picking five bottles from the bar at random. It was mildly unpleasant but not offensively bad. 

3. The final drink was bourbon based with some mint jelly, served over a large ice cube. This is the drink that earned Trick Dog it's one star review. It tasted like someone dumped an entire bottle of generic brand creme de menthe syrup into my cup. I would rather get drunk off winter-mint mouthwash. There was apparently some strawberry flavored something in the drink as well, but I couldn't taste that or even the bourbon, because the terrible mint flavor overpowered everything. Honestly this may have been the worst cocktail I have every had. 

Don't believe the hype, this place is "creative" but by no means good.
author: James H.

description:
Come here if you are looking for creative, thoughtful cocktails. Their menu changes every few months, so don't expect to order the same drinks that you see in the reviews! My favorite drink ever was from a couple years ago (the Leo) -- it had condensed milk and stout but somehow tasted like a tropical vacation. Go figure! Come with an adventurous attitude and expect a crowd; if you're just in the mood for a gin and tonic or glass of wine, I'd recommend going elsewhere. 

Also, I HIGHLY recommend their manimal fries. It will look like barf but taste like delicious, diet-killing sinful goodness.
author: Jean L.

description:
If you are living in San Francisco - you have to go to Trick Dog and it's mandatory for anyone who is living in the Mission. 

You love murals? - they can tell you about the murals around the Mission here 

You love fancy beautiful cocktails that get you drunk? - they got yo' back 

You love food ? - mini burgers are to die for 

Trick dog has it all. Came here for a good time and amazing service
author: Thao P.

description: The Holy Grail of Kale. Came from out of town and a friend brought me here. Just had a few appetizers and a beer (should have tried the cocktails). Hands down best mountain of kale salad I've ever had. I'm still thinking about it two weeks later. Service was excellent on a busy Friday night. Bar area was insanity around 9pm, a popular place but for good reason.
author: Nicole C.

description:
I know this place is touted on their world class drinks but I was a little disappointed. We got a drink that is similar to an old fashioned but had some sour pitch kids stuck to a toothpick to stir with which was super cute and very innovative! I ordered a beer cocktail which sounds interesting but ended up tasting cheap and novice and not worth the amount I paid. 

The actual bar is super cool and looks like something out of a mafia movie! Will give this place another shot on a less crowded night but overall...mehh
author: Rachel N.

description:
Super fun, creative, ever-changing themed drink menu that will likely expose you to something new (a chocolate coated olive, what?). Don't be shy to ask about the drinks to find one that's just right for you.

While the food is generally average, the kale salad is by far the BEST.I'VE.EVER.HAD. They must take that kale to the Four Seasons cuz it's more massaged than Kobe cows. So soft, creamy dressing, and a generous amount of avocado and parmesan. To satisfy the craving, we've even gotten it to go (not sure they're crazy about doing this, but hey, they just made it too good).

Instead of fighting the crowds below, wait for a table upstairs (because hello, you're getting that kale salad) and pat yourself on the back for picking a cool spot.
author: Cristina S.

description:
Trick Dog has long been my favorite place to get craft cocktails. 

I was introduced to Trick Dog a few years ago through industry people on a company trip around SF cocktail-barhopping. Trick Dog is a favorite among many hospitality professionals, and easily a bartender's favorite spot. Sure, their drinks are $12+, but where else are you going to find seasonal, delicious, and pushing-the-envelope cocktails that make you want to taste across the entire menu?!

I love the space, although small and rough to move around once primetime hits...it's always a fun time. Come with a big group or small (will be more comfortable), stay to eat some bar food upstairs or start the night off with handcrafted drinks...you'll always find Trick Dog to be a fun time. The only issue is finding space or even a way to get to the bar once you get there during cocktail hour, but have patience Padawan, and you'll get rewarded a thousandfold!
author: Jodi H.

description: This is a San Francisco gem, whether you are looking for an amazing drink or libation or one of the best burgers in the city look no further. Their playful take on their menus that change seasonally are one of the best parts. I highly recommend this place for dates or hanging with your friends.
author: Jonathan A.

description:
Really mediocre food:
We ordered a kale salad which was very tart and tasty. It was very interesting and something I would recommend ordering. The trick dog was really mediocre, tasted just like a hamburger in a hotdog but. The pickle in it was very crunchy and probably the best part of the order.  We ordered the manimal Fries which were amazing, perfectly crispy and a tasty sauce that went on top. As for the chicken nuggets it had a crispy and crunchy outside but a weird texture on the inside. Really would not recommend ordering that. 

The drinks are interesting and definitely something to try. The pickle back is definitely an experience.
author: Jasmine Y.

description:
Only vouching for their drinks...

There's a reason why Trick Dog has become a tourist stopping point because the locals can't stop (and won't stop) talking about it's amazingness. The bartenders are super attentive, have personality and quick with their drinks. I'd say your average price is $13. 

Check out their super cool menu. Their drinks are named after murals in the city.
author: Laurisha C.

description:
I can see how this place is great for the single, under 35, working in tech-with a high salary-crowd.  It's loud, has great interior design and a cool ambiance.  Drinks were, um interesting, but we wouldn't know.

Menu was absolutely bizarre and confusing.  Maybe we should have researched a bit more before hitting it up (we were waiting for a table at nearby Farmhouse Thai).  

We didn't know what to make of the Dr Seuss theme menu so we ended up ordering an Old Fashioned and a glass of cava.  Maybe this place wasn't for us, and more targeted for people who like trendy drinks like ritz-cracker infused cocktails.  Or cream cheese flavored drinks.  As for us, we were baffled and the bartender made no attempt to try to guide us.  So our experience was just blah.  Drinks were standard but $$$.  The "inventive" cocktails were $14 and wine was under $15.

Observed the clientele- mostly 20's and early 30's single white and Asian, white-collar job and out with their group of friends/coworkers (one of the same with this type of crowd).  

NOT FOR: the Marina crowd (frat/sorority types, no one was dressed to impress), anyone past the age of 35, couples, romance/dates.  It is extremely LOUD inside- and outside this bar.
author: Cin P.

description: Was in the neighborhood for dinner and with 30 min to kill we decided to check out trick dog. In a very quiet neighborhood but it was definitely packed inside. We were able to get to the bar and only waited a few min to get our order in - tantric Yule log and broomstick backlog. The menus are these cute hardback story books. Bartenders were efficient and we soon had our drinks. Only problem now was finding a place to hang out. There are only a few seats along the bar and some tables along the back wall. Otherwise you'll be lucky to find a corner or wall to lean against. Drinks were strong and delicious! Definitely want to come back and try more. Upstairs seemed to be a quieter dining area?
author: Yin H.

description:
The new aviation themed menu isn't nearly as good as the previous children's story book menu.

Everyone seemed to be ordering the Red Eye but I went for the BOS as I like bourbon and another drink with manzanilla sherry which clearly wasn't memorable as I can't remember the name and anything other than that it was really sweet. I wouldn't get either again but would give this menu 1 more chance, although I hope they change it before my next SF trip. 

I don't recommend the Manimal style fries. It's just a kitchen sink type of dish with too much cheese. You're essentially getting overpriced cheese fries.
author: Rachel G.

description: I can tell why this is one of the top 100 bars in the US! It was crowded when we arrived but thankfully we managed to grab a spot on the counter. I love that the drinks are modelled after airport terminals around the world. I have the SEA which was delicious!!
author: Run.It.Off V.

description: Feel mixed about this place.... the drinks are definitely good but don't know what all the hype is about really.  Lots of places in sf have great cocktails...
author: Jenna C.

description:
Bartenders are very attentive here. We went after work on a Tuesday night and were given menus right away. We only waited for about 20 mins total which was perfect since our friends were meeting us. 

We ordered plenty of food, including the trick dog, pork tacos, kimchi rice cakes (actually rice rolls), chicken nuggets and manimal style fries (highly recommend). I also ordered "the optimist" to drink. It was very tasty and just the right amount of alcohol and flavor. Even though it was placed in a ridiculous peacock cup that weighed about 10lbs and was freezing cold. lol

The check took a while to get but it seemed like the waitress was having a rough day. The vibe was good and the setting cute and trendy. All in all great experience. I will definitely be returning and probably sooner rather than later. :)
author: Ashley K.

description:
A girl friend and I came here for Galentine's and it was the perfect spot. Upon entering, the first floor is a bar before making your way upstairs for the restaurant. The dim-lit ambiance in a warehouse like interior gave this place a rustic, yet romantic feel. Their drinks menu is made into a freaking book --how cool is it?! I ordered some kind of whiskey that came with three sour patch kids ($13), how cute! Also, definitely needed that to finish off the strong as hell whiskey they have going on.

For food, we shared the Manimal Fries ($7) and Kimchi Ricecakes ($11). Although it seems small, both dishes filled us up plenty!
