description: We went on a Monday night expecting a quite drink. We were wrong. This place was bumping (don't judge me for saying that). The drink menu was so creative we endeavored to try one too many. Which lead us to order nachos. Thank god we did. I usually find nachos trashy but I couldn't stop eating these!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Trick Dog is a good bridge between bars and lounges. It was filled on a Tuesday (weekends are packed) so go weeknights if you can. If you don't go to lounges often, this venue is not too fancy or nice that you would feel out of place. Like at many lounges and speakeasy-themed spots, the drinks are very good - skillfully made with top-shelf quality ingredients. Of the drinks I tried, favorites are in order:

Pantone 7621 - a good kick & didn't overwhelm the foods.
Straw Hat - a second drink.
Paper Moon - good and strong starter to the evening.
Baby Turtle - good in-between drink.
Lion Heart - just strong enough when starting the night.
Alligator Alley and Vintage Photo were very nice as well.

The entire venue set-up resembled a loft, albeit loud and you will have to raise your voices to be heard. Downstairs is the bar like most places but it's not divy nor dim. Upstairs is the sit-down-dine area which is pretty nice for a bar. The eats were fancified bar food and really good though don't look for dinner-size portions. However, smaller plates works as they're better priced and allow for more tastings.

The restroom down the hall is shared with the restaurant Central Kitchen. Parking may be tough in the area, and it is quite a walk from the BART/Muni stations.
author: Peter L.

description:
Do yourself a favor and go to the upstairs seating area! It's kind of small, but if you come on a Sunday evening it won't be so packed. 

If your'e looking at the food menu, they have a really amazing kale salad!! I think I liked this kale salad more than the fries or anything else I ate here. They also have really great drinks here. I can't quite remember which drinks I've had here, but they're all solid choices.
author: Jeanette S.

description:
Two years ago, I gave up on Mr. Tequila after he left me on the floor at the Palazzo Hotel in Vegas. I woke up to my bachelorette friend and a trio of security guys hovering over me shaking their heads. Damn you, Mr. Tequila.

Once Mr. Tequila left my life, I've done some growing up and have been semi-behaved. That's until I saw him featured in the Patone-colored menu at one of the hottest new bars in SF.

From the people who brought you Flour + Water, Salumeria, and Central Kitchen (next door) comes Trick Dog, an industrial vintage bar in Potrero Hill/Mission serving creative artisanal cocktails ($8-$12) by cute bartenders along with tantalizing bar food eats. 60's and 70s Motown favorites from The Supremes, Marvin Gaye, and Jackson 5 playing in the background added to that old-time feel.

Trick Dog is cracking and even on a Wednesday at 5:30 pm, all the bar seats were taken (hipster and yuppie crowd). Come early as it's a small bar and there's only 12-14 stools. They do have an upper level with tables but all the action is downstairs. Parking is all residential and it may take several rounds to find a spot.

There were over 20 artisanal cocktails on the menu and against my better judgment, I ordered the Baby Turtle: tequila, campari, grapefruit & lime topped w/ a creamy egg froth ($12). It was wonderfully refreshing with a luscious creamy and fragrant finish from the cinnamon sprinkled egg white froth: http://bit.ly/ZFrt6I. I'm usually not a cocktail girl but this one was cocktastic; cocktail-wise that is. I expected nothing less from the Bon Vivants/Owners who consulted on the menu for 15 Romolo among other bars known for their stellar cocktails.

Happy hour is never complete without something to nosh on. Perusing the menu of cracklins, mushroom hummus, sweetbreads, the burger, and other delectable eats, we decided to exercise some self-control and order one item, the $10 Scotch Egg. One for each of us because I never share my yolk. Fernet lovers: there's even Fernet ice cream on the menu which I regrettably forgot to order. The kitchen closes at 1:30 am. 

It's a good thing we ordered two Scotch eggs because it was incredibly delicious: http://bit.ly/13Xsdem. Perfectly fried to a golden brown, the salt cod (tastes exactly like dungeness crab) encased egg was crunchy on the outside with an yolk that oozed out like lava upon cutting into: http://bit.ly/13XsfTF. The beet confit, creme fraiche and salmon roe made it that much more decadent.

Trick Dog is a great neighborhood bar to distress and drown yourself in one of their yummy cocktails but beware of their not very "happy" hour prices (no hh specials). The tab for two was $80 (including tip) for four cocktails and two Scotch Eggs. Ouchie. Minus one star for a pricey menu in this more desolate area of SF.

Nobody ended up on the floor this time after Mr. Tequila's reappearance but he did make the bill less painful to hand over my debit card after downing two Baby Turtles. 

For those hella balling, Gilt City has a "deal" for Trick Dog: http://www.giltcity.com/san-francisco/trickdogsfmar. You can have a private party for 20 guests for a mere $5,000 (cocktails only) or 75 guests for $15,000 (cocktails and food). Pshhh, just the cost of a wedding banquet...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
So many drinks, so little time.

That's why you go with a huge group of people and sample as much as you can! We all came to celebrate Peter L's birthday. All six of us!

Drinks:
1. Boduolige shuang ($13): Don q anejo rum, vecchia romagna brandy, benedictine, banana cream, hidalgo oloroso, lime
2. Shengdanshu ($13): high west double rye, bonal quina, leopold brothers cranberry liqueur, amaro lucano, balsam fir
3. Qincai he boluo ($13): Plymouth gin, bigalet china china, pineapple, celery seed, lime, cel ray, gardenia
4. Kaite lin bu xihuan ($13): coconut-infused atlantico platino rum, luxardo apricot liqueur, green tea, harissa, lime
5. Da maijia ($13): old grand dad bonded bourbon, ancho reyes, mango, ginger, lemon, cola, bitters
6. Zang mading nei si ($13): tanquerey old tom gin, alessio vermouth de torino, mandarine napoleon, almond, jasmine, olive, chocolate
9. Jianguo gei ni ($13): evan williams bourbon, kumquat cordial, walnut-infused fernet branca
11. Wen xiang nainai ($13): absolut vodka, sibona chamomile liqueur, tempus fugit liqueur de violette, grapefruit, lime, pontarlier anis
12. Kafei he xiangyan ($13): dewars 12 scotch, st george nola coffee liqueur, hidalgo pedro ximenez, malt extract, cinnamon, rooibos marshmallow
18. Nikka coffey grain whisky with swamp pop satsuma soda ($12)

And that's why we were able to try so much! My favs were 2 & 9. I tend to like my cocktails dark and boozy, so both of these did the trick. 12 was also a nice cocktail, but more like dessert. Coffee flavored with some sweetness.

Food:
72. Kale salad ($9): avocado, parmesan, pepitos, slow-cooked egg yolk dressing 
74. Shrimp noodles ($13): chinese trinity, cloud ear mushroom, garlic chives, crispy garlic, lao gan ma
75. The trick dog ($10): house-ground blend of chuck & brisket, lettuce, onion, pickles, cheddar cheese, house sauce
76. Chicken tricknuggets (13 pc $15): sweet and sour, chinese mustard and soy dipping sauces
80. Manimal style fries ($7): house sauce, cheddar cheese, charred scallions
81. Baby bok choy ($5): roasted shitake mushrooms, garlic soy glaze

I didn't think the food here was that great. The dishes were good for snacking while drinking, but I'd never come here just to eat. I think my favorite dishes may have been the nuggets and the fries. And they were pretty simple. Nuggets with dipping sauce and fries with cheese and sauce. Hard to mess that up right?

Great spot for drinks, but I'd go next door to eat next time.
author: Elena N.

description:
One of my absolute favorite bars in SF. I kind of hate writing this review because I don't want to make it more popular than it already is. Yes, I realize it's very humble of me to take credit for the popularity of Trick Dog. ;)

Very creative cocktails. Even though I'm one to enjoy going off menu, the menus and the cocktails are always beyond innovative. It's so impressive to see the theme get carried so thoroughly throughout, even though it changes every 6 months. A really brilliant production. That said, I won't even bother pointing out favorite cocktails, as they will be gone soon anyway

On the topic of food however, their staples are really great. The famous trick dog, the mound of kale, the chicken nuggets (omg that sweet & sour sauce) and the fries. 

Awesome staff. Very friendly (made my first SF friend here!). Very impressive considering how busy they always are.
author: Rita K.

description: Great spot in the Mission to go for drinks with friends after work or on a weekend. Does get pretty busy, there's only a few seats and they fill up fast. They have an awesome cocktail menu!
author: Ghazal S.

description:
The themes are fun and the drinks are good but this spot is soooo crowded and the set up isn't ideal. My group of four was backed into a corner and couldn't hear one another. We got there pretty early, too.

Bonus points for the sprinkles that were in my drink!
author: Sara M.

description:
I liked the setting: it was dark with pretty cool industrial lights. The place was really small though and they only let in people in when people leave. 

Drinks: I like sweet fruit drinks so I was not really into their special drinks menu, which was a lot of strong drinks with liquor I don't like (whiskey, tequila). The vodka one they had with fruit was with egg white (dang it) as well. Cocktails were also expensive, around  $13 for a small little glass. I got a Reptilian drink. They do change their menus every 6 months. This time, the theme was top secret documents about monsters like Big Foot which I thought was clever. Though the menu size was too big! I'm not talking about the number of pages. The dimensions of the menu was literally too big so it was hard to hold and flip through in such a crowded space.

Since the drinks on the menu weren't really my taste and were also expensive, I give this place a 2.
author: Vio C.

description:
Cocktails: great
Ambience: ok, wannabe hipster I think.


Compared to other SF bars, this is very good.
Compared to some of the best in Las Vegas and Manhattan, it's okay.
author: Sridevi K.

description:
For some reason, when I entered the front door of Trick Dog, I felt like I was walking onto the set of a reality TV show where a lot of twenty-somethings were trying to get as drunk as possible just to irritate the hell out of me. I had heard about the bar scene here, so it was with trepidation that I greeted my colleague Robbie's suggestion that a group of us come here for a late night dinner. It shares the same warehouse-style building that houses Central Kitchen, which I felt was a marginally disappointing dining destination when Jamie W. and I went there a couple of years ago. So it was onward and upward as the four of us squeezed through the hipsterati (photo: http://bit.ly/1uGdqhj).

We finally made our way to the comparatively becalming upstairs section where people actually dine (photo: http://bit.ly/1zQ8Xhr). Even though the noise level was still pretty high, at least the space gave us a reprieve from all the shoulder jostling that could have occurred down below. The menu turned out to be a nice selection of interesting plates (photo: http://bit.ly/16lhQoJ), but first I needed some libation. The $10 Low Proof section of the menu was good enough for me, so I ordered the Necklace of Lights, a nice tall one with Manzanilla sherry, aquavit, peach, lemon and soda (photo: http://bit.ly/1BKkeST). Refreshing for 11PM and it relaxed me from the stress brought on by the crowds. We shared plates since I was among colleagues who are friends as well.

There was a predictable start with the $7 Guacamole mixed with sweet corn and accompanied by a pile of Mission tortilla chips that needed to be replenished (photo: http://bit.ly/1w5KC6z). No complaints from me as the fresh avocado just whet our appetites for more. Then came two orders of their Thrice-Cooked Fries, which were Kennebec potatoes that were boiled and fried twice - one naked ($5 - photo: http://bit.ly/1BKldlW) and the other Manimal style with chow chow sauce and ketchup ($7 - photo: http://bit.ly/1BB8DTf). Very satisfying for fries. More adventurous choices came next first with the $11 Crispy Duck Egg, tasty and savory as it came deep-fried atop cranberry beans, chorizo, Cojita cheese and epazote salsa verde (photo: http://bit.ly/1wuYjKU). I have to say the evening's winning dish came in the form of the $9 Kale Salad.

It was piled high on a plate with chopped greens with a creamy egg-based dressing, chunks of avocado, toasted pumpkin seeds and Parmesan cheese (photo: http://bit.ly/1spLxik). The $11 Tomato Salad was overshadowed even though the Early Girl and Sungold tomatoes lent a welcome freshness complemented by the burrata, basil seeds and bread crumbs (photo: http://bit.ly/1A7vN2D). The most anticipated plate came next, the $10 namesake Trick Dog, a tender burger shaped like a frank to fit into a sesame seed hot dog bun and ladled with lettuce, onion, pickles, cheddar cheese and their house sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/12M4CiA). It was tasty but relatively inconsequential compared to the other plates. We finally ended our meal with something sweet, the $10 Fig Tartine, which mixed Kabdota figs, their own housemade ricotta cheese, peanut brittle, ver jus and a lime vinaigrette (photo: http://bit.ly/1uGemT0). 

FOOD - 4 stars...better than expected food really chows creative flair and solid flavors
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...quite loud though cordoning off the upstairs for their dining clientele was a smart move
SERVICE - 4 stars...very attentive and informed
TOTAL - 4 stars...the Bon Vivants deliver the goods in this space even if the bar noise dilutes the dining experience
author: Ed U.

description: I'm only giving 4 starts to this place is because they have the most amazing kale salad. Holy crap it's so good. I also really like that their menu is a calendar and proceeds go toward helping dogs get adoptive. LOVE that. I would only come back for the restaurant part of Trick Dog. The bar part is very whatever to me. It's crowded and just not my type of place. Nicely filled place though if that's what you are looking for.
author: Julie L.

description:
Trick Dog always gives me the giggles. There are definitely hyper-hipster aspects here.  Let's start with the dramatic cocktail menus. What used to be Pantone strips now is in the form of a book of records. Took me a minute to realize each record actually has the name of a cocktail on it, themed to suit the song name ("Ain't No Sunshine," "Eye of the Tiger")...I had just flipped to the Spirits insert towards the back, and settled on a gin and lilikoi (so hip we can't call it "passion fruit") soda, which was surprisingly tasty.

Then there are the handsome bartenders, with their hip aprons and the spectacle of watching one of them shake up not 2, but 3 drinks at one time. This place is so cool I once waited for 15 minutes around 8pm on a Thursday to get in. It's so cool it draws quite the eclectic crowd (veers to older), from lumberjack beard man to Marina girls night out, and you can get your thrice-cooked fries "manimal style" if you so desire.

Sure it's a pain to push your way to the bar, cringe that you're always up in the personal space of those seated as you call out your order, and feel like you're watching paint dry as you wait for your drink, but once you have it in hand, you realize it's a pretty tasty concoction that has fancy garnishes like lemon slices (not wedges!) and...you feel immediately cooler. I'll be back...outside peak hours.
author: Jen E.

description:
I have had this place bookmarked forever and was so excited to visit. I was sadly disappointed by my visit. They have rotating themes. They currently have a Chinese theme. The signage out front is simply a pink sign with Chinese symbols. We walked by it twice before we realized what it was. 

The bar downstairs is very hipster with wood paneling and hand crafted cocktails. We wandered upstairs so that we could sit down and get some food with our drinks. I was saddened to see that none of the items mentioned on yelp that I had wanted were there. We settled on the chicken nuggets, Trick Dog sandwich and the manimal fries. The fries were very thick and dry. It was happily topped high with a sauce which was good, but didn't leave me wanting more. The chicken nuggets had an odd texture to them and needed their dipping sauces. 

I can say that the Trick Dog sandwich was really good! It had a great flavor and perfect texture. I also really liked our drinks. I got the number 1 which came in a Chinese style tiki glass. It had quite a kick to it and was quite yummy.
author: Kari G.

description: I love the creativity and execution of this place! Their rotating menu is so unique and designed very thoughtfully. The drinks deliciously crafted and the kale salad is phenom. The service is fantastic as well. The waitstaff and bartenders are all helpful and all around awesome. Def a great place to just hang out and have a drink or two (I'd say three, but the drinks are pretty strong).
author: Wendy Y.

description:
The cocktails are creatively named and creatively executed!  The menu changes every once in a while and the presentation of that cracks me up every time.
The place can get super loud and packed.  Other times it's more mellow.  One issue that I had on my last visit a few weeks back was that when it was pretty slow, was that my friend and I had to wait a super long time just to get asked what we would like to have, then the guy proceeded to take other people's drink orders and make them their cocktails, but just seemed to forget about ours.  It was only when I went, "hey, how are our drinks coming?" that he went, "Oh yeah," and made them.  Silly.  But generally a fun place!
author: Gillian K.

description:
The first time we went to Trick Dog, we entered the crowded bar looking for food in the early afternoon. It was our first time eating out after a month of homemade food. As such, we were being picky about our first restaurant experience in a while, and were intimidated by the lack of seating and tables, and left.
We came back a few weeks later in the evening, and this time we were asked if we wanted food, and were directed upstairs. Ah hah! The upstairs area is much more fitting for food. Nice little tables, cool lighting fixtures, neat windows.

The menu was a tad sparse with vegetarian food, but it was getting late, and I wasn't so hungry, so I went for the kale salad.
Shortly after, as we were enjoying cocktails (they were okay. The ones I had were not as amazing as Pläj's), we watched a neighboring tale get their kale salad. It was a huge mountain of a salad! Like, half a 4" tall pile of salad. As I panicked about how much food I had ordered for a late-night snack, I thought it had to be multiple orders. But no, that's a single order.

Luckily, it was tasty enough (avocado and lemon, yum yum) that the meat-eaters helped me finish it. While their Trick Dogs could work as a late night snack, the Kale Salad is best split among a few friends.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Trick Dog offers a fun atmosphere and good music. 

The drinks are awesome. I love the different themes the drinks cater to. However, they are quite pricey.
author: Tunaidi A.

description: Kale salad was delish. Drinks we kinda pricey, but also delish!
author: Regina J.

description:
I have been meaning to go here for some time to sample their artisan cocktails.  Menu changes frequently as they apparently like to keep trying new creations.  My rye-based cocktail was very good.  

Sadly, they couldn't come up with a cocktail to satisfy my lady friend.  I asked for something non-boozy and pleasantly flavored for her...3 tries and they couldn't get it right.  She didn't drink any of them.  Under the circumstances I would have thought charging me for just 1 or none of her drinks would have been appropriate, but no, I was charged for the lot.  

Ambiance is that of a dive bar with few women in the room ( maybe a good thing for you girls looking to hook up).  Bottom line, you can get better artisan cocktails at many places in SF that are better than this on all counts!
author: Howard B.

description: Came for late night drinks so I can only comment on the bar. Very schticky with their "Top Secret" drinks menu, with each drink warranting it's own page in the very large menu. But still very much appreciated if you are in the mood for something fun! Great craft put into their drinks. I tried the Japanese whiskey highball which had mushroom and ginger. I enjoyed it. It wasn't too bitter or earthy, but tasted just balanced enough. I also tried the bourbon based chemtrails. This was a bit sweeter but also tasted pretty good. This is more of a neighborhood spot and I probably wouldn't go out of my way again to come back, but it was great to try.
author: Vivian D.

description:
Great food, amazing friendly staff, strong tasty cocktails.

I'd never been here before. It's a bar downstairs, and a small restaurant upstairs that gets its food from the restaurant next door. When I walked in the bar tender did the opposite of what bar tenders do, and she acknowledged me and assisted me with a menu, within moments of walking in. 

3 of us sat upstairs and ordered several of their speciality cocktails, which had an asian theme (My friend says the restaurant theme changes every so often). 

As for food, we shared:

- Chicken nuggets
- Kale salad
- Spicy noodles
- Manimal style fries

Everything was superb. The kale salad is enormous and could feed like 6 people, and is a great side to cut through the rest of the totally unhealthy food. Chicken nuggets were good, but the fries were some of the best I've ever had, and we destroyed the noodles and ordered more. 

The only reason this place doesn't get 5 stars is because it's not cheap. Cocktails are $13 a pop and between the 3 of us with 9 drinks and food the bill was over $200 but I suppose that would happen anywhere you order 9 drinks :)
author: Jordan C.

description:
This is another Yelp! success. One of the fine community managers sent out the standard email with cool bars to try, one of the options being Trick Dog with its 4+ star rating, and I absentmindedly bookmarked it. Fast forward to a goofy weeknight in SF and we're looking for somewhere to have a late drink. I pulled out my phone and, viola, there was Trick Dog in my bookmarks. Done deal.

The bar staff and patrons are very friendly. The drinks are interesting and extremely tasty. My favorite was the Lombard, but could have easily drank the other drinks I tasted. Everything was well balanced and smooth.

On a side note, we ended up going again on a Saturday night, and the place is pretty crowded all night. If you're looking for more of a laid back environment, you may want to wait until the crowd thins out and go late.
author: Akash K.

description:
Damn, son.  Trick Dog lives up to its reputation with some phenomenally well-crafted cocktails.  Do get here on the earlier side to snag an upstairs table - you seat yourself and the server will come by to take food & drink orders.  My City Lights was  fantastic with its undertones of fruit and bready notes to accentuate the gin-forward foundation.  Likewise, I found the Alcatraz to be top notch in its floral and citrus qualities that elevated the Four Roses small batch base.

While we didn't order much in the way of food, I can absolutely vouch for the ginormous kale salad.  At $9, it's a gargantuan pile of crazy nutrient-dense awesome tossed in an exceptionally balanced egg yolk dressing.  Easily shareable between two people even for someone with my appetite!

What really rounded out our experience though was the wonderful service.  With the crowd growing by the minute as the night went on, one of the staff came by to politely ask if my friend and I could move downstairs and free up our table.  I was happy to oblige, but not before she apologized profusely and offered a round of cocktails on the house for us.  Truly above and beyond service that left a lasting impression on me.  Couldn't recommend this place more, just know that it's crackin' on prime nights!
author: Eric F.

description:
Where customer service went and died.

Within a minute of walking in, I was treated like I kicked their dog. Don't know if I managed to somehow offend with ordering a salad, or if they were just tired after a long day, but there was no effort to leave any positive impression or just to make eye contact and acknowledge that I was a person. 

Maybe I wasn't spending $$ on an indefinite amount of their drinks? I don't know but I haven't been treated so rudely in a long time within seconds of meeting someone. 

That's what I'll remember about this place.
author: Joanna Q.

description:
I give the cocktails and healthy, yummy snacks 5 stars. Go when it opens or right before the kitchen closes, this is when it's quietest.

I'm a neighbor and this place is EXTREMELY noisy and I don't like having to walk through smokers on the street.

Go to Asiento, Debi has her ceilings soundproofed and has Djs nightly and there is never noise bleed or smokers!
author: Bernadette B.

description:
By far my favorite bar in SF! They're squash is unreal, and their bartenders are top notch. I don't order off the menu, I just pick and alcohol, give them three adjectives, and am always blown away. Plus, Trick Dog is one of a limited number of places in the city to get good food and booze after midnight.

Can't endorse enough!
author: Juli R.

description:
Order the old fashioned (either rye or bourbon) and the baby turtle. Nuff said. 

The bartenders there are super friendly and knowledgeable. Watching them make a cocktail is like watching an artist paint... or a sculpture sculpt... or Brad Pitt in slow motion. Wait. Okay you get the idea. 

Fair warning, this place gets SUPER packed, so if you want to eat/get your fair share of drink orders in, plan to arrive early.
author: Andrew E.

description:
My experience is incomplete. My friend and I made our way over from the Richmond after seeing a commercial with an egg resembling the Scotch Egg, and I knew it was on (commercials really work apparently). 

Unfortunately when we got there, the place was packed, but we gave my name and phone number to the hostess to wait for a table, and grabbed some Negronis at the bar. While we sipped, we were told that, sadly, the Scotch Egg had sold out for the night. The drinks were stiff and the ambiance was very chic yet cozy. Hope to be back for some egg yolky goodness.
author: Crystal C.

description: Great drinks, menu is always unique and rotating. Definitely recommend this place. This month, for December, their menu is on a 2016 calendar with the cutest dogs on each page. You can buy the calendar for $20 to support the Muttville and Family Dog Rescue!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Friendliest bouncer ever!
Interesting cocktails although I stuck with a lagavulin old-fashioned, which was balanced just so. Friendly and lively atmosphere. Hip without being pretentious. Would definitely come again.
author: Victoria C.

description: My friend and I had a great time at Trick Dog last Friday evening after work!  Get the pina colada for two complete in a pineapple - watch your eyeballs when you go in for the straw though!  Pineapple tops are pokey!  We also had the Area 51 cocktail where they spray a stencil image of an alien on the top foam, and I had a citrusy cocktail with rum (I can't remember the name but yum!).  We also ordered the kale salad (loved this!), chicken nuggets (nicely fried and loved the sauces) and the fries with everything on it (I think called "animal" style, also yum, not good for the heart but yum anyway!).  Go there!  Plus the bartenders are all easy on the eyes!
author: Maile N.

description:
Bar tenders are very friendly and helpful. I was surprised how quickly they reached out and got our orders. 

Food is super tasty, drinks are fancy and delicious (but not too froofy).
author: Glenn T.

description:
When my friends and I hit up Trick Dog for dinner, we tried almost everything on the menu. I really liked everything, but there were a few real standouts. My hands down favorite thing was the Kale salad, and by the sheer volume of them flowing out of the kitchen, a lot of folks out there agree. Part of its' wonderfulness is its' simplicity. This one has  avocado, parmesan, pepitos, and a slow-cooked egg yolk dressing. Yum Their version of a Scotch egg was pretty fabulous too. It came with the requisite soft-boiled egg, but instead of the typical sausage wrapping, they chose to go with a brandade (an emulsion of salt cod and olive oil) wrapping. The fish tasted like fish sticks (in a good way) and made me think of breakfasts as a kid. If I HAD been at home, that would have mean it would be paired with a warm Winchell's jelly doughnut, but I was at Trick Dog, so I had to make due with purple potato salad and romesco sauce. My third favorite was the Fig Tartine. It had Kadota figs, housemade ricotta, and pinenut brittle (!!!) with a verjus and lime vinaigrette. It was delicate and super fresh. We didn't try the burger or fish tacos, both of which looked intriguing. I think they may be on the docket for a future visit. 

All the cocktails are interesting. I could only have one, so I opted to go the rye route and have a Fugazi Bank. It's not for the faint of heart, but it's a nicely balanced tipple. My friend's Cliff House was lovely, even though I was wishing for more chocolate. The atmosphere is no frills, but there is a chance for some good people watching. Service was fine. I kind of wish they took reservations, but won't complain too much about it because people (me included) can be flighty and the seating area is pretty cozy. You might get lucky, but don't be too surprised if you have to wait a bit. Definitely recommended!
author: Nicole M.

description:
I was digging the prohibition era set up and crafty drinks. I had one of their special boiler makers, which is a bottled beer and a shot of the suggested liquor.

The bartender recommended we try their homemade fireball shots. How do you say no to a stud who knows his way around the bar? So, after a few shots we definitely felt the heat.
author: Sarin P.

description:
I got here closer to 6pm, and it wasn't very crowded. But give it an hour, and this place gets packed. I got a seat at the bar where I was meeting a friend. Open up the menu to a map of the different areas in SF, and those are the drinks. I thought it was actually just a map at first glance. Their drinks are stiff, so be careful. They may taste like juice but they are strong. 

I was really looking forward to their cracklins and Scotch egg, but they no longer serve it. They have updated their menu. Most things we ordered instead were good though. The Kale salad is pretty sizable, and good. The animal style fries (they call it something else) were amazing and we were tempted to order a second one. We also got a duck egg, and that was delicious and on par with what I expect the Scotch egg to be. 

The night was fun. Major props to the great drinks and food. Bartenders were awesome too.
author: Jeanne M.

description:
Excellent excellent whiskey bar with great food options! This is an amazing bar in Noe Valley and a must try. The cocktails are to die for as well and the idea behind the menu is pretty cool.

They are not kidding around with their whiskey. Definitely try this place!
author: Kabir S.

description: Stopped in here after dinner on a business trip. Trick Dog was highly recommended by a friend who lives in the city. Loved the warm, fun vibe and inventive cocktails. Warning: they make 'em strong - watch out!
author: Nathan W.

description: Really yummy cocktails and great bar food. I like what this bar does with it's ever revolving concept and ideas. They get really creative with their cocktails and are truly done the way they should be. Highly recommend you try it. It's just fantastic. Couldn't praise the bartenders more.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Still one of my favs in SF 

I hope the kale salad never disappears because it will make me cry. 

Current Menu- Conspiracy Theories 

CROP CIRCLE IS SO GOOD
author: Anne-Mary P.

description:
So I was on a recent trip to SF and Trick Dog was a definite must on my list. It was recently names one of the best bars in the world along with another SF bar. I had tried to go to the other bar on the list, Smugglers Cove, the night before and didn't even get in because of the pretentious and angry man working the door who had an attitude problem. I had almost lost hope that I would get to try one of SF's best bars but then I went to Trick Dog.

Trick Dog doesn't have a sign out front so when we first arrived we were confused if we had gotten the address correct. We stopped to try and look around and immediately a friendly man approached us and said "Looking for Trick Dog?" and he lead us right into the bar. I immediately felt welcomed! The bar had an upstairs with sit down tables and the downstairs was the actual bar. We were able to get a seat right away and were instantly handed a drink menu. The menu itself was literally a map with each drink named after a neighborhood/attraction in SF which was pretty cool.

We tried a total of four drinks; Lombard Street, Alcatraz, Mission Dolores and Fugazi Bank. My favorite was the Mission Dolores which was a sweet drink of four rums, followed by the Lomard Street drink. Overall, all of the drinks were fantastic and it was fun sitting at the bar and watching the bartenders work their magic. 

The staff was really friendly and I am so glad I finally got to visit this place. The service, drinks and atmosphere were top notch and I can't wait to return!
author: Courtney D.

description:
Apparently Trick Dog changes their theme. So no more Scotch Egg. This time it's a Chinese theme. There's no signage outside other than two Chinese characters in red that translate to "trick dog". Good thing there's a bouncer standing out there watching for confused patrons and asking us "are you looking for trick dog?".

The space is long and skinny, two floors. Kinda like Rickhouse downtown. But not nearly as crowded. Service could possibly be worse though.

The entire menu is in Chinese with pinyin translations of the names. Luckily the descriptions are in English and each item has a number to order from.

Choose quickly then peruse as you stand around trying to get the bar's attention. Literally there were 5 people behind the bar and only one person making drinks. Took me 20 minutes to get my order in and at least another 15 before it showed up. After that though it wasn't as bad. Not sure if things were going smoother behind the bar or if we as a group were able to get their attention better when we needed it, or maybe we were just being efficient and when one person wanted to order everyone else would rush in with their requests.

Drinks themselves are very very good. I tried the #2 (cranberry), #3 (tropical gin), #9 (herbal bourbon). I like how they pair up the flavors. But I like strong drinks and herbal flavors.
author: Jean K.

description:
Don't waste your time. There are plenty of great spots in this city and the last thing I am going to do is run up a tab at a bar where the owner and management have so little regard for the customer experience. 

When we got to the bar there was one girl waiting at the door. She had three friends inside sitting 10 feet away yet the doorman could not let her in. She had been waiting for 20 minutes when we got there and she waited for another 20. The bar inside was far from packed, it was actually very sparse inside. While we were waiting at least 20 people walked out yet they still didn't let anyone in.  We were told that the owners were around and they would prefer it not to be crowded.  After waiting for 45minutes, the girl waved good-bye to her friends and left. They were still saving a chair for her... 

Message to the management and owners - this isn't Las Vegas and you're running a bar, not a nightclub.  Manufacturing a line outside so you can feel good about yourself is a total joke. 

The bar inside was pretty unimpressive and there is a long list of bars with a cool vibe that can make a good drink.  Lots of people stopped by while we were waiting and quickly moved on.  We only waited because our friend was on the way.  You can be sure those visitors will never be back. 

However, if you feel like standing in line with a bunch of bearded, cigarette smoking hipsters... THEN THIS IS YOUR PLACE!
author: Honest A.

description:
Really excited to have Trick Dog as a local neighborhood bar. Awesome creative craft drinks and also a delicious food menu to accompany it. Their drink menu is on a dog calendar, how cute is that??

Their "manimal" fries are to die for. Not twice, but THRICE cooked fries (boiled, fried 2x) have this amazing extra crispy yet tender potato to ever touch your lips. Topped with cheese, house dressing, and green onions.

This place was packed on a Thursday night. Can be quite loud and overbearing. If you end up staying for dinner, the upstairs is surprisingly sound buffered, so you can have an actual conversation without have to strain your vocal cords.
author: Minh N.

description: Trick dog is the ideal place to get a delicious, exciting drink in a very comfortable, social atmosphere. One of the main draws are their menus, which all have very different concepts, and have ranged from chinese takeout menus, to zodiac calendars, to drinks inspired by san francisco's street art. Changing twice a year, these menus keep things fresh, and allow the staff to continuously innovate.
author: Holden B.

description: Just came in for a drink, but loved every second! Beat the post-work crowd so was able to get a seat by the bar before it got too busy. Bartenders were very attentive, answering all our questions about the drinks and giving recommendations. Creativity is through the roof with their drink menu! We got 54-40 or fight, I am not a crook, and I like Ike. All super tasty! Cant wait to see what they do with their cocktails next - bartender said they update it every 6 months.
author: Erica D.

description:
Trick Dog was crowded and full of dudes on a Wednesday night. Why?? 

Music was kind of loud if you're trying to have an actual conversation with someone, but aside from that, I have nothing bad to say. I tried four different cocktails from its spinny astrological drink menu thing and all were really strong, but so so good.

See: http://sf.eater.com/archives/2014/01/09/trick_dog_debuts_new_astrological_cocktail_menu.php

Highly recommend the Aries and Scorpio!

Probably the best cocktails I have had in San Francisco so far since living here!! Kind of a big deal. If only I lived closer...
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Just a wholesome bar.  I live in san jose and make trips up to the city as often as i can and this has been one of my favorite spots to revisit.  I am yet to have an experience short of stellar. 

The bar staff - friendly and professional.  Extremely helpful, and you can tell they enjoy being there (which is a great job by management & ownership).  Often I find that San Francisco bars struggle with hospitality skills.  The great city is a titan for the cocktail scene, and very much so deserving.  However all too often I get served by far from humble individuals.  But the folks behind the stick at trick dog give off no pretentious vibes.  

The beverage program is a work of art.  And not only what goes into the glass.  The menus are innovating & unique.  Last round I experienced was a Dog Calendar, where all drink options were attached to a different month.  The current menu looks like a confidential packet from a criminal investigation.  The contents of the libations too are innovative.  These guys are pushing boundaries with delicious execution.  Rarely do I go to a bar where I am excited to drink the entire menu. 

The decor and environment was well drawn out as well.  One of my favorite parts about the space is the back bar.  The bottle shelves are like no other shelves you've seen. I don't even know how to describe the style, you just need to see for yourself. 

Having cocktailed all around the bay area, NoLa, Portland, Souther California, this is one of the best bars I've walked into.  Keep up the good work you dawgs.
author: Tombo C.

description: One of my favorite cocktail bars I visited while in San Fran! A little off the beaten path, but that makes it just more accessible! The cocktails, the whiskey list, and some of the quick bites were outstanding! I had read great reviews about this place and they didn't disappoint! Looking for my next trip to San Fran so I can hit it up again!
author: Sam V.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend to try the burger. We read on a blog that is was one of the best burgers in SF. The restaurant is on the second level. The bottom floor is the bar.  The waitress was pretty sassy to be quite honest. We had to ask the other waiter to flag her down a few times. It didn't really bother me though.
The burger looked interesting. It's on a wide hot dog bun with a long burger in it. It reminded me of a backyard burger at a BBQ, but twenty times better. They have a different kind of sauce that is amazing on the burger. We also go manimal fries. They're kind of like a fancy, less intense animal styler fries from In-N-Out. They were pretty good but not as good as In-N-Out. 
We also got drinks with out meals. I can't for the life of me remember what they were called but man were they strong and delicious!
author: Nicole C.

description:
It's kind of a whole in the wall bar. My friends and I totally wouldve missed it if the security guy in front of the door didn't catch us. It's really small and holds about 50 people. Bathrooms are spacious. Its very HIPSTER. I like it a lot. They have a unique cocktail menu to order from. The drinks are pretty strong for my tastes. It's a fun place to just grab a couple drinks with friends and although it's small it wasn't over crowded. They also have these cool postcards that they'll send out for you if you out it in their mail box! No postage necessary! 

Drinks tried: $12.00 each
Mission Dolores (tastiest)
Coit Tower (strong, slight carbonation)
... gold Fire Hydrant (strong)

They have other drinks. Shots are pretty cheap. Their menu is basically a map of San Francisco. Very cool theme and atmosphere. Give it a try at least once. You have to find street parking! The people here are really nice!
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Well well what can I say . I work in the business . Just came from work . Identified myself as a fellow in arms  . Tired read my book . Went to the restroom . Did all the necessary things . A coaster on my beer and whiskey . Came back all cleared off the bar . The you are not welcome here was clear . I only came because one of my guests at one of the places I work was a judge on a cocktail completion that you guys won . He was from London and told me I needed to try them . Not only did you disappoint a fellow bartender who works in two places in the city I also get to tell a judge what happened . I never yelp I hate it . However manners are easy you can be bad at your job and polite . Ego seems to run this establishment . I could have been a great asset . Alas no longer . I know you don't care what I think . That was pretty obvious .   This was no tonight . 
Sorry if I offended anyone working .
author: Susan L.

description:
2nd favorite scotch egg. Must try.

Drinks to die for with constantly updated menus. 

So many people.

I just can't deal with such crowds. I literally fight to give me money to someone and get drunk off really tasty cocktails. 

So popular. So many people.

Did I say that? What else. Go check it out for some bomb-tastic drinks, but as a crowd hater, I'll avoid on popular nights. Time is money and I'm giving you me money? I'll pass on those nights. Otherwise, yum.

Cheers!
author: Joseph L.

description:
This is the most hip hipster bar in the mission, and I love it. First of all the menu is on a dog calendar. How damn cute is this?! 

The drinks are all great and creative. I can't believe I am saying this but the Kale Salad is to die for, and its massive. Its like a vegetarian cloud of goodness. It will also make you feel better about the copious amounts of booze you will down in this bar.
author: Ciara T.

description:
A hipster bar with a dog calendar as the menu and drinks named after each month? Of course I needed to come here. I have wanted to come to Trick Dog for years as it is one of the best bars in the nation, and I was very impressed. Tucked in an obscure smaller area of the Mission next to Sightglass and some other restaurants, the pink building has no sign. You hear the music, see the people, and assume that's the one. 

The casual ambience was charming and inviting with tables along one wall and stools along the bar. Trick Dog also has an upstairs dining area, but most people came for the bar. Seats are first come first serve, so you just have to be quick about grabbing a table or seats. Even though it is a free for all, people were respectful and nice; there was no shoving, pushing, shouting, or an unorganized feel. 

Now, getting to the drinks. With 12 drinks, one for each month, the selection is unique and delicious. Since I was born in May, I had to get the May drink as my first. It had blanco tequila, tempus fugit kina l'avion d'Or, sunflower seed, and sweet lime. I also enjoyed the April drink, with vodka, vermouth, Suze, green grapes, taragon, and lime. Both are sweeter drinks, and the April one even came in a special glass. Even though the menu is dog themed now, in a few months, it will be something else unique again because Trick Dog changes its menu from time to time, so that customers always stay fascinated and can taste unique drinks. I will definitely be coming back soon to try more month drinks!
author: Annie C.

description: Love this warehouse bar! It's super roomy and their menu is funny. Try the low proof cocktails or the ones with vermouth.
author: Katie P.

description:
I've been here for drinks a few times, and I've been consistently underwhelmed. Maybe my expectations were too high from the many glowing reviews, but I just don't see what other people here are raving about.

Their cocktail menu is interesting. I've tried most of their specialty drinks now, including all of the bourbon- and scotch-based ones. They've each had novel flavor combinations, and none has been bad, but none of them have been particularly good either. 

Besides the mediocre drinks, Trick Dog is also too crowded to sit, too noisy to talk, and too busy to be able to get a drink quickly. And those mediocre drinks are $12 apiece!

All in all, if I want good cocktails that are actually worth $12, I'll go to Oddjob or Single Barrel. If I want a place with good ambience, I'll go to Bourbon & Branch or even Shotwell's. And if I want a place that is both as overcrowded and as overpriced as San Francisco housing, I can go to Trick Dog.
author: Dan D.

description:
Awesome place and cool bartenders.

The 5 stars alone for the Scotch Egg!! Well worth the $10 price tag. Definitely will be back for these and these alone. BUT, the drinks are made well too, which solidifies the 5 stars.

Love the Astrological cocktails that are catered towards your zodiac sign. Virgo is right on the money.
author: Ling H.

description: Although a little hard to find (no sign outside), this place was great. I came in with 3 friends around 4pm on a Tuesday, right after they opened and we were the only ones there. I have a feeling that if we came in a little later it would have been busier because the ambiance was prime, the bartenders were very attentive, and my cocktail was delicious. I got one of the gin drinks and it was top-notch. The food also looks delicious even though we didn't eat there. I need to come back again to see what all the fuss isl about!
author: Ilana B.

description:
This is home base for the Bon Vivants... http://www.bonvivants.com/
They've won a James Beard award for being one of the five best cocktail bars in the country. http://www.pastemagazine.com/blogs/lists/2015/04/5-best-cocktail-bars-in-america-1.html
The pork mushu tacos are good, as is most of their bar food.   It gets loud in here, but there is an option to sit upstairs and nosh on bar bites and have more cocktails.
I was there for Negroni week....but the negronis were pre-mixed and made with Beefeater.  What?   The bartender was accomodating and let us sample two different types of gin before ordering more drinks.   I appreciate the professionalism...and the clear ice cubes that they cut everyday with a chainsaw.
author: Wendy W.

description:
I've been meaning to update this. I love love love love their drinks! They come up with an entirely new themed cocktail list every 6 months, and they're always the most creative drinks I've ever had!

Definitely the best bar in SF, by far!
author: Kazu O.

description:
This place is pretty cool! Each month they have a themed selection of cocktails. One month it was the zodiac, and another it was neighborhoods of SF. All very different, well thought, and delicious. I didn't think a place like this existed in the area! Great place to hang out! 

Its a small space and it does get crowded. Parking is difficult even here..
author: James S.

description:
Dear Trick Dog: your drinks are one of the best in SF and I used to be a fan. But your recent Chinese-themed menu is offensive rather than funny. Before you excuse me as a humorless person, I do appreciate the level of detail you put in (the kitschy Chinese menu design, the Chinese-named drinks, etc.). And yes, your drinks taste good. But why do they come in a mug shaped like a face with a Fu Manchu mustache on it? Racial caricatures aren't funny in any form. Can you imagine what kind of lawsuits you'd get if you served with a mug shaped like a "little black sambo" or a big-nosed Jewish caricature? It's really the same thing. 

And if you bother to give every drink a Chinese name, why can't I order with the name you put on the menu? This means the Chinese drink names are there for decorative purposes only. Because you think an entire language and culture are "funny."

Please check your humor and think about where it's coming from.
author: Deanne C.

description:
This place has been in my bookmarks and finally we made it. It was surprising that there was no sign for this place. It is a nice environment to walk and hang out. I had a cocktail which was pretty good and my husband had a beer. It is more like a cocktail place. They do not have tap beers.
Generally, the foods was good! Great place for cocktails!
author: Sujung S.

description: They have a really cool, hands-on menu, which is very large and you feel like a little kid reading a book that is too big for your tiny hands. The menu has a top-secret theme and is written like a recipe and there are certain ingredients that are crossed out with black sharpie for the secrecy aspect. I enjoyed the drink Biggie and Tupac. They also have a good selection of beers, and I enjoyed the Ballast Point beer after my cocktails. If you're there early you can get a seat at the bar but it fills up quickly as it gets later. We tried the Manimal fries, which are triple-fried and have a mayo-based pink sauce. I've heard the kale salad is also excellent.
author: Sara M.

description: A party of 8 we were asked to leave this bar because we were standing too close to the bar even though we had been stood in the exact same position for over an hour as they happily sold us $14 drinks. Sad experience and won't be back.
author: David N.

description:
Trick Dog opened up in SF well after I left the city for the east coast, so upon my return to the Bay Area, I made it a high priority to check it out. After so many years of following the Bon Vivant guys, I'm stoked they have a brick and mortar to call their own... and they seem to be rippin' and tearin' their way into SF cocktail bar glory.

Their converted warehouse is the perfect setting for a well curated libation, and the fact that they're open at 3:00pm on weekdays means Summer Fridays have a new best friend. 

I didn't have a chance to try their food (someday) as I was there to tap into the drink menu, and it certainly lived up to expectations. Dozens of creative elixirs dotted the menu (that's comprised of 45s - brilliant!) with seasonal ingredients being the biggest takeaway. All sorts of stone fruit and seasonal melon beverages made it hard to select just one... but really, you could just throw a dart at a page and chances are you'll be happy. 

The service was slightly aloof, but I suppose it was early in the day and dude behind the bar was just cracking his knuckles for the afternoon. Probably the only bummer part of my quick jaunt. Not disenchanting enough to keep me away for future visits, though.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
Best cocktail bar in SF I've seen. Great drinks. Great vibe. Usually crowded and high noise. But still very much worth it.

Semi-expensive and old school music.
author: Jesper B.

description:
Love this place! Phenomenal drinks, and great food to go along with them. 

Highly recommend going upstairs, snagging a table and eating a full dinner here. It seems that most people just go for the bar on the first floor, but they're missing out on so many great food possibilities. 

For food, highly recommend:
- the kale salad (enormous, with slow-cooked egg yolk dressing, avocados, and parmesan; sooo tasty!!! a great starter if you're hungry)
- the thrice-cooked fries - get this Manimal style!!! So good!
- the duck egg (they've replaced the scotch egg with this; rich and delish)
- the trick dog

As for drinks, we loved:
- the Mission Dolores (rum-based)
- the Alcatraz (a bourbon cocktail)

Service is a bit slow though - so don't come here if you're in a rush, or a big group - the tables are all for 2-4 people; and the upstairs where they serve sit-down meals is quite small.
author: Amelia C.

description: Had heard so much about this place - the best thing was the menu though, literally. Not the stuff on the menu, but the way the menu has been designed. The bartenders are awesome and have a lot of energy, but the crampedness of the place along with the decidedly average cocktails, I thought it wasn't worth the hype. Still, got to go to verify.
author: Aashrey K.

description: I lost a brand new pack of ferry tickets and I'm not even upset about it. Adorable little hipster bar, very simple, contemporary with open duct, not over-designed. It's like the self-aware people from Portlandia opened a bar to NOT be ironic, but just be fun, unpretentious, and tasty.... all the while having the silly and over the top drink menus with way too many weird drinks, that take a bit longer than normal to make, etc. But the theme is fun if you know what you are getting into, and the barkeeps are absolutely friendly and not Portlandia. Sorry to be uninspired with the references, but I find too many people teetering on the self-aware and out-to-lunch "we're doing this like that show" vibe. These guys know what they are doing, they walk the line, and they pull it off marvelously. =) Cheers.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
I know people will say I'm too PC but this "Chinese" menu rubs me the wrong way. I don't think management put much thought into this one. The owners seem to think Chinese language is funny and that Fu Manchu cups are quaint. 

Someone else just pointed this out here but would it be as funny if it were another ethnicity?   

Not giving one star because the drinks are still good.
author: Victoria W.

description:
I guess I had my hopes unrealistically high for the cocktails here, because I wasn't blown away. I probably also picked one that did not seem too challenging, and, it wasn't - The Lombard on The Tourist menu. It had a nice hint of smokiness but otherwise, wasn't too interesting.

However, I thought the rest of the menu, which doesn't all seem to be online, was really nice - high balls, boilermakers, low proof drinks, and some really interesting looking non-alcoholic options - not at all what I had expected! I would definitely be interested in branching out to some of those areas, which are also notably less than the $12 cocktails. Although that did include a free stamp, which I used on a complimentary postcard.
author: Lisa K.

description: This is a cute little bar in the Mission tucked away in a neighborhood. They change their drinks on a monthly basis based of their personalized dog calender. For dinner they have a separate upstairs seating which is very intimate for a date night. I recommend getting the beef tartar and their Manimal style fries which contains their house sauce, cheddar cheese, and charred scallions. I'm getting hungry just thinking about them. Based on popular reviews, we had also ordered their kale salad which I was very sorely disappointed in. Since it was such a large portion, after a few bites, I was already sick of eating it. It is purely just kale, shredded Parmesan cheese and pumpkin seeds.
author: Karen C.

description:
Great place to hang out and grab some creative drinks and food!

Business was hopping in the bar area on the Saturday night when I visited.  I didn't get there until after 11, but the lines were long and the drinks were long in coming.  At least they were also delicious, and worth the wait!

After hiking all day, I was pleasantly surprised that the kitchen was still serving, so we headed upstairs to grab a table and some food.  The menu is currently going through a revamping since the chef is new, but even thought the choices were limited, they had great flavor.  The price was a bit high per serving size, but it was still a high quality menu, both for food and drinks.

I definitely look forward to going back when the menu has returned to a normal size to see what else the chef can come up with.
author: Jes G.

description:
Trick Dog was pretty confusing. First off, it was kind of off-putting that my friend had to get his ID out twice, because the guy in front forgot that he already looked it.

Going in, the place was a madhouse, probably because it was prime time happy hour. Had to fight to get to the bar, and decided that we were going to stay in. After waiting for 10 minutes for a table, and looking at the menu, we found it that it wasn't too appealing and decided to head back down at the bar, just so we can get a drink and leave. (Though, the food looked pretty good..)

I ended up getting Hunter's Moon, which was on their lighter menu, and let me just say, the bartender did not skip on the "light" part, because there was plenty of alcohol in there. My friends got the Aries and the Pisces, both were really tasty and refreshing.

Would come back for the drinks, maybe not when I have to fight for it.
author: Tom T.

description: Great cocktails! They change their menu a couple times of a year and I had the opportunity to go while it was the Chinese takeout menu which was awesome. I tried the #4 which had coconut-infused Atlantico Platino rum, Luxardo apricot, green tea, harissa, and lime. I loved all of the flavors, and I'm happy I took the bartenders recommendation for this one instead of going with #5 which was my first choice. The #12 was good as well - especially with the housemade marshmellow. Bartenders know their stuff here.
author: Teresa C.

description:
I am so sad to be giving trick dog a 1 star review. =/

I've been to the bar several times and eaten upstairs twice. I always recommended them as a great place for cocktails and socializing. I even had a great experience hanging out and chatting with the bar tenders on several occasions. 

So why the ONE star review? 

Well, I met up with a few friends last week and we sat by the bar and were figuring out the order, it was a busy Tuesday night a little loud and crowded, but nothing out of the ordinary.  Anyway, a few people gave their orders to the bartender (who's name was JIM i believe), and a couple other were still deciding and decided not to order right then. So Jim made the drinks and handed them to the group. Everyone who ordered grabbed their drinks and there was one left - we asked around to see who's it was and no one had ordered it. So we told Jim. Jim then proceeded to throw a FIT, that would make a pmsing 18 year old look girl look like a pleasure.  

Keep in mind this was a Tuesday, no one was hammered or even close to drunk, this was our 1st drink of the evening. To avoid argument and conflict after a bit of back and forth, one of the guys in the group stepped up and bought the drink, also mentioned that  we'd probably end up buying more round anyway - so no big deal! Even though in my experience, if a mistake has been made, bar tenders generally tend to offer to take the drink back. 

The group finished their drinks and the guy who bought the extra cocktail, decides to order another round for everyone. Here is when it gets really funny... Jim tells him that he will allow him to buy a drink but if he purchases any other drinks and gives them to anyone else in the group he will kick him and the rest of the group out of the bar. 

The group tried to talk to jim the bartender, even to jims coworker, but there was no reasoning with jim and the coworker stood by his colleague which is to be expected. After some insults and back and forth, and very unnecessary childish drama for a Tuesday night it's needless to say we decided to cut our night short and leave. 

Once we walked out - we heard tht the bouncer was told not to let the group back in. I have never been so insulted in my life. No one in the group did anything to deserve that treatment. It was over the top, blown insanely out of proportion and just bizarre erratic behavior by the Trick Dog staff member.

I will NOT be going back - and will definitely not be recommending trick dog to any friends from here forward. it's truly a shame - BC it is nice spot and i'm sure the owners and other people involved with the bar are just fine. 

Jim need to check his attitude and his insecurities at the door... no, at the city line. SF has no more room for that!
author: Shadi N.

description:
How do you rate a bar if they won't let you in?

Apparently, an interim driver license in conjunction with my 2 day expired driver license is not enough to prove that I am who I say I am. Though I gained back my legal right to drive, my California residency remains expired, my birthdate remains expired, and the image of my face remains expired. Did I get that right, Trick Dog legal team? It felt like a TSA shakedown at SFO. But good for you guys for doing it by the book.

Oh and thanks for telling my party that the guy whose birthday they came to celebrate cannot come in for his first visit.

TL;DR - Bring your license, your passport, your employee ID, a blood sample, a urine sample, and a genetic screen to get past the bearded security guard.
author: Justin D.

description: Loud, little seating downstairs. We just had dinner upstairs and enjoyed it, but the sound from downstairs does really echo. The food was good - manimal style fries and the trick dog, a burger hot dog hybrid - and the drinks were great. Worth going to at least once every six months for the new theme.
author: Mauna D.

description:
Overall good. Went 11:30pm-2am for drinks only. 

Atmosphere: Chill. Food smelled good. Late 20s crowd.  

Drinks: Cocktails delicious crafts. The October was ok. The July, April, June, all were super good. 

Staff: bar tenders, awesome! Door guy, typical tool bag. Rushed us to finish drink 20 minutes to closing, made us wait outside for uber 5 minutes to closing while other people still inside (friends of the bartenders - we get it- but seriously? 5 minutes? Not like we're wasted here dude.)
author: Christina B.

description:
Wow -- what a fun find this place was.  Nestled in the Mission, right near Central Kitchen, this cocktail-centered place was packed before 6 pm on a Friday night.  Luckily, my partner had arrived a little early to snag some seats, which were being eyed lustily for the other patrons when I finally arrived.  Ordered the #9 cocktail, which was an infusion of bourbon, kumquat liqueur and some other equally unlikely ingredients.... which managed to send this jaded lush into fits of gushy praise.

Ordered some food also -- the menu is an ironic take on your dime-a-dozen greasy Chinese Restaurant... but so much better than that.  Ordered the Mu-shu Pork Tacos, and burnt my mouth snarfing them down.

May just be one of my new favorite out-of-the-Castro Happy Hour haunts.  Come here -- you will not be disappointed.  And come thirsty -- truly inventive and interesting cocktails.
author: James P.

description: I need to come back to eat here but the drinks are great (pantone swatch) but great quality and very unique. I would definitely come back here and it was small but very chill.
author: Lily P.

description:
Been here a couple of times, but my latest trip on Saturday for day drinking was pretty good.  We got there early around 4 so it was pretty empty, which allowed us to pretty much take it over for a friends b-day.

First, it was day drinking and it was a hot day, so I allowed myself to drink "girly" drinks cause, well, they are refreshing!  The drinks menu is in the form of small vinyl records book.  Each record represents a different drink!  The used to have a book of paint samples as the menu.  Very Hipster indeed.  Drinks were good.  They have a fully stocked bar for off menu ordering.  They also have a non-alcoholic section!  

However, this day was anything but hipster for Trick Dog as we took it over.  The staff was really nice and helpful and the bartenders were friendly and attentive as well.  We also ordered food and buy was this the best part.  The Scotch Egg was amazing, with an outside layer that was done so well, it tasted like crab cakes.  The Trick Dog itself was actually a burger and not a hot dog, tasty!  The cracklings, well how can you go wrong with crackling!  YUM!  

We were there for a good 3 hours + and had a very good time!  It started to get a little hot stuffy as it began to fill up, be prepared.
author: Veasna H.

description:
Why Hello Trick Dog! ?

New bar in the Mission District serving CLEVERLY Crafted and NAMED drinks! Best of all they are delicious! There is a downstairs and upstairs level. The upstairs level is reserved for people who are dining at the bar. 

DRINKS:
Baby Turtle- EGG WHITES + Cinnamon  + TEQUILA! WOO. Frothy start to the night. (This was available the first time I was here when they had a Pantone menu)

Bank Robber - RYE, Bourbon, Congac, bitters, and blackberry. Amazing combination to give a well balanced by strong flavored drink. (The menu is a vintage disc set)

FOOD: 
Beef Tartare: Sous-vide rare sirloin, egg yolk, cornichons, mustard and fines herbs, served with toas. The egg yolk mixes well with the beef. 

Cracklins: Pork belly cooked crispy, with brown sugar, salt & spice- These are great chips to go with the bar drinks!!

Overall, one of the coolest bars in the Mission! Coming back again for sure.
author: Stephen C.

description:
On a lazy Saturday afternoon my sis and I rolled into Trick Dog soon after they opened at 3:00pm. We stayed for a good 3 hours and had 5 drinks. One thing you must know about my sister and I is that we are picky eaters, and perhaps even pickier drinkers. The mere fact that we were interested enough to try half the cocktail menu  at Trick Dog warrants 5 stars off the bat.

What Trick Dog has going for it is their candidly bizarre drinks. There are combinations I've never heard or thought of before. A carrot drink? A chocolate-covered olive? How about a homemade marshmallow in your scotch? For foodies like us it was like being a kid in a candy store: too many interesting things to try and not enough space for all of it (or perhaps more realistically, not enough alcohol tolerance...).

That's not to say I absolutely adored every drink I had. Lighter, citrus-y drinks are not my favorite so I found that I didn't particularly enjoy the #4 (notable for coconut infused rum, harissa, and green tea) or #9 (tequila and carrot (!!) drink with absinthe). Despite my personal preferences, I still appreciated the drinks for their unique flavors, like the intriguing savory quality of the harissa, and that bizarre carrot-y sweetness in that carrot drink! The #12 (nice touch of smokiness from the scotch and that boozy marshmallow was great) and #9 (intense walnut flavor was fantastic) were really solid, tasty drinks that I would easily order again. But perhaps the best part was that when we asked about a drink on the previous Zodiac menu, the bartenders were accommodating enough to look up the previous drink and mix us up a something that fit to the best of their ability (the drink was fantastic, btw). They did not have to do that; it was awesome service on their end.

I also want to tip my hat to the concept of Trick Dog. A rotating menu and theme every 6 months is a brilliant way to keep things new and interesting for customers (next time I'm in the Bay Area I know I'll want to come back!). That's what I love so much about the crazy concoctions at Trick Dog - I saw combinations I never imagined; I tasted flavors I'd never tasted before. It's places like this that keep my inner foodie going.
author: Clarice W.

description:
I love love love trick dog
I don't love much
I love trick dog
It is a great bar - except it is not cheap
It is otherwise great
You should go here if you are anywhere near
author: David G.

description: The bartenders are stellar and Kenny the door guy is friendly as fuck. Great overall experience in a busy space.
author: Pico S.

description: Love the cocktails here... Its been a few years since I last had a drink here. I just found out that they rotate their menus twice a year. Love the different themes.
author: John Z.

description: Review is for drinks only.  Decent atmosphere with a mix of hipsters, poseurs, and "normal" people (whatever that means these days).  The whole calendar as menu thing is pretty ridiculous and a pain in the ass to have to open up, but the cocktails are interesting (albeit they were all a bit too sweet for me) and the bar staff worked quickly.  I'd come back here if someone suggested it but would never choose to come here for myself.
author: Chris C.

description:
Order the Chicken Nuggets - OMG, so good!  Panko crusted (oh so crispy) with tender micro thin layers of minced chicken with the best sauces ever.  This is a must.

Cocktails were heavenly, however the female bartender today was the opposite of friendly, bordering on offensive.  Still, we'd go back for the creative cocktails and to try other dishes on their menu.  Highly recommend the I'm Not A Crook Cocktail - such a refreshing treat.  Drinks are about $13 and very, very small, mostly ice, but each sip is exceptional.
author: Chris H.

description:
(See pics) Review #1335. This is more like someone's loft with Start-up looking crowds who wear fashion sneakers and checker shirts than business shirts with leather shoes. It portrays a casual, fun, very friendly and Mission atmosphere.

The bartenders here know how to make a solid drink. Not a big fan of fizzy drink but theirs were a good starter. Their stronger drinks definitely are way more solid and delicious. The 2 of us had 7 drinks out of the fun paint book so that shows how much we liked them (from smooth to fizzy):

Alligator Alley
Vintage Photo
Lion Heart
Paper Moon
Straw Hat
Baby Turtle
Pantone 7621

We came here on a Tuesday and it was quite busy. Drinks did take about 10 to 15 minutes to arrive early on around 8pm (most drinks do take time to create and the place was more than 75% packed) but got better after 9ish.

The great thing about this place is that you can enjoy a fantastic drink in the well lacquered but keeps rustic feel in the dim light (most standing room except by the bar with seats if you want to eat downstairs.) It's not too loud (not sure about the weekend since it's not that big of a place. Think of a smaller loft.)

Perfect timing as we got hungry after a drink and went upstairs where there's table service with menu. 

In between the beams, here comes the light.

There were about 9 to 10 tables and most seat for 2 with a few that fit 4. There's good space between the tables and it actually feels more like a bistro. You left the lively crowd and great background music, and stepped into coziness. The seats were plush comfortable!

Food was decent and the dishes were lounge dish size. We had 6 dishes:

* Raw radish with dehydrated Campari butter dip and house-smoked Moldon sea salt - the trick was the butter.

* Cracklins (pork belly) - the fatty part was good but meat was too dense for my taste

* Beer nuts - turned out I really love beer nuts!

* Scotch egg - smart and artsy looking and was a soft-boiled egg wrapped in brandade served with shaved beet with a side of salmon roe and creme fraiche. The egg was very good but they can totally skip the beets that was too overwhelming. Everything else looked more like garnish than a side.

* TrickDog - the trick was the sirloin, chuck and brisket, and that aioli with stronger mustard and really good pickles. This felt right home in the Mission style - greased up and absorbing all the alcohol that made you so hungry in the previous 2 hours.

* Brussels sprouts were not the totally crispy style but softer. This actually was my preferred style.

Trick Dog is right next to Central Kitchen and they even share the bathroom. No sign and you will literally pass right by and thought it was part of Central Kitchen. Do like the fact that it's not on Valencia side and it gives this place a more neighborhood feel.
author: T L.

description:
Went to Trick Dog for the first time last night. Generally speaking the food was good, the cocktails were well made, and the service was acceptable. A few of the servers were unfriendly and unwilling to give recommendations.

The plates are small for the price. If you are going for dinner, expect to pay $45-60 per person to fill full. They serve "tapas style bar food" and suggest 2-3 plates per person at $15 a pop. I had three and still left feeling hungry. Also, there is no dessert menu, and we were not offered an alternative (sweet wine, coffee, cocktail etc).

The noise level is definitely loud and it is hard to maintain a conversation with more than one person in the bar area. The upstairs dining room is a tad better.

Overall I would come back for the drinks, but I will not be a regular.

Edit: Kenny the bouncer was amazing.
author: Jillian S.

description:
Love this place for craft cocktails!  The cocktails are tasty and the mixologists are super friendly and helpful if you're indecisive about your order.  I've had the She's Gone and Heat Wave, both good.  She's Gone is served in a tall glass with a generous slice of cucumber and Heat Wave is served in a champagne glass, both are fruity and refreshing.  

Look for the door with hexagon window, there's no sign for Trick Dog.  This is my new go to place for drinks!
author: Wendy S.

description:
Fun spot to try once.  

Drinks are affordable and tasty! 

Food was good, nothing spectacular, but good! I liked the trick dog, of course. 

Be prepared for the loud atmosphere.  Bar is very crowded on weekends.
author: Suzanna F.

description:
It's a little loud for me, but if you want a place you can go and just socialize with strangers and not feel like a social outcast,  or somewhere trendy to go with your little "crew".  Trick Dog would be it.

The food upstairs is quite good, although the menu is limited.  Make sure you order the Kale Salad with extra cheese (be prepared, it's quite chewy...and you're gonna have to work to enjoy it).  The scotch eggs are worth it.  Seems pricey ($10 bucks for two eggs) but yum yum yum.

Parking can be a little bit of a b*tch but just trust in your parking karma and it will work out.
author: Edward M.

description: Really nice vibe. Came here pretty late in the night and the food menu was still available. Bartenders are super attentive. Cocktails were great as well. Probably my favorite bar in San Francisco so far.
author: Susan T.

description:
Not impressed, but want to be fair. The mezzanine was closed, review only on drinks.

Dined once at the restaurant across the street. Saw the crowd outside Trick Dog. Came by one night after midnight. No wait. But staff seemed overworked. Don't want to judge the service.

The menu (classified document folder) could become a collector's item. But took us a little while to read through. Ordered a rye-based drink. Decent, even unassuming for a drink that was given the name of a secret society (according to conspiracy theories). The drink must have been handcrafted, but before we placed the order. 

Ordered a second drink. Then we got distracted and didn't see how that drink was mixed either. We like Japanese Whisky Highballs. Ramen Shop in Oakland makes one that is simple and elegant. The Trick Dog version was busy and icy. The barley water, with the help of that ginger reishi mushroom syrup, just killed the whisky - not a conspiracy. It might go well with the food on their menu, though.
author: D.V. A.

description:
Very good drinks. The horoscope drinks are creative, the other drinks are solid, too. I asked for something whiskey based with citrus and the outcome was perfect. Layers of tastes and good citrusy punch.

The dishes are also quite good. We got the scotch eggs, rice crisp and fries.

The scotch eggs are solid with runny yold inside. A bit pricey, but worth trying.

Rice cake was very Asian (Korean) so it wasn't a big surprise but still the use of white kimchi balances flavor out quite well.

Recommended!
author: Lance C.

description:
Call me a sucker, but I love the creative drink menus here. Last time I visited trick dog, the drink menu was on a record and this time around it was on a horoscope. Totes cute! 

The drinks are hand crafted and remind me of bourbon and branch (drinks that takes a while but totally worth it). It can get pretty crowded in there as well. I've never had the food but it looks bomb. 

I had a bad experience this past weekend with one of the guests. He dropped drinks all over our groups' jackets. Having said that, you're going to find drunk a*holes at every bar.
author: Grace Y.

description:
Trick Dog was recommended by a waitress of another restaurant the night prior so we decided to do an impromptu cocktail tour of San Francisco based on some recommendations throughout the week of our vacation. 

I say go. It was a great experience despite a bit of sass from our rugged waiter. The cocktails were interesting, perfectly mixed and diverse in flavor range.  I enjoyed the nods to various locations throughout the city. 

The food was really good as well. Thrice cooked fries are rockstar, note: you're a fool if you don't get them mani mail style. Out of this world. The Trick Dog was exactly how it sounds, cool as fuck. A perfect burger in a hot dog, it's brilliant. Kale salad was monstrous, recommended.
