Wait Staff: Very friendly hostess(?) from Brooklyn, was a great offset to our waiter who tried to blatantly rush us along our meal (to no avail). Not appreciated, especially when ordering a lot and on vacation. 

Check this place out, it's a must hit on your culinary trek through Mission District.
author: Sal D.

description:
We loved the place back when it had 45s as the menu.
I really don't care for the new menu.  They have all of this Chinese names for drinks with Chinese pronunciations.  This would make sense if there was anything Chinese about them.  There isn't.  
The drinks were ok.
author: Peter O.

description: Been a favorite for a long time. Even with all of the choices in the neighborhood I just cannot stop coming back! Maybe it's the awesome possum staff. Or maybe it's the consistently changing and kitchsy menu style. I'm not embarrassed to say I've swiped one before but most recently paid for the last one! Delicious kale salad and the brisket dog is out of this world. Plus the drinks. How could I forget the drinks?! The libations are unbelievably good and always inventive. 5 stars all the way!
author: S S.

description: Perfectly crafted cocktails, fetching and attentive bartenders, buzzy (but never obnoxious) crowd, airy industrial atmosphere at the same time that it is intimate, a stumbling-and-a-power-walk-through-the-pissoir-that-is-the-mission distance to home.
author: Paul M.

description:
Get a table to avoid the line. The don't let anyone in until someone leaves, so the wait is variable!  But you can ask to be seated upstairs for some food and drinks. My boyfriend and I had already eaten dinner, so all we wanted was dessert - which was a-okay with them!

Drinks - so awesome. They give you a deck of cardstock that resembles different shades of paint. But instead of different shades of paint, each card has a different drink description! 

We ordered:
-Grandma's Sweater - DELICIOUS. It had Gin, Lime, Mint and Bitter Lemon....there was so much mint in it that you could barely taste the alcohol. So wonderful.
-Straw Hat - skip. Tasted so bland compared to Grandma's sweater. Boring drink.
-Ice cream special of the day, which happened to be POPCORN flavored. This was a real treat!!!  We were pleasantly surprised. This seemed like ice cream from Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous or Humphrey Slocombe. The ice cream also tasted fresh, not frozen for a couple days!!!

Can't wait to return!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: The menu is and always has been absolute fire. I'm appreciative of the friendliness and patience of the staff.
author: Katie S.

description: God, well, you know it's pricey. This is where you savor your cocktail, which take 10-15 minutes to order and another 10-15 to make. It's definitely a finely crafted item though. It's just that it will set you back around $12-13 each time. Is the Lunar New Year inspired theme a little racist? Sure. This place doesn't exactly exude an Asian vibe, and the majority of its patrons are white hipsters and yuppies, but I'm not that PC, so I don't care as much. What I do care about are the manimal fries. Holy mother of...they are bomb. Thrice cooked, so they're crunchy as hell, but the house sauce has just the right amount of spice and scallions. I'd come just for that, but a $5 pint of Konig pilsner isn't bad either. You should come just to try one or two of the drinks they're offering because they are really good, but in order to maximize drunkenness levels and stretch your dollar, hit up a dive bar elsewhere in the Mission afterwards.
author: Danny C.

description:
This place was more awesome than I expected it to be. I went to Trick Dog with 5 friends on the second day that it was open, and as imagined, it wasn't a slow night. It was packed, but I'm guessing if you give it a few weeks, it'll die down on the weekdays since it's a little off the beaten path (Valencia). I'd been hitting up the Hideout behind Dalva for craft cocktails, but am really glad that Trick Dog is another available option, as it lives up to the hype, and bonus points, is much closer to my apartment. The location is great. A major ease of going to Trick Dog as opposed to the Hideout will be not having to wonder if my bike will still be there when I leave.

One might think that their Pantone-themed drinks, and even further, menus could be compensating for weak service or cocktails, but that wasn't the case for us. All six of us got a different drink, and they were all AMAZING. Service was backed up for the night, but it was the second night they were open, so you gotta give 'em a break. 

I ordered the Pantone 7621, which contains a few of my fave ingredients: beet, ginger, and lemon, combined with Kummel, Combier, and Four Roses Bourbon. Yummy in my tummy! My second favorite of the night was the Vintage Photo, but the Baby Turtle: Tequila Ocho resposado, Campari (YES), grapefruit, cinnamon, lime, and egg white served on the rocks took the cake. Whomever came up with the recipe for the Baby Turtle, you are a bartending superhero.

This place is going to be one of my new haunts. Cocktails at Trick Dog followed by pool at Shotwells = recipe for success. The tall man in the white shirt who works there and gave us a table to sit all six of us upstairs that night rules. Let's be friends. I'll be back tonight!
author: Julianne M.

description:
Went on a Friday evening and the place was packed. Occasionally can actually hear the tunes that are playing above the roar of the crowd. Difficult to converse but had a great time. Fun crowd. I have no clue how the bartenders can keep track of drink orders, mix the drinks, have them delivered to you in the crowd and, deal with the tab.
Really enjoyed the Louie Louie and my wife loved her Bad Girl.
author: Joe M.

description:
Great place to go on a date (head upstairs) or catch up with a few friends (space is narrow).  It can get packed on the weekends and take forever to get a drink since most people come in for the craft cocktails. 

Drinks are very tasty here and extremely creative. When they first opened they had the pantone menu now they use an album with records to display their drink options. 

Shared the beef tartare and it was good but not exceptional. 

Current fav drinks:  "Mr. Big Stuff"  (see pineapple drink pic) and "Eye of the Tiger". The Eye of the Tiger was mouthwatering, tangy, and refreshing.  Mixing the condiment honey mustard, apple juice, lime, and mezcal (among other ingredients) was delicious! Who'd have thunk it?
author: Meaza S.

description:
"If you just want guac, you better go back downstairs". Thanks upstairs troll!

Justin Beibers Roast had better jokes.
author: Daniel F.

description: Late night cheat meal after the gym lead us to this place. I know I know... Wrong time but definitely not the wrong place. Simple menu with comfort food that will make you feel comfortable. Get the trick dog, I guess they call it a trick dog because it's not really a hot dog. It's better! Succulent ground beef hot dog style. Just wished the waitress had asked how I would like it done. Good food, great drinks, awesome environment. One small critique I have is that the Service was good but not great.
author: Farhad H.

description: Don't come here if you want a good value on drinks. $14 for less than half a glass of Pinot. Wallet rape.
author: Matthew S.

description:
This place never fails to WOW me.

I can say that I am now a devoted regular of Trick Dog. Whenever we have guests visiting from out of town, this is the first place we take them too. Their menus are constantly changing, their drinks are amazingly on point, and the food legit.

Even when we don't have visitors to entertain, this is our #1 go to spot. We've tried every single menu they've ever created!

- Pantone color wheel
- Record albums
- Astrological signs
- SF landmarks

Can't wait to try their newest menu that just launched!!

TIP: drink menu changes every 6 months, so be on the look out!
author: Kristen C.

description: It was the eve of my best friend's cousin's 21st birthday... we got to Trick Dog at 11pm and the bouncer didn't let her in!! What a freaking buzz-kill, my friend was turning 21 in seriously an hour! We left and went to another bar for some drinks and came back (at the birthday girl's request) to Trick Dog after midnight. The drinks were A-Okay, it was a nice plus that the kitchen was open until midnight. Otherwise, it was packed, hot, and nothing too special inside.
author: Elaine N.

description:
By the name, you'd think this is a hipster hotdog joint but it's not. Arrived here on a Saturday around 7. A good 30 min wait for a table but decent standing room downstairs (a plus for the hooks under the table top to hang your coats and purse, us bag ladies truly appreciate you *cue Erykah Badu music*).

A nod for the Pantone inspired drink menu, HELLA artsy fartsy. First glance I was confused at what I was reading.... Words next to the familiar "rum/brandy/bitters" had no meaning to me. So I ordered based on pantone color and drink name... It was a yellow-orange tone by the name of Lion Heart (familiar words like mango was on the list, totally in the mood for something fruity). Overall, it was pretty good. Cute little wine glass (I'm not a glass connoisseur obviously) with a strawberry varnish. I ordered 2, not drunk but I was definitely talking more.

As for the food... Ordered the rice plate (pork, with fried sticky rice, mushrooms with fish sauce). It was good, wish the rice cake was bigger because after it was gone, the dish was too salty for my liking. Also ordered brussel sprouts, very good as a side to another item, but not as a standalone dish... then this is where the Asian side of me hurt a bit... I didn' finish my food, figured I'd take the rest to go but the waitress took the plates and they were gone, forever... NOOOOOOOOOOOO!!! 

P.S.
good music selection and friendly staff (including the bouncer). I likes that!
author: Leilanie T.

description:
I met the Bon Vivants at a food/wine/cocktail show in SF a few years ago and I still remember the cocktail I tried.  The Radio Flyer.  Wild Turkey, dried cranberry infused Cocchi Americano, Tomahawk Bitters and a pickled cranberry garnish.    I was impressed.  With that in mind, I had high expectations for Trick Dog and they did not disappoint.   

We went to see Eddie Izzard (woo!)  at Z-Space around the corner and stopped in for a pre-show cocktail.  The line was about 6 people long at 8:30pm which wasn't too bad.  It moved quickly and the doorman was friendly ...  giving us updates on how much longer it might be and thanking us sincerely for being so patient.   Waitstaff and bartenders were equally friendly and service was quick. 

Upon entering and finding a spot to squeeze in we were acknowledged immediately and given a drink menu to peruse.  The Panettone card style menu is a little large and therefore a bit unwieldy to flip through but on the other hand it is creative and definitely convenient.   You can just pick what you want and hand it back to the bartender rather than try to shout over the din.   

We tried the Gypsy Tan and Pennies From Heaven.  Both were complex and delicious.  If we didn't have a show to attend we would have gone back for another round and tried the food but we'll have to wait until next time.  Sadly, the line was way too long (30 people or so) after the show ended (around midnight) so when we return it'll have to be early.  YMMV.  

Loved the decor and people watching.  Since the space is pretty small it gets warm inside, especially upstairs ...so be prepared.   Street parking in the area is not too bad.  Restrooms are shared with the restaurant next door but weren't crowded at all and were practically spotless.

Is the crowd pretentious or hipster?  Eh...  I dunno...    I didn't get that vibe but then I'm a little older than most of the folks who were there so I also didn't particularly care.  I'm not trying to compete with or impress anyone.  I'm just interested in good food, good drink and good atmosphere and Trick Dog delivers.    

We'll be back.  Saving a star for the food until then.
author: Shanna K.

description:
My new favorite spot! I heard of this place a few months back. Made the top 40 bars across the world list,  Bauer raved about it, and friends couldn't stop hyping the food and drinks.  So.... we went to experience the amazing-ness ourselves. 

First of the drink list is impressive.  Amazing craft cocktails that cover all areas of liquor selection. The bartenders were friendly, attentive and easy on the eyes.  Keep in mind these are craft cocktails so they take a few minutes,  but are well worth the wait.  Each sip gets better and better.  We may have ordered 70% of the specialty drinks... Don't judge.  

The food was beyond incredible.  We ordered 4 dishes: Ceviche, Fried Chicken, the "trick dog" and the kale salad. Portion size was generous, taste was phenominal: not overpowering but diverse and satisfying. With every bite you find a new flavor. There was nothing I didn't like. 

Can't wait to go back!
author: Miriam L.

description:
I was looking forward to the Pantone color-themed menu, but upon entering Trick Dog and sidling up to the bar, I was handed a 45 record album that contained 10-12 records that doubled as drink choices. Drink names by artists such as Elvis Presley, The Kingsmen and The Clash adorn each record. 

I guess Pantone has made way for records. 

The cocktails were tasty, but the real treat was venturing upstairs into the loft-like second floor dining area and wondering through the choices of small plates. Nothing cost over $12 and everything, and I mean everything, sounded appealing. That doesn't happen very often. 

The small plates are ideal for sharing and you could make a meal out of three or four of them. We were intending on being there for a pre-dinner drink, which turned into pre-dinner appetizers because everything sounded intriguing. The scotch eggs encased in brandade were an unusual twist on a pub favorite. We eyed our neighbors' choices and the thrice cooked fries, kale salad and fried green tomatoes all looked delectable. 

The takeaway? Trick Dog is a must to return to for further menu exploration.
author: Lee H.

description:
My favorite thing to do at Trick Dog is to grab a table upstairs, so I can have some delicious food as I sip on cocktails. The recommendations from the servers have always been awesome -- and the food is really good, too! Standouts from my last meal there include the fried green tomatoes, totally standout beef tartare, scotch egg, kale salad, and popcorn ice cream for dessert.  NOMS!

The bar downstairs is often incredibly crowded and you have to yell to hear each other and elbow throw (and be elbowed through) a crowd six deep around the bar. Not fun. I always hold out for a table, or go somewhere else.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Excellent cocktails and food.  I had the evil woman drink.  Aren't all women evil? Just kidding.  It was very favorfull. My bestie and I shared the deep fried pork rinds.  Darn good!  Deep fried pork fat with a bit of spicyness. What's not to love. 

Great bar and I most definitely be ack to try the other drinks and food.
author: Marck N.

description:
It's a small space and insanely packed on a Friday night. I had to wait in a line to get in - not what I was expecting for a bar in the Mission, but understandable as Trick Dog was recently on a list of 50 best bars in the nation.

Their cocktails are well crafted and contain interesting elements such as kombu, horseradish, lemongrass, rhubarb, cocoa butter, and sightglass coffee.

Started off the night right with a badass bartender who knew exactly what she was doing. Grabbed our drinks and we were on our merry way. Yes I was eyeballing those mountains of kale salad and coveting those oozing scotch eggs the entire time.

As the night progressed, we made the mistake of gravitating towards the end of the bar, where our bartender seemed confused and overwhelmed - and that's a nice way of putting it. 

PS I want the badass pantone menus back.
author: Jessica O.

description:
Gotta love those hip new places that don't have signs... signs are for squares right?  From the moment I walked in to Trick Dog and spotted the mix master mixologist's working their craft, I knew I was going to like this place.  It's like going into a secret drink lab where the menu is a list of complicated schematics and the tools of the trade... beakers of all sorts and sizes.  I believe my bartender's name was Chad (whichever one is from Boston).  His service was top notch and i was actually fascinated watching him make my drinks.

My first drink was a bartenders choice that a friend of mine got and I had to try.  The only instructions were bourbon and citrus and the rest was on Chad.  He did an amazing job and I wish I could remember what it was called because I would definitely try to get a replication back home.

Next up was the Pennies From Heaven (Templeton Rye, Meletti, Leopold sour apple liqueur, sherry, and Gold Rush bitters).  I Thoroughly enjoyed this one even with the added sweetness.  Until I tried the Witch Wood.  I'm not downing on the Pennies From Heaven, but the Witchwood (Torres ten-year brandy, Pampero Aniversario rum, Manzilla sherry, Pedro Ximenez sherry, Ron Miel honey rum, and Alhambra bitters Served up) was wonderfully wicked.

I can't wait to go back.

PS. - I heard people are stealing those sweet ass bar menus that look like paint swatches.  Don't do that.  Doing that makes you an asshole and discourages the bar owner from wanting to incorporate unique products into his establishment in fear that children won't know how to behave in public.
author: Scotty C.

description:
Creative and delicious drinks, no real complaints there. Didn't try the I'm-sure-magical food program. 

But like most bars (and restaurants) oozing their way into residential neighborhoods, this one has an air of dickishness about it. Maybe not to those who also have an air of dickishness about them, but to most people who pay attention to culture and politics, it does. It's hard to want the place to succeed after that ridiculous video made by the owners on how to spend $1000 in the Mission. Just so incredibly tone-deaf and sadly emblematic of the wave of gentrification surging through the Mission, to name but one neighborhood.

So yeah, on one hand, this place is a bar that has good drinks and a fun, bar-ish atmosphere. But it also represents a "new" Mission that many many people don't want. There isn't that much they can do about, so I'd guess the owners just don't give a sh**.
author: Ian M.

description:
Hands down one of the top 5 cocktail bars in San Francisco.  Everything on the menu is fantastic and there is definitely something for everybody.  I love that their current menu is set to Song Names and printed on various records, its a great idea.  I tried:

- Mr. Big Stuff
- Heat Wave
- Leather & Lace
- She's Gone

I would love to go back and try some of the items off the food menu as well.
author: Chad T.

description: Been back a couple times, back when they had the zodiac menu and recently with the Chinese menu. It was pretty fantastic. Their drinks were impressive and priced accordingly ($13 cocktails). We also got some mezcal/Montenegro shots which were brilliant. Triple-fried fries, I finally got to try them!! Legit. And a wonderful heap of kale salad to balance it all out. The bartenders were the good kind of sarcastic. We were there until close and they kicked us out very kindly.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Loved this place.  Amazing drinks and really good food.  We started with drinks downstairs and then headed upstairs for dinner. 
A great place to go if you like specialty cocktails and a cool crowd.  
Will definitely be back!
author: T S.

description:
This bar is awesome! My coworker took us here one random afternoon and the ambiance is very nice and clean. I love how they switch their menu's every 6 months into something creative. This particular time was a map of SF and they had drinks based on the districts! You could also take one of their postcards and put it in the mail and they will mail your postcard for free! They said that there are new drinks every 6 months. 

The bartenders are super knowledgeable and you can tell that they have a passion for what they do. Their drinks are very unique and you can tell that there is a lot of pride in each drink. 


Definitely worth checking out if you are in the area!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Cute and cozy bar. Solid drinks and I like that they try to be different with the menu but the records kept falling out of its book.  

Next time, I'll def try to get a seat upstairs for some delicious food (hello, Dutch egg) and good drinks.
author: Nho C.

description:
I was looking for last min place for good drinks and found The Trick Dog.  From the outside you can easily miss it, there is no sing with establishments name nor address and it almost looks like a private home party with intimate lighting but when you enter is very much so lively and quite noisy.  The place is small but there is this simple yet classy vibe about it. The decor is enchanted with funky brassy lamp holders, candles and pictures which just work. The staff is attentive and sweet and if there is something not on the drink menu  which is funky in itself because the drinks are in a book made out if old small vinyl records and the baby turtle was not available but I was offered something similar that the mixologist was willing to make it for me which u declined,  I asked for them to use Polish vodka which I was super surprised that they had - luksusowa, mint and asked for the drink to be little sweet and they made a yummy drink which was bubbly....A for effort for sure, very small drink that Polish myself would need to order many of. 
Lets get to the yummy stuff...food! The shrimp cocktail which included 4 shrimp total for $12 so you do the math was incredible, each of these shrimp was cooked to perfection and the horseradish sauce was such a nice compliment. The three slices of green fried tomatoes for $6 were bland and needed some seasoning on them, they were presented with a source but slobs they were just too plain.  The trick dog was a hot dog sandwich which I guess makes sense but since I was tired I was surprised that it was a " sandwich" but when I took a bite, I was over powered by bread so I took the bread off and the beef was incredible! Just fantastic!
author: Magda G.

description:
This place gets super crowded. I found out about it on a Zagat blog so I was surprised that there would be some sort of wait to get service. Expect a fight over bar stools. When we finally got a spot at the bar, we let loose and ordered a bunch of items.

We got these items:
1) scotch egg - soft-boiled egg, brandade, beet confit, salmon roe, crème fraiche
2) the trick dog - house ground blend of chuck, brisket & sirloin, lettuce, onion, pickles, cheddar cheese, house sauce
3) thrice-cooked fries - manimal style
4) grandma's sweater - beefeater 24 gin, zucca rabarbaro, blood orange, lime, mint, bitter lemon soda, served long
5) pennies from heaven - templeton rye, amaro meletti, leopold brothers sour apple liquer, amontillado sherry, the bon vivants' gold rush bitters, served up

Everything was good and we were too full for ambulation immediately afterwards. The drink menu is very creative and the drinks themselves were unique/flavorful. I like how the employees wear like 1850's railroad worker outfits--that's what they remind me of at least. There's a place upstairs with tables for food/drink service, but good luck getting a seat promptly because there's only like 8 of them and 50 other parties want to the same thing. There are no reservations (I think).

This is a nice little trendy joint.
author: Marlon T.

description: What is this? A super hip bar with stellar cocktail menu designed by the Bon Vivants that changes occasionally. Expect a long wait and loud crowds inside. The cocktails are unique and themed. The menu is usually a statement itself. Their current menu is the SF Tourist Map. My favorite of this is Sutro Baths, which incorporates Sightglass Coffee, located just next door. Lombard Street and Coit Tower were nice for the summer. Their dining menu is small, but you'd get to sit upstairs if so.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Very, very, very crowded. Especially on a Saturday night. The place will be full of SF power nerds and you'll likely be waiting 15-20 mins for an overpriced cocktail. 

if you're looking to 1.) meet men or 2.) drink, go elsewhere.
author: Vanessa Y.

description:
Drinks-tastie
Food-Delicious!!!! 
Atmosphere- AMAZING!!!!! if you went to highschool in the early 2000s you would love it!! The music just takes you back to the good old days. 

Awesome Staff!!
author: Jackie I.

description:
IT'S PRICEY. You're spending $9-$12 depending on a drink and some "okay"food. 

I got the pork tacos and mammal fries and I really only enjoyed the fries which were reasonably priced. The tacos were just okay. 

I'm torn with the drinks because they're really great quality, but It hurt to spend so much on them. If you feel like splurging and treating yourself to a top quality drink, by all means go for it. I guess the quality and top variety of spirits makes up for their "eh" food. 

Oh and the bartender (forgot her name) was great, gave my boyfriend a FREE taster of their whiskey, which went for over $20!
author: Rachel M.

description:
So, the jury's out on this one still.  I came on a Tuesday night with some friends to grab a few drinks and the drink I had (Pantone) was boubon with beet, ginger and lemon.  Super earthy and what I thought it was going to taste like.  The other cocktail that I tried a sip of (Vintage Photo) was just...interesting.  Very strong, but not my thing at all.  Tasted like it should have been on top of an ice cream dessert or something.  $3 Miller Highlifes were a hit with the boys.  

Overall, good scene, bartenders were very quick to get orders and entertaining to watch.. Reserving more stars because the one drink I ordered was good but nothing to write home about and the selection was a bit underwhelming.  Next time I go (not on a weeknight where caffeine and tequila are not the smartest decisions), I want to try the baby turtle and night moves.  Will review again!
author: Raina D.

description: Love the vibe. Awesome menus. Great drinks. Food was delicious. The tricknuggets tasted like kabob, wow! Couldn't believe the trick dog was brisket and chuck, very good!
author: C C.

description:
Wow.

The cocktails..so on point. You cannot go wrong with any of the drinks here. The mixology here is very memorable! (....or not :P )


Food...amazing price point, great ingredients, flavors are amazing. Everything on the menu is great to share. 

I cannot wait to come back! The space is great, bottom level is the bar and open standing space. Upstairs is intimate and has a great feel to it. Lighting is great as well.

Trick dog is my new favorite!!
author: Selina W.

description: After my first visit this afternoon this instantly became one of my favorite places in San Fran. Not sure what is was about this place that made me like it so much before even trying anything but it must have been the great vibe I felt after walking in. After taking a look at the menus I ordered a drink and some food. Once I tasted the drink my love of this place was confirmed. Then the food came and I wanted to stay the rest of the evening. Unfortunately I stopped in by chance as I was only in the city for work. I will be returning next time I am down there so I can linger a bit longer and try one of the many other drinks I wanted. Great spot.
author: Doug M.

description:
My friend recommended this to me, which she heard from her friend. I walked right past the front entrance on my way here, it looks boarded up and there's not much natural lighting inside - it's a large open bar space on the lower level and a more intimate dining area at the top. We didn't have reservations for dinner but it was a nice space to have amazing cocktails while we waited.

We ordered grandma's sweater (I love anything with mint and thought the proportions were perfect), baby turtle, and gypsy tan (which I've just listed in order of my preference). The colors of the drinks are super cool and unique. The menu is interesting with a large variety (see menu at their site).

We ordered the trick dog which was delicious, manimal fries (gluttony at its best) and a soft boiled egg. All were well prepared and unique and tasty, although kind of pricey.

My throat felt super sore afterwards because we basically yelled at each other for three hours straight, since it's so loud inside. That's the only reason I give it less than 5 stars - how loud it is.

Service was average in attentiveness but very nice and friendly. I highly recommend this as a date place or a small group outing (definitely not large though).
author: Melissa T.

description:
The bartenders can be uppity and annoying. Yes, they are good at mixing drinks. But he made some strong comments, and made us feel pretty crappy. So uncomfortable. Ugh. 

It's also very hot in there, and I was sweating bullets the whole time. Never going back again.
author: Andy C.

description: Great cocktail bar! One of the most famous place in the neighborhood, always packed but totally worth it! The menu changes often and is always original!
author: Julien S.

description:
Had fun fun fun with the pro bar tender who apparently created the drinks on our menu last night.  Mine was the one with bourbon, peanut and sage.  Was NOT at all as froufy as it sounded.  Was definitely boozy enough.

My friend is a fan of their kale salad and I had their TASTY scotch egg variation -  soft poached egg inside a salt cod brandade bomb like thing over a nicely seasoned romesco sauce.  Not enough chefs leave their romesco so nicely piquant.  
Fish tacos looked good but were kinda meh.  Fish could have used some seasoning/heat?
The french fries sounded better than they were.  Not bad, not overly memorable.  Maybe if they came out with a little something else?  

The lighting in this place needs some work.  Before sunset, we grabbed bar stools near the one window and the space immediately around us felt cozy.  Otherwise, the rest of the bar felt a bit 1940s prison like. 

Once the bar got crowded, it was annoying to have a throng of people hovering right up on us to get their drinks.  Wonder if there's some way to set up the drink making stations or get drinks out more quickly to alleviate the big push against the bar?
author: m h.

description:
The Kale Salad was the highlight of the dinner. I need to come back here soon just to have that salad again. We also had the chicken nuggets (just okay) and the beef tartare (pretty good). I saw from photos that they used to have Scotch Eggs -- I'm sad that they don't any more :(

I had the "Chemtrails" (sweet and lighter) and the "Illuminati" (stronger, with Rye whiskey) cocktails to drink. My partner had one of their mocktails (the "root beer"). The cocktails were inventive (one of them had caramel corn on top!) and pretty tasty, though a bit small for the price. The "Root Beer" was a very strange rust color, and was definitely a unique spin on the flavors in root beer.
author: Chris M.

description: The 1star is for the inflexibility of the manager for no good reason. We came in Thursday evening and had a table of four and we needed a fifth last minute. Couldn't accommodate even with empty tables. it wasn't even OK to swing a chair over from an empty table.  I could understand if it was 7 PM but it's the end of the line and plenty of seats and tables open and they could accommodate if they wanted to instead some nonsense policy. Unbelievable and disgusting customer service. you lost a loyal customer here. The irony ? The ended up acquiescing but too late, as I already left to Tradesmen where they are much cooler and great food and accommodated me even with the kitchen closing by just a few minutes. I knew where I'll spend my money where they treat people like humans.
author: Daniel S.

description: 3.5 star. This place is way over hyped! It was average but not over your mind awesome! We came here because the burger was listed as one of the top burgers in SF. It was just ehh. We tried the steak, shrimp noodles, chicken nuggets and fries. I would have been satisfied with super duper burger or mc Donald's chicken nuggets. The drinks were very different and unique. I would definitely recommend coming here for drinks instead of food.
author: Vivian N.

description:
Stumbled upon this diamond in the rough on my way to central kitchen next door (review to come). 

Asked a gentleman outside, "what is this place called". "Trick dog" he said as he continued to suggest cocktails and lead us inside. Doorman, manager, I don't know but he was one of the nicest people I've ever met at a bar. 

Walked inside, great looking bar and people. We quickly slide up to the bar and were handed menus. The bartender was super
Nice too?!? Where am I?!? We ordered the Capricorn and the Pisces cocktails. Both delicious and I would most definitely order again.

We stood since the bar was crowded and left after our first cocktail. So excited to come here again! Looks like a great place for parties, dinners, happy hours and a great change up from the marina!
author: Heather H.

description:
Love this place! Great for drinks and appetizers!! There is a drink with Tequila 
and Wipped Cream AMAZING! Great music!
author: Maria P.

description: Such a hipster spot. We all know that Trick Dog doesn't really serve authentic Chinese food, but I was expecting something surprising. The Rice Taco was the only surprise, the rest of the dishes were A-ok. I found everything a bit over-priced, including a non-alcoholic beverage with lime, celery, soda in it.. $7 is a lot for a small glass. The vibe was very good, you can find many hipsters gathering in this Mission spot (of course!). Nothing special for me to go back again. Will hop into another hipster joints in Mission to satisfy my experience in SF.
author: Shaz L.

description: I. Love. This. Place. Came for drinks on my birthday and had a great time. Cool location and atmosphere and the drinks and menus are so fun! The drinks are unique--I tried the Area 51, which had a great spicy kick to it, and the Chupacabra, which mixes root beer with tequila; certainly not a combo I would've thought of, but it worked! My friend who lives in the city told me that the themes of the menus change all the time. I can't wait to come back and see what drinks they're serving next time!
author: Liz D.

description: Consistently been a hip cool spot with a hipster vibe.   Been here a few times.   The drinks are pretty interesting, and it did apparently get recognized as one of the top 50 bars in the world.    I've gotten just the cava, and I've  also had the bartender whip me up a drink based on a few suggestions.  She did a great job.  It took a while to concoct but it was really good.  Definitely plan to go back and try more.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Not just anywhere can I order a drink called the Castro Theatre nor the Dragon's Gate, all SF location-based titled cocktails. They actually had some tasty food items, too, including "manimal" fries and a sea bass crudo dish. Trick Dog even blends up their own unique version of a Fireball shot, should you choose to accept it.

Quite crowded here, but perhaps understandably so. Appears to be a full-blown restaurant upstairs. Shares a hallway restroom with neighboring restaurant, too, so don't get lost when finding your way back!
author: Garett T.

description: Delicious drinks and good music. The only downside is this is a very small space and if you are going with a group that more than 4 you might want to skip for another spot. But if you are willing to wait for drinks, which should be easy cause your with friends listen to awesome music, then it's worth it.
author: Theresa D.

description:
Dashing metal-on-modern modern decor. If this place had lofts, I would already be living in the dog house. Their drinks are good too, but here's the trick: the kinetics of their cocktail chemistry experiments is on the order of weeks to months. What a logjam. 

In all my nights of drinking, this is the slowest mixology I have ever witnessed. I counted three bartenders working--one bearded hipster boy, one adult man in suspenders, one siren in tights. They moved like manatees or filibustering congressmen. Meanwhile, thirsty customers stormed the bar like it was D-day, their bodies piling up in rows as they were repelled. Despite my determination and relative lack of courtesy to others, it still took 30 minutes to place an order, and the realization of that order recapitulated the first moratorium on intoxication. I could never come back here again sober.
author: Lou S.

description: Went here last month for the first time.  It was super trendy (read ton's of hipsters, men in flannel with beards and a bit of a meat market) with good drinks but holy heck was it crowded.  Maybe I'm just getting too old for places like this but waiting 30 min fighting your way to the bar to pay $15+ for a cocktail (albeit a good one) seems like waayyyy too much work on a weeknight.  If I come back it would be to have some food upstairs where you have some breathing space at your own table.
author: Grace L.

description: It can get tight in this dimly lit unmarked bar, but the drinks are good, they play good music, and it's a good time here. I've even had he food upstairs and I remember a really good kale Ceaser salad with the best croutons, good steak, and a crazy waiter because when I asked if they had dessert the waiter told me, "we don't have dessert but we have Scotch." so uh.. What do I say to that? "Um. ok I'll have a scotch." "Do you want nice and pricey or funky and not as expensive." "Uh.. Funky?!" Lol. It was funky! It took my table of 4, passing the drink to one another sarcastically saying "this is Sooo good!" I came back fort Bday to try their CALENDER cocktails. Everyone was happy with July, Which had a chedder cheese garnish and was pretty stiff but everyone seemed to find it addicting.
author: Hazel F.

description: Great cocktails, inventive af!! The menu can seem intimidating at first but embrace it and look for your liquor of choice to narrow down your options. It may seem like you'll never be able to order your drink due to the crowd but be patient and one of their renowned and well trained mixologists will acknowledge you and make your drink with the attention to detail and speed it deserves. Don't expect to find a place to sit, to rest those weary feet but the people watching more then makes up for the lack of seating. Great night for pre or post cocktails with the girls or a date you only care to stare at vs. actually talk to!
author: Mita P.

description:
Okay, I haven't tried the food, which I hear is phenomenal.. but someday! Besides that, the mixed drinks are great, and they change up the menu every few months. And by that, I don't just mean new drinks, they literally craft brand new menus. Each time, they're creative little masterpieces.

If you like crafted cocktails in a cool space with awesomely crafted menus, come here!
author: Ashley G.

description:
**Drinks and bar review only

Round of applause to those bartenders 'cause those cocktails are kickin'! Every drink I had was perfectly made--delicious and strong. Awesome beer offerings, first time seeing Headlands Brewery in the city.

Great ambiance, mellow and modern decor.
author: Emmeline A.

description: Cocktails are off the hook at this spot and the Horoscope/Zodiac drink menu? AWESOME. After a painfully poor dinner next door at Central Kitchen, we cruised into Trick Dog and the place was popping, tasty looking dishes circled around us, and I wished we had eaten there instead. It's certainly a creative little joint. A fun spot for a night cap indeed.
author: Isabella J.

description: What can I say...This is my favorite bar in the city. The staff is great. They are friendly and extremely knowledgable. They take great care in their cocktails. The food is also wonderful. The kale salad aka the mountain of kale is my favorite, followed by the trick dog (burger) and the chicken nuggets.
author: John J.

description: Highly recommend this place! Great service! Very kind professional bartenders! Josh did his own amazing wisky drink as per my request. Clean and very enjoyable atmosphere! Will definitely come back!
author: S V.

description:
This is certainly a good bar with a creative cocktail program. But man - it could use an attitude adjustment.

My friend and I arrived here around 5pm to catch up over a drink. I was excited to check it out because their libation program was created by the Bon Vivants (one of SF's top mixology teams). It's located in a funky yet burgeoning part of the Mission (20th St. @ Florida), next to Central Kitchen, Salumeria, and Flour + Water. Be warned: parking in this hood ain't easy. 

We saddled up at the bar and perused the menu. The menu is actually pretty clever - it's a rotating circular thingy (like something out of a board game), and you move it around to find your zodiac sign, and then it recommends a drink for you. I'm a Libra, and the corresponding drink was an interesting concoction of tequila, tangerine, dill, lime, and egg white, and maccha. All of those ingredients sounded appealing to me except the egg white. In fact, all the zodiac inspired drinks looked tasty at first, but then it would have one or two ingredients that didn't match my palate. I finally asked the hipster bartender if I could just order a regular cocktail like a martini or manhatten. This is the part that kind of cracked me up. She looked at me all snooty and replied, "Yeah. Why wouldn't you?" And then rolled her eyes. "I'm sorry," I said, "I just didn't see any other drinks listed on the menu. Can I just have a manhatten on the rocks?" She kind of nodded at me as if unimpressed by my drink order. My friend decided to stick with the zodiac cocktail program and order the Libra/Tequila drink. "Would it be possible to order this drink without the egg white?" my friend sheepishly inquired. The bartender just sort of stared blankly at her for a few seconds and replied, "Why? Do you have some sort of aversion to egg white or something?" This response definitely caught the both of us off guard. "Um, no. we just don't like it." The bartender sighed and went off to make our drinks. 

After we got our drinks, we tried to find somewhere to sit. All the bar stools were more or less taken, and the rest of the bar area is comprised of tables and counters where you just sort of lean and drink. We decided to go upstairs to see if we could grab a table and chat. It looked more like an empty dining room with tables and silverware. But before we could grab a seat, an employee told us that this section was closed off until 5pm for dinner service. I looked at my watch and we were about 5 minutes early. So cocktails in hand and tails between our legs, we returned to the downstairs bar area and perched our drinks at one of the lean in counters.

Over all, the cocktails were very tasty. My friend loved her egg white-less tequila beverage. And my manhatten was perfectly balanced. Instead of serving it on the rocks, they gave me the largest ice cube I have ever seen (this thing was a boulder). In fact, it made drinking it by hand a little tricky (maybe that's why they call it Trick Dog). So I had to grab a straw to stick in my glass. I made sure to do it while the bartender wasn't looking, lest she roll her eyes again and judge me.

Long story short - this place makes good drinks and attracts a lively crowd. This isn't my normal go-to neighborhood, so it was nice to get out of my comfort zone and explore some place new. I would definitely return for a tasty cocktail, and I'd like to try some of their menu items. I'm just hoping that when I return, the servers drop the 'tude and make the customers feel more welcome. In my opinion, that's the difference between a good bar and a great bar.
author: Kevin B.

description: This place is lame. I don't like the vibe. There isn't enough space. The patrons are generally unkempt and/or frumpy.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Fine bar. Always pretty crowded and drink menu always changing. The drinks can take a moderate amount of time as they're all complex. This week we ordered the #5 and LOVED it. 

Won't go out of my way to return.
author: Wendy K.

description: Drinks are good and the scotch egg is a must order. It's not my favorite place but its a good place to grab a drink with a friend. A bit loud for groups but atmosphere and hipster vibe makes this place a scene to be in. I'd go back if others asked but not my go-to place for drinks.
author: Marlene T.

description:
DRINKS:
Pantone = s'ok
Razzle Dazzle = mm! I'm getting this one next time. So yummies. 

SERVICE:
good

ATMOSPHERE:
Small, cute, raw "speakeasy" ish... Novelty menu in pantone swatch how clever
author: Angela L.

description:
We rarely get to the Mission for drinking/dining purposes, but when we do, we've found we just cannot go wrong. V Day at Trick Dog was no exception! 

Great service from start to finish. We dined upstairs and started with a few cocktails - yes, they are as good as everyone makes them out to be. Also snacked on the manimal fries, trick dog sandwich, and pulled pork tacos. Loved every bite of each dish. Can all fries please be manimal fries? Crispy crunch perfection.  Loved the chill, happy crowd. Nailing service, food, drink, and ambiance is no easy task, I applaud you, Trick Dog!
author: Brianna M.

description:
One of mine (and apparently everyone else's) favorite cocktail bars in SF. The Bad Girl stole my heart. All the drinks are aggressively well-balanced and inventive, and I love that they change up the cocktail menu every so often (before Pantone paintstrips, now vintage 45s).

Also appreciate the gorgeous design of the space - love the overlapping/sliding panels that hold all the liquor behind the bar.

I never thought I'd ever utter the words "I want some headcheese taco in my mouth so bad!" But I have, multiple times. That dish and their brandade coated scotch egg are to die bananas Zomgs lol #yolo #fomo...?

I'm trying my best at hip slang, but I'm old. Anyway, what I mean to say is it's really very good and you should probably eat things and drink things here.
author: Selina K.

description:
Ok this is a first impression review because I've only been here once and I'm going to keep it that way. I came on a weekday night because Kronnerburger was doing a pop up for two nights! I came at 10pm and they said the wait would be an hour, they took down my cell and I went to another bar to grab some drinks and meet up with friends. 

11:20pm rolls around and I haven't received a call, I've been continually checking my phone. I walk back to Trick Dog with my friends and we walk upstairs to the dining area and there's 4 empty tables! Then I tell the waitress that we never received a call and she seats us on the spot- which would have been great but she gave me major attitude not apologizing but actually making it seem like they called and we just didn't answer. She continued to be nasty towards us when she came back to give us our drinks. And she hands us our menu and informs us that the burger is out.. Which is the entire reason we came.so we all walked out. This place left a really bad taste in my mouth. It honestly would have been ok if the waitress would have treated us better.
author: Jariah B.

description:
Not my kind of place....

Drinks are good but wildly overpriced for the quality of booze and size.

It's the ambiance that ruins this place though, it is literally full of people who think very highly of themselves and not much of others.

Staff were cool, doormen were chill but the other bar goers were just awfully pretentious and off putting.

Swerve if you like places full of chill, nice people....you won't find any here :(
author: Cali J.

description: This place is very cute! The menu (changes every 6 months) was made to look like a top secret file. We got the chicken nuggets that comes with three delicious sauces and the kale salad, yum! the drinks were equally good, would definitely come back!
author: Rachel G.

description:
Please bring the beet cocktail back!!!!!!!!
I still go in there thinking maybe they changed the menu back up again and they got the beet cocktail on it! Nope.... It's still that horoscope wheel..It's ok I still love you. 
Great local mission bar for a killer cocktail. It's a good place to hit up after dinner because you are not ready to go home yet and you might just need few more drinks.
author: Tumay A.

description:
An awesome speakeasy, yet modern style bar/lounge in the Mission. It has no sign at the door, so make sure you use GPS to find it. Though it's pretty crowded and hard to miss. 

Must gets:
$10 Scotch Egg - think if an eggs benedict, a crab cake and a croquette had a lovechild, it's amazing and well worth the ten dollar bill
Astrology Drinks - the bartenders are extremely skilled and put a ton of effort into these (and other) drinks depending on your birthdate. Some (Aries / Libra) are extremely strong speakeasy style, and others are light and refreshing. Try them all.

The cocktails are just fun and unique and a definite photo op. Check it out!
author: Chuck N.

description:
The cocktails here are always well done and the menu changes constantly giving you a sometimes challenging and sometimes charming way of navigating a list of cocktail specials. 

The Mr Tough Guy I believe, is a super tasty lime / coconut type drinks that comes in a surprisingly funny mug of sorts.  

Haven't tried food but my first time I was there I overheard the bartender explaining the process for making a popcorn flavored hand made ice cream by straining buttery popcorn into cream at the beginning.
author: Leland T.

description: Generously, the venue can accommodate mayyyyyybe 40 people. Last Friday night, they easily had 80 people crammed into that tiny box of a room. How people even hear each other is beyond me. I went to school in Austin, so I've been around 6th street and I know what crowded is, but this place seemed to be crowded for no reason. No where to sit, no place to lean, hardly any place to stand -- I don't get it.
author: Zi-on C.

description:
Why am I just now hearing about this Jem in the city.. This place is The place. Drink menu? BAM! Music? Pure 80's classics. ..

Why haven't you ordered yet? Stop reading reviews.. And just go.
author: Chris L.

description:
Each time I come I wonder why it took me so long to get back here.  

This time around they're doing SF themed cocktails, and the menu is on a map of SF. 

Favorites: 
- Sutro baths: yes coffee sounds weird, but it's very subtle and a super well balanced drink 
- Alcatraz: beautiful giant ice cube, very spirit driven 
- Coit tower: more citrusy but not too sweet at all. I love the the with cider and thyme 
- Lombard Street: mezcal, cucumber, lime - very refreshing. I don't usually like sherry, but it was very subtle in this

We also got a ceviche with taro chips and sausage to share. Te sausage was super flavorful and came with apples and an amazing mustard - perfect to go with drinks.  I'm sad they don't have the scotch egg anymore :(

I love watching them at the bar - their multi tasking skills are amazing, which is why they  can churn out high quality drinks at a reasonable pace. 

It's super low key but is probably the best mixology in the Bay Area.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
Such a neat joint! Great food, drinks, and service.

They definitely hit the mark.
author: Bianca D.

description: I liked this place. Nice upstairs area for dinner - don't give up if it looks busy from the door. Fries are great, as are the short rib tacos. Love the drink menu, too. Nice selection of cocktails and local beers.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
As a fan of well-constructed and innovative cocktails, the rollout of the new Trick Dog menu every six months is a heavily anticipated event. The four star rating here is related to the latest drink menu, as I would definitely give the bar five stars overall for being able to consistently construct tasty and creative drinks (with delicious bar food to boot)

I was accompanied by several friends on the most recent visit, so we were able to sample our way through the entirety of the latest Dog Calendar-themed menu. As always, the menu design manages to be fun (the dogs are very cute!) without being too cumbersome. I also really like that this menu can be purchased with the money going to a few dog rescues.

In general, I found that the individual components within many of the drinks on the latest menu tended to get lost compared to some drinks from previous menus (the Aries and Libra from the Zodiac menu, the #'s 8 and 9 drinks from the Chinese restaurant menu for example). While many would argue that ingredients like bonito or tomolive should not stand out within a cocktail, I do feel that being able to taste the different layers in a drink (bitter notes from Campari, depth from chocolate mole bitters or aged rum, etc) elevates my enjoyment of the cocktail. Having said that, all of the drinks do taste good. It's just that there were fewer standouts for me than the previous menu (or the delicious Zodiac menu).

A synopsis of each drink (with the caveat that the bulk of these judgments are based on a sip or two from the drink from one of my friends. My liver and wallet are certainly not strong enough to handle all of these drinks alone!):

January: A pretty tasty spin on a Sour style of cocktail. I liked how the Irish Whiskey worked with the orange citrus and bitter notes from the Gran Classico and the vanilla. Some friends found the drink a tad on the sweet side, but this was not the case for me personally

February: A fun play on a Tiki-style drink with a split tequila and rum base. The key lime is quite prominent and reminded me of a liquefied slice of key lime pie. Depending on your point of view, this could be good or bad (mark my vote in the good column!) 

March: Refreshing, but I only noticed the citrus and strawberry. Did not pick up any of the spice or bitterness from the Ancho Reyes or Campari

April: Another refreshing drink that mostly tasted like a (fresh) grape soda, though hints of bitterness from the Suze did peak through

May: Tasted like a nice margarita (certainly not a bad thing)

June: A nice spin on the Pimm's Cup, but the bar seemed to be out of mint and cucumber. I think the aromatic note from the mint would have bumped my enjoyment of this drink up a bit higher

July: Definitely the cocktail on the new menu with the most disparate list of ingredients. However, everything came together to make a wonderfully complex and enjoyable drink. This was the consensus favorite amongst our group. The bourbon is initially present, before the citrus, blackberry, and wine notes come forward. The drink finishes with the spice and herbal notes from the bourbon and amaro. For those worried about the sharp cheddar, it is a garnish (but does contribute to the aroma; not as bad as it sounds, trust me!)

August: Another favorite of mine. The baking spices from the barrel aged reposado and the nuttiness of the sherry worked very well together (though some friends commented that they gave a bit of a peanut-buttery flavor)

September: Mostly came away with scotch and stone fruit (maybe plum) notes from the drink, with the other ingredients getting a bit lost. Good, but did not pick up on the aroma or flavor from the dill, grapiness of the cognac, etc

October: A savory spin on a martini, though I would give a slight nod to the martini-variant from the previous menu (#6)

November: On paper, this drink had the greatest pull for me. However, I was only able to pick up on the bourbon with a note of orange. I was curious to see how the pear/pecan vermouth would contribute to the flavor, but they were not noticeable. Not a bad drink at all, but did not stand out too much from other Manhattan variants available in the city.

December: Another drink that sounded good on paper, but mostly tasted like a rye old fashioned (again, not bad, but also not on the level of some of their other drinks). The other ingredients did not really stand out upon my tasting.

In summation, it was another fun trip to Trick Dog for me and my group of friends. However, the bar has set a very high...what's the word?...bar for itself and I feel like less drinks had the same wow factor on this menu versus some prior versions. I still would happily return to have more of the July, August, or February and definitely look forward to menu #7!
author: Brad G.

description: This place is the worst, it's filled with bros who fart on you and pretend like they didn't and the bartenders take drink orders from up to 10 people at once. I went last night & ordered three drinks at once for me and my friends. Instead of working on my order, the bartender took three more orders and then began slowly working on them. Then, probably because he took so many orders all together, he gave me someone else's credit card after paying. Now I'm left with someone else's card, I have to go cancel mine, & wait for a new card in the mail. Not to mention how not worth it this place was. My drink tasted like mango salsa and was overpriced
author: Lily H.

description:
Stopped by yesterday on the recommendation from a friend.  Thank god that friend is smart and has good  taste!  She told me where it was and that it wasn't automatically noticeable from the street. She was right- I wouldn't have guessed it was there and would have kept on walking       

My friend told me she and her girlfriend went around 4:30 on a Sunday and it wasn't that crowded. They were able to have a few drinks and apps. She was totally spot on. My friend and I arrived around 5 on Saturday and bar was not too crowded. I was able to order drinks relatively fast-it took me longer to go through their drink menu than it took to make the drinks. 

They have very inventive concoctions on their menu. My friend had Grandma's Sweater and I stuck with my tried and true Campari and soda (don't judge me). Both were delish. The bartenders are lovelyto look at and friendly - what a girl can't appreciate eye candy?  Drinks were reasonably priced. The crowd was a mix of hipsters and older folks- alright by me. 

We didn't have any food but it looked delish and my friend and I talked about going back for dinner very soon. 

Thanks for the recommendation, Kristi. I will be back.
author: Cindi C.

description:
I guess I need to try the food because the cocktails are just okay for me. One time we had to send a drink back. During my last visit the mezcal cocktail was unbalanced. I know it's spirit forward, but damn. 

I'm not really feeling the space either.
author: Derrick V.

description: Amazing crowd, barely amy standing room, but such a fun place to hang out and unwind after a long week. The drinks are strong, the service is as efficient as it can be with such a huge following. Good luck squeezing your way to the restroom at the very back of the establishment! I'm dying to try the food next time!
author: Judy L.

description: Food, cocktails, our waitress and ambiance were wonderful. But the manager made us feel super unwelcome. We were a party of 11 and when seating us it was a huge deal to get a table and enough chairs even though there were many free (it was 5pm). Then he kept stopping by asking if we were ordering more food, saying there were other (smaller!) parties who he could seat at our table. It was very unprofessional - you don't make a huge deal when seating a table in a space with lots of free seats... and then once sat make them feel bad for being there. He stopped once he saw how much we were spending.
author: J E.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco, hands down!  Their menu is small, but full of amazing choices that they rotate regularly.  It's kind of tapas style, making this a great place to meet and bring friends.  They have the most creative drink menu too... It's based upon the signs of the horoscope.  

Everything here is made fresh and with the highest quality care and ingredients, from the bar, to the kitchen.

The bar itself is always packed and pretty loud, but the dining area doesn't really pick up that noise.  I don't think they take reservations, but their dining area is also small so it can take a while to get a table on a good night.  

The entire place was put together with a very industrial design in mind.  You can tell that they were paying attention to all of the details (even though I found a light fixture that was installed backwards from the others).  :)

The staff is all friendly and hard working.  You can't ask for much more than that.

If it's on the menu when you go, be sure to get their beef jerky (with horseradish), kale, or scotch egg.  Everything has been amazing, but those are some of our favorites.

I'd recommend this restaurant to anyone any day of the week!
author: Will S.

description: I'm old so I like good drinks and quiet. This place has great drinks but is loud as hell (damn rowdy hipsters). But can they mix drinks! Old man pro tip: order a Sazerac--the obnoxious youth won't have a clue why your quietly sitting there with a creepy huge smile on your face.
author: Jason G.

description: Went for a late night dinner. Loved the vibe, and the food was great! My friend loved the kale salad, i thought it was a littler bitter, but it's kale so no surprise there. Ordered a pina colada in a pine apple! Delicious and fun! Would definitely go back.
author: Bailey M.

description:
4.5 stars, a slight negative for the lack of atmosphere. 

Bartenders can vary, some awesome, some not very friendly. But they have DELICIOUS whiskey drinks. Definitely one of my favorite cocktail bars in the city. My favorite drink so far is Alcatraz; the bourbon and horseradish go together wonderfully. The Coit Tower was pretty good too. 

Good stop for a drink and people watching, but a very bland atmosphere/seating (or should I say lack of it?)

Go to Trick Dog for a good cocktail; they will not disappoint.
author: Sneha P.

description:
All in all, great place for crafty libations. The space is fun & lively. Trick Dog fills up pretty quickly on Friday & Saturday nights, so get there early if you can, or else you'll feel a bit claustrophobic. 

Only downside comes with the crowds: it can take up to 15 minutes to put a drink order in. I usually end up feeling like a creep trying to make intense eye contact with the bartender. But once you do, and you take the first sip of your drink, you realize it was definitely worth the wait. Be patient; you won't be disappointed!
author: K K.

description: I am surprised that I haven't written a review for Trick Dog for the amount of times I've gone there and dragged friends there. This is my favorite bar in San Francisco for many reasons. First of all, the drinks are always well made and are always original. You can order your usual or look at their ever changing menu for inspiration. Secondly, they don't ever let it get out of control crowded so there usually isn't a problem with personal space or ordering a drink. Lastly, their food is AWESOME.  I don't need to go grab food anywhere else when I can sit down and eat some of the best food in the city after I'm 4 drinks into my Friday night. The only minus I'll say is that the upstairs can get super loud but that's such a minor issue when you can just hurry up and eat and head back downstairs for one more drink before heading home. Trick Dog, I LOVE you.
author: Jim M.

description:
My husband and I arrived a little after they opened on a Sunday to avoid the crowds for the drinks and eats. As other people have mentioned there's no sign.

We started off with our SF themed drinks of the Painted Ladies and Suttro Baths. Really good drinks! Had another round of drinks too, to pass some time as we didn't know that their food menu items are not served till 5:00 PM. I must have missed that somewhere! The bar starts to get busy around that time too.

At 5 PM we headed upstairs for the bar eats. It was nice because we were the only ones up there until about 6 PM. Also, note that it can get hot/stuffy upstairs, so our window seat was nice! Believe all the hype, the Kale Salad is so good! The other items we ordered were Scotch Egg (okay...our egg was not runny), Hamachi (good), Fish Tacos (okay), Trick Dog (so-so), Thrice Cooked Fries Manimal Stlye (so-so...might have been better sans Manimal which you can get). Not on the menu that we wanted to try was the Cracklins and Beef Tartare. There's always next time!

Also, they give you a postcard/coaster and a stamp for free, which they will mail for you if you put it in their mailbox at the door!
author: Brianne T.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE!!! Went a couple months ago with 5 others and we started with some tasty cocktails and proceeded to order 1 of everything and 2nds on many!!  Best Kale Salad ever created, the manimal fries are a must (we had 3 or 4 orders), the scotch egg...wow!! I can go on, or just say order everything. Our server Keisha was hilarious and very attentive. Good times, good music, great food, great drinks...you can't lose here. If you're in San Fran out Trick Dog on your list!!
author: A M.

description:
Some friends were visiting from Seattle and wanted to check out a cool bar in the city. I asked my friend for a recommendation in the Mission district, and she told me about this place. 

There's no sign outside so we literally almost walked past without noticing it. The guy outside very kindly welcomed us in. We only stopped by for drinks, so unfortunately did not get to try the food (which seems to be pretty good based on the reviews!)

The bar was super crowded when we got there, but as expected I suppose for a Saturday night in the city. I actually don't drink alcohol really, but my friends all ordered a drink or two and commented that they weren't actually that strong. Still good, however. They do have a menu of specialty cocktails here, but I believe my friends all went for their usual drinks. Overall, a decent bar to hang out. If your'e looking for lower volumes and intimate conversations, then this is not for you. But if you're just looking for a fun night out, I would definitely recommend checking this place out.
author: Carole Y.

description:
Kale salad.  I can't stop thinking about kale salad.  

Don't let the hipster force ruin your experience here.  These people know cocktails like you know traffic.  The drinks here are nothing short of brilliance, and while they're a bit on the small side, they're worth every penny of the upscale price.  The drink menu is changing constantly.

Seriously, order a drink, then pay attention while the bartender spends almost as much time making it as you will spend enjoying it.  There is true art in their work.  Not only that, but they're genuinely into their job, and that makes them fun to interact with.

The food is limited to maybe ten or twelve menu items, but they're spectacular.  Don't miss the steak tartare.  Did I mention the kale salad?
author: Benjamin E.

description:
A great bar with even better cocktails! I had the Scorpio cocktail that was absolutely delicious, most satisfactory. I had a taste of the Virgo cocktail, which was sweet and somewhat fruity. 

The food is better than expected for bar food. Eating family style, we were able to try many plates among us. The fried zucchini and beef tartare as our appetizers, both having interesting and one of a kind tastes. The scotch egg was made very well, and tasted exquisite. Definitely the fish tacos stole the show, the fish was crunchy and moist, with a delicious taste. 

The bar was packed on the Friday night we went. A good crowd, and even better service. Starting with the bouncer, Kenny was friendly from the start we walked in. When we were seated at the tables, the waiter recommended great cocktails and food
author: Stacy L.

description:
It was first and probably last visit to Trick Dog. Two stars for a pleasant interior decoration and venue.

Lack of further praise due to Pinocchio, the tall Thor like bartender. I requested 6 Margaritas,for which 4 mixers were used. I pointed out my observation to Pinocchio, but he said that there were two Margaritas' worth of servings in the drinks. It certainly wasn't the case. The drink was served in a short whiskey glass as well, while I witnessed the mixing.

One can only ask for an honest margarita from the Latin American these days.
author: Aristides N.

description:
I was accidently there for Chinese New Year and Trick Dog made a punch that was super delish! Pricey at $5 a large shot glass, but potent and yummy.  I arrived with a gf while they were making it so ordered several of the current signature drinks while waiting for the punch to be ready - no disappointments in those signature cocktails either.  The staff and the patrons were friendly to this older lady with pink hair (me!) and I really enjoyed my experience.   We did order fries and bokchoy to tide us over for dinner and there was plenty on the plates for two. 
Our experience was enhanced by the bearded bartender who looked just like a young George Clooney with brown eyes.  (Swoon!)
The bar design was innovative and the drinks inventive.
author: Donna Blue H.

description:
Love Trick Dog's most recent zodiac cocktail menu. Hands down a complete fan of the Cancer - scotch, pineapple, sage, peanut. Whoa. It was smoky and smooth and delicious.

Also love that their bartenders remain zen among all the chaos. There are like 5, 6 different ingredients in each drink, easily, and they go about mixing, concocting like no one's business. Also retain friendliness and smiles, which is no easy feat.

My only gripe is the small space. It will get crowded, occasionally uncomfortable, but I think they do crowd control pretty well. Also this is not a complaint - people tend to come here with their friends and so inter-socialization is not likely to occur. This is a chill space if you want to catch up with friends and throw down some good cocktails, not holla at yo boy.
author: Brandy A.

description: Everything is to love. SF is so creative! I wish I could remember the name of the drink I had but this was a post flour and water excursion. I will have to try the food the next time around.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
*Epitome of hipster "you're not cool enough to be here" vibe in an up and coming still a little edgy hood in SF
*Note to the bartender, you're not Jax Teller bro so get over the tude, it's over the top.  You're in customer service bro and that's why I'm docking a star, I shouldn't feel like I am bothering you when I order
*Food was blow me away good, I mean, as in, might be some of the tastiest pub grub gourmet I have had in a while.  Still thinking about the scotch egg!
author: Dan S.

description:
What a complete 180 degree difference from the social club in FiDi that my date just took me to. From pretentious hoity-toity to grungy hipster ambiance. I prefer somewhere smack in between. Well we were meeting our friends, since we were double dating. Apparently my date's friend and my girlfriend felt more comfortable going on a double date with us, since we all met at the same time at Harper & Rye. 
They had seats at the bar. It wasn't as packed as it was the very first time that I've been here. So that was nice not having to feel like a sardine. I've never dined at Trick Dog, but it looked good. We rushed our drinks, then walked next door for dinner. I've learned that my date is extremely punctual. He didn't want us late for our reservation.
author: Myra M.

description:
Staff at bar/restaurant were polite and helpful and kale salad looked epic. However, this review is aimed at the crowd, drinks and ambience on a Friday night around 11.

Entire upstairs is a dining area and not much room to move around downstairs, better for an after work place if it were empty-20 people.  Whole venue space is typical small, crowded bar. Drink menus in a fake old timey record folder. Hard to read and I don't wear glasses. Other customers equally deterred by tiny print and lack of ease in locating a drink menu (only 2, nothing posted on wall). Novel idea, bad execution. (again would be fine if you were seated and the place was empty and you had the luxury of going through it at a leisurely pace). Each record is a drink and mixed in with the original record title, Black Uhuru and other  artists' real tracks designed to elicit ooOoooos and aaAahs re: musical knowledge and general pretentiousness.

The crowd gave off a similar vibe. I felt like I was in the Marina, Polk  or any urban enclave of corporate hipsters. Had I really left the city for so long,? The Mission went from 25% to a strong 50% to a clean 98% nonconformist-conformist transplant gentrification? No, but this particular venue-Absolutely. There are two overpriced and difficult to book places with "tasting menus" within spitting distance:  Central Kitchen (connected to bar) and flour+water, as well as a beerstein and "Shotwells" a local pub serving beer and wine only..... so it makes sense. I remember growing up, a friend lived on Lexington and 19th and as much as things had been changing for the last 20 years, there was nothing like this. I felt like an alien in my own hometown. To top it off, was so crowded--as it gets in these kinds of situations some people are respectful and some people are careless and become pushy, step on you, spill drinks, (first and last occured). Either way, no one here was interacting outside their little clumps, no congeniality  or sense of community here, folks. Love small business thriving but this feels like a whole different animal. Anyhoo, that was the vibe there.  

The drinks themselves were elaborate (took 5 minutes to make), involved any combination of tiny bottles of syrups and extractions, fresh citrus peels and fresh bitters shavings, and tasted good, vodka-based and mezcal-based refreshers that did not taste overly sweet at the time. No disgusting artisanal bourbon concoctions to go with the wave of folk music/Mumford and Sons revival music in the background, (I've been tricked before by a bourbon drink sounding delicious.) 

However, I had a banging headache this morning and I can usually handle my alcohol. Also drinks were not strong nor did they give me a good buzz. And even if sweet, two drinks should not give you a massive headache the next day (after drinking lots of water.)

I would never want to go back here. Again, the staff was super nice, impressively so for popular spots in the Mission, who more often then not have the apathetic to downright rude service to go with the obnoxious "city" vibe, it was just the crowd and the overall vibe of the place I couldn't stand. (On the service account it seemed as though the staff here were one of those exceptional city locations with all the trappings of edgy urbanites, but the humble and utterly conscientious service to make it tolerable, shout-out to Southpaw up the street-they were awesome.) 

Ultimately this bar has been more fun to write about then to visit. As soon as we gave the place  a good try and ordered two different drinks we downed them and took off.
author: Lily G.

description: Came here for dinner and was not disappointed. It was not as noisy as feared and the seating upstairs was comfortable, industrial-trendy, fun. The steak tartare was fantastic and one of our party ordered something with sun chokes/Jerusalem artichokes that was my best meal of the year. I always thought they were boring and have been trying to recreate it ever since. Cocktails were fun, many bizarre combinations, nothing that cried out that it was meant to be. I like this restaurant much more than some more expensive places with big reviews and can't wait to go back.No visible sign and guy outside needs to check your ID before they open the door- I am eligible for Medicare this year.
author: Kathy R.

description: Trick Dog was awesome. The drinks here are phenomenal, I wanted to try all of them. I also had the burger and kale salad, both were delicious. The price of drinks and food I thought were very reasonable. I have recommended many people to come here. I would say this can be a staple for locals and would be a nice local experience for those traveling to SF.
author: David C.

description:
$12 cocktails that I will pay for.  Bartenders that are every bit charming as much as they are skilled.  

I tip my hat off to the creativity of the menus at Trick Dog.  First Pantone colors, then a song list, now a zodiac wheel.  This latest menu iteration is the most fun!  Our group wound up drinking our way through all 12 drinks and yes, they were all delicious and had their own zodiac drink "personality" from the heavier, whisky-forward drinks to the lighter, tropical libations. The drinks introduce flavor fusions of ingredients you don't hear about everyday that I normally wouldn't see go together.  So yes, it's always a treat to see what they come up with!

And the food...you must get the manimal style fries!!  They were a perfect drink accompaniment and will go fast if you order them for your group.  

A five star review well earned, Trick Dog, and a spot on my favorite SF bar lists.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
Hipster bar/restaurant with no obvious sign on the outside. However, it's totally packed on the inside. Came here for an early dinner upstairs (seated right away for 6 around 7PM on a Sunday). The concept is pretty cool with their drink menus hidden in old record books.

Kale Salad - Wow, I was pretty impressed by how good this was?? I thought Kale was usually bitter but it was seasoned and dressed really well. Loved this
Scotch Egg - We tried to share this amongst 5 people and while doable, you should probably order another one. Pretty good but it wasn't mind blowing
Beef Tartare - Pretty standard but still good and a great dish to share with a group

There were others but I didn't eat them so I don't know. 

I also ordered this non-alcoholic drink (the most popular one) which was this pomegranate (I think) type drink. It was good but for $7 I was kind of disappointed by how they used a super small cup for it. I mean, cmon now, don't be stingy.
author: Diana Y.

description:
You know, I like this place. My only complaint is that they sometimes let way too many people in. It gets so crowded in there that it's like a night club. 

My friend claims that he was hit on by the door man, but who knows? added perk!
author: Erin L.

description: This place has a awesome menu of signature cocktails and the atmosphere is chill and the vibe is hip. One of my favorite bars in the city for sure.
author: Nicholas F.

description: Rock solid cocktails and food at Trick Dog. Can't miss with any drink at this place
author: Greg S.

description:
This bar...stinks.  Pretentious door guy at 8:00 on a Wednesday, 20 minute waits for a drink, menu trying a little TOO hard to not be pretentious (fish tacos, scotch egg, burger-ish thing), bad service.  The "trick dog" which is the burger-ish thing was ground beef, store-bought hot dog bun, iceberg lettuce, and mayo. It's a Burger King Original Chicken Sandwich but with beef and for $10 - no side or anything either.
