1 star for good cocktails despite the long wait. 1 star because I like chicken sandos from Burger King.  No bueno otherwise.
author: Matt M.

description:
Good food, good drinks, good service, a little pricey, $12 cocktails? Maybe at a hotel bar, but not here. 

The drink menu is composed of a series of 45s in a binder. It is impossible to use and the height of satire. I thought they were messing with us. It actually makes me think this tech bubble is about to burst if a restaurant/bar manager thinks that menu is a good idea. Maybe if they wrote the drinks down on a completed Rubik Cube, mixed up the Rubik Cube and then expected the customer to sort it out. That would be more ridiculous.
author: Lamb Shanks S.

description: Cool speakeasy where they have a drink menu based on your astrology sign -- don't worry, they also have a regular drink menu. We got a drink here while wandering around the Mission with my friends. Most of us got beers, while some of the guys got the harder stuff. The bar tenders were cool, but the bar area gets crowded. Luckily they have tables and chairs spread out on the other wall, so it's not difficult to get your drink order taken. They have a restaurant upstairs which looked pretty cool... Might check it out next time.
author: Leana L.

description:
Came here with a buddy on a Friday night, the downstairs was bumping. It was so crowded it took 15 minutes just to get a drink! 

The cocktails looked really good, though I couldn't take in that much sugar so I opted for a Gin and soda. The crowd was late-20 to early 30s, professionals who have probably had enough of the dive bar scene in the mission. 

I would say it's a cool place to grab a drink when you have a group of friends if you're looking for something new. The only thing is that there's not that many bars just around the corner from Trick dog, so don't plan on making it the start of a bar hop.
author: Brad M.

description:
This place is awesome. I've been here twice already.

The drinks are strong and so good. They changed menus since I went the first time, but both have had amazing tequila drinks (you know how I like it!) I think it's probably one of my favorite bars. The chocolate beer was also delicious. 

Second time I went, we got some food with friends as well. We ordered 3 different dishes. The Trick Dog which was the burger was great and juice and so delicious. The scotch egg was also great. Big portion and definitely I can tell why there are so many reviews on it. But I think the best dish was the Kale Salad. I've had some other kale salads before and this one was just so delicious. However, I will say, not the best to eat when I'm drinking haha. 

Definitely recommend this place. LOVE IT.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Finally got around to checking you out after moving into the neighborhood.

You are such a treat, Trick Dog. Your drinks were creative and well crafted, and your decor/atmosphere was JUST what I was looking for in a good neighborhood cocktail spot. 

I didn't even care that I was drinking a cocktail out of a ceramic pineapple... 

Well done.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Kale salad was gigantic and really good, trick dog was decent. 

Drinks solid.
author: Julie K.

description: Okay. Let me start of by saying, THIS IS THE BEST SALAD IVE EVER HAD IN MY LIFE.  Wow. Blown away. People close to me would be so so soo surprised by me saying such a statement. But wow. And also the chicken tricknuggets, BEST chicken nugget ever. It was like the best chicken katsu I have ever tried in my life. As far as the drinks, they were great as well...but the food..blew me away. As we speak, my friend and I just ordered more chicken nuggets. Seriously I have no words for this place. AMAZING is an understatement. From LA, anyone I know coming to San Fran I would advise to come to this place for some great food, drinks, and environment. Can't wait to come back to the bay just to come here and I haven't even left yet.
author: Sheyda B.

description:
Trick Dog has hands down the best bar drink menu I have ever seen! The horoscope idea is so creative and all of the drinks sound so innovative and yummy. Too bad I was unable to try the drinks, but the sheer number of people downstairs having a good time is proof enough that their drinks must be solid.

We went here mostly for the food, which was delicious! Started off with the chips and guac, which was a whoppin' price of $7.00. I definitely do not recommend this as neither the chips, nor the guac were worth that price, in my opinion. The highlight of the meal was the beef "tartare," which was made with sous vide sirloin and had a raw egg yolk on top. The idea of doing a sous vide tartare is absolutely genius and would appeal to those who are a bit scared of trying fully raw meat.

Other highlights include the trick dog, which is cooked to a nice medium rare. We also go the rice plate, which was good, but nothing too memorable. The best part on that plate was the rice cake! We tried out the thrice cooked fries- manimal style of course- and that was good and quite filling. Lastly, we ordered some fish tacos (which came out to be around $4 a taco), which were perfectly crisp and flavorful.

Overall, the food is quite good and the atmosphere is nice. While some dishes like the tartare, trick dog, tacos were definite hits, the guac, fries, and rice plate were just ok. Make sure you get there early to secure a seat! There is very limited seating upstairs.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
This is one of my favorite bars! Their bartenders are professional and the drinks are to die for. A nice collection for all pallets and innovative. 
The food is in a "charging is caring"style and also very nice! Definitely creative and in line with the trends in San Francisco right now.
Supercool hangout spot for hipsters and others alike, great ambience and music
author: Helene S.

description: First time coming to San Francisco. I picked this bar thinking it be great and it wasn't. Took about 10 minutes get 1 beer & 1 cocktail. And they weren't even busy which makes it even funnier. So don't visit this place.
author: Jackie M.

description:
Trick Dog is cool.

It began with the most friendly bouncer I've ever encountered. Seriously, a nice bouncer. Say "what's up", but then get inside for the cocktails because that's why you're headed there. High expectations are acceptable - the bartenders at Trick Dog will deliver (and they seem cool enough to not have to call themselves mixologists). 

It's a small space that gets crowded, so I suggest planning on one or two and taking the night somewhere else.
author: Marcus C.

description:
I personally like my cocktail bars a little more low-key than Trick Dog - so take the three stars with a rim of salt:

-Great drinks. 
Stupid, overstylized pantone-deck menu. Flip books are great for visual comparisons; not so much for textual ones. 
-The vibe is not 'mellow'. The music is loud; it's crowded. There's a bouncer. You might get hit on.  
-But, it's not a dancing bar. It's a standing-or-sitting-down bar - like a house party at peak hours. Lots of standers.

I can't imagine myself hanging around for a few drinks' worth - it's not a nurse-and-converse kind of place. Make it a punchy pregame, or a lively ladies' night instead, and you won't be disappointed.
author: Liz C.

description:
Oh my dear Trick Dog. How could I have known what sweet, secret delicacies were hidden inside your walls?

Sweet mountain of Kale, your hearty, woody and cheesy flavors make my mouth sing.

Trick Dog, your complex cocktails of palate massaging flavor make my heart soar.

Your dark and moody aesthetics with warm vibrations move through me! 

Thank you, for your buttery popcorn ice cream with flavor so intense my mind froze in time as I experienced the fullness of creamy goodness.
author: Stephie M.

description:
Cocktails were well balanced. We had the Capricorn and Sagittarius (yah, the menu is unique and bold).  The ambiance is mellow, cozy and dark. The bar is beautiful and filled with countless amount of well made booze. This is definitely a cocktail drinker's heaven. 
We tried their food as well. Had the tartare and manimal fries. Tartare was well executed and seasoned. My fiance loved it! The manimal fries had cheese, aioli and fried shallots. It was really delicious and decadent. Awesome place for cocktails and small bites. Food and cocktails were reasonably priced and the bartenders were super friendly and not at all pretentious compared to many establishments out there. Definitely coming back if I'm ever in the neighborhood
author: Nikki C.

description:
"Do I just stand here and drink? Can I sit down? No seats? hmm.. Upstairs only for diners?" Those are the questions running through my mind on a Saturday night packed house at Trick Dog. The reasons for the 3 stars are simple:  1. Available drink menu. 2. Assorted interesting drinks from Fernet to whiskey. 3. Decor.

Downside is this place is pricey and the crowd has an identity crisis.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Love this spot. Great decor and vibe, great concept for the drink menu, and great drinks, signature or otherwise. It got pretty crowded on a Saturday night but I was lucky enough to catch a stool at the bar. The bartenders take time to craft the drinks, so if you're impatient or claustrophobic this probably isn't the place for you. If you don't mind taking the time though, you're sure to enjoy the product.

Minus one star for a couple of bartenders with less-than-welcoming attitudes (to put it nicely). The rest of the staff was awesome.
author: Victoria G.

description:
Great little bar in the Mission with a super hip vibe. Just revisited to try their new record album menu (I've previously been when they had the pantone menu) and tried the following cocktails:

Linda Ronstadt (Hanger One, Lillet Rose, Meletti, Galliano, watermelon, lime). My personal favorite of the night. Best way to describe it is simply "fresh." Not at all too sweet -- just perfection.

The Bankrobber (Wild Turkey Rye, Ferrand Cognac, Becherovka, blackberry, Bonal Quina, bitters). I was pleasantly surprised by this one because it sounded a bit intimidating, but was delicious. (We decided Trick Dog must just specialize in purple drinks.)

Mr. Big Stuff (Calle 23 Reposado Tequila, Gran Classico bitter, coconut, bay laurel, lime). Served in an adorable pineapple glass, super strong, unique, a bit smokey, and yummy.

That's All Right (Suze, Orgeat, Denizen Rum, Lime). Smells fantastically herbal, tastes nice, but has a very strong bitter aftertaste (much more so than the other drinks)

They won't make anything from the old menu anymore, so forget about the beet juice, but their new drinks are great, too, so don't worry. I'm guessing every single thing you could order would be fantastic!
author: Sam L.

description:
It is easy walking past this place mistaking it for an apartment building. A very cool modern apartment building. The bouncer outside the door gives it away though. 

Inside is just as nice with a chill and intimate vibe. The drinks are interesting and strong. This is a great place to sip cocktails with friends or with a date.
author: Katrina L.

description: This is the closest I've ever come to feeling like I was in that "Hey Mr. Mixologist" parody video.  I like elaborate cocktails well more than the next person, but several of these pushed the line even for me.  The coconut vinegar one smelled rank, like rotting feet; the beet one had a very strong edge of borscht, though it was kind of drinkable.  Many of the others were actually quite tasty.  It's a good place to take cocktail enthusiasts, just as an edgy art gallery is a good place to take art lovers, if for no other reason than to learn your limits.
author: William B.

description: My favorite spot for a classic cocktail. And I CAN'T RESIST the kale salad. I'm not that into kale salads, but this one is killer. It's perfect. I can't say enough good things about it.
author: Kiiya S.

description: Funky drinks with a young hip vibe.  (Try the February!) Met friends for a drink before heading to dinner and had such a good time didn't want to leave.  Looking forward to returning to try more unique drinks.
author: Daniela S.

description:
The best out there. 

I don't know remember what I drank, but I know everything was infused with creative ingredients and when I asked for something with mezcal they produced a twist on a classic cocktail ("improved mezcal cocktail") that was so expertly executed I transcended. 

Trick Dog came heavily recommended from my fave bar back home, and they definitely came to play - despite the grungy hipster ambiance and the mission-to-the-mission bus ride our visit required, my 50-something french and Australian bosses were sufficiently impressed with their drinks to give me kudos on my bar selection.  

Also, these San Francisco bartenders are SO much nicer than our Miami-based cocktail snobs. They sent me home with $20 bill with a friendly message to my local craft cocktail bar - to which the Miami crew responded with an equally friendly "F*ck off". West coast hospitality is so much less vulgar than ours - must be the humidity or constant drone of Pitbull in the background - it changes a person...
author: Caro D.

description:
Scorpio drink 5/5
Libra drink 4/5
Kale salad 5/5
Scottish egg 3/5
Trick dog 5/5
Manimal fries 3.5/5 but my bf says it's a definite 5/5 lol
Jalapeño poppers 5/5
Service 5/5
Price 5/5
author: Cindy L.

description:
Trickdog is a cool hipster bar that's got an industrial look on the inside.

+The ambiance in this area is pretty cool, it's worth buying 1 drink and people watching

-drinks can get expensive fast since they are roughly $10-$12 per cocktail. They are delicious though.... Which is good. 

+ I like how it's tucked away in the mission.

-I haven't tried the food yet, but it smells good!

Conclusion: just buy one drink here unless your a super baller that makes millions. Otherwise, if you prefer quantity over quality just have 1.
author: Julia D.

description: I've only gotten drinks here but they are fantastic! I got this lavender margarita that was one of the best cocktails I've ever head. The bar itself is pretty crowded and the bartenders have a bit of a snooty attitude -- think pretentious mission vibe BUT the drinks made it worth it. I can't speak for the food but all the dishes I saw people eating looked great. The drinks definitely sneak up on you as they're so good you can't taste the alcohol :)
author: Lizzy U.

description:
Stopped by here last night for drinks with a friend. I set my expectations pretty low, but was very pleasantly surprised.  The place is pretty small, so it's probably always busy, but the bartenders were prompt, nice, and courteous.  Plus, the menu is printed on the labels of records stored in old albums. How cool is that??  It was a working night for me, so I had to stop at just one drink: the evil woman, a sweet yet spicy whiskey based concoction.  

I'll definitely be back to try what others are raving about: the baby turtle, mr big stuff (served in a pineapple glass), she's gone, and the cracklings!
author: Janet Z.

description:
This place has some of the most creative cocktails in SF. They have a large menu full of tasty drinks, the decor is stylish, and the bartenders are friendly (and attractive!). They are most definitely on the pricy side, though, and it's understandable since they're catering to the tech yuppies that live in the area. I guess I'm also a tech yuppie but over $10 for a cocktail after work is definitely a bit much for me and prevents me from going to this establishment more often :(

If you can afford it, though, go! You'll have a great time.
author: Anya P.

description:
So in love with Trick Dog, and would no doubt give it 5 stars if everyone else weren't so in love with it, too. Keep in mind that if you're arriving after 9pm, you may have to wait in line outside for awhile.

Drinks are worth the wait, though. (I recommend the "Ain't No Sunshine" for those with a penchant for sour tequila cocktails, and the "Bad Girl" for lovers of bubbles and gin.) The bartenders are troopers for being able to serve so many people at once. I was literally shoulder-to-shoulder with other patrons; one annoying man kept pushing into me, tilting my stool halfway off the ground. (I wouldn't have fallen because there were 5 other people holding me up from the other direction. Yes, it's that crowded.)

My friends and I arrived at 8pm and asked if they could make room in the eating area upstairs for a table of 6. (Sadly, they don't take reservations for dinner.) They said we'd have to wait around an hour; we ended up waiting for 2. One pleasant surprise after we were seated, though: the food, once ordered, arrives lightning-fast. And it was perhaps the best "bar food" I've ever had. We all shared the kale salad (decent flavors), the trick dog (shamefully indulgent burger-dog with creamy sauce and cheese), beef tartare (SO SO SO SO SO GOOD, my favorite thing on the menu), cracklins (crispy pork belly, rich and delicious -- may induce heart attacks if eaten too often), and thrice-cooked manimal-style fries (OMG salivating at the thought of eating these again). 

Overall had a great time. Would recommend heading over at 8pm at the latest, earlier if you want to eat. Also probably not ideal for big parties. Did I mention how much I LOVE the industrial decor? The drink menus, not so much. I heard they used to have amazing Pantone menus, but they've been redesigned as "record albums" -- not the easiest to read. Word of advice: Be sure to hold the menu upright or all the "records" will come spilling out.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
A girlfriend introduced me to this place and I have become quite fond of it. 

Although I did like their previous Pantone menu better, the new menu has potential. The old fashioned here is fantastic (my go-to). I actually prefer coming here during the day as opposed to at night because I like the casual atmosphere and it gets kinda crowded otherwise. Good food options.

Will be back next time I'm in the city.
author: Ashley K.

description:
I give this place an "Inc".

Stopped in there one evening a few months back while waiting on a table at Central Kitchen.  It was pretty crowded, which is to be expected on a Saturday evening at the new "it" cocktail joint.  Once I managed to slip and slide my way up to the bar so I could order a Baby Turtle, I was pretty much ignored by the "mixologist".  Waited about 10 more minutes and then hit the road through the back hallway and sat on the fountain with a nice beer at Central Kitchen.  I chalked this one up to being slammed on a Saturday night and everyone else south of Chestnut Street wanting to be there.

Which brings me to last night (03/27/2013) a Wednesday at 6:30.  We had reservations at flour + water at 7:15 so I though we'd give this place another shot, I'm always a sucker for a well crafted cocktail.  The place, as expected was bustling for a Wednesday but far less crowded then the previous Saturday night cocktail attempt failure.  We looked at the Pan-tone cocktail menu, decided on a Paper Moon and again a Baby Turtle...and just like the past visit started to wait and wait and wait.  And just like the past bailed after 10 minutes of watching the bartender methodically mix his creations. 0 for 2.

I accept the fact that a lot of work goes into each drink, but take the 1 second to look up and notice the ever impatient, thirsty, soon to be ex-patrons and at least make eye contact.  This would inspire hope that you're at going to get to us soon.  

I had a great deal of expectations for this place but 2 failed attempts at getting just one cocktail have brought me to a couple of conclusions:
1. This place needs to staff up to the level to handle the crowd.
2. Jay 'n Bee never disappoints.
3. The fact that this place is associated with Central Kitchen and flour + water raise the expectations, it's time to live up to them.
author: Martin E.

description:
Trick Dog is a good bar. You should go if it's not too far out of your way. I'm just only calling it A-OK out of some neurotic personal preferences of my own. This won't be my most "objective" review. Dispite being a good bar on all technical grounds, I don't think I'm a "fan", a guide for 4 stars I tend to take very literally. I tend to hate things that seem counter cultural in a forced way so...

You need to fix up the outside of your bar and hang a damn sign with your name on it. This is not Brooklyn circa whenever people cared about Brooklyn, and we are in the Yelp era. There are no hidden "it" spots for people "in the know." The person who is "in the know" is anyone. And nestled into one hella gentrified block of the mission, your run down store front looks douchey (and hella 90s). You serve $11 cocktails, and your insulting your clientele by pretending that you are trying to get to something "deeper" than people who buy $11 cocktails. But that's just my read.  

About the cocktails. I had a large carnivore theme for the night and ordered the Lion Heart and the Polar Bear.

I really liked the Lion Heart. Mango paired with Scotch was both a new flavor for me and a cool play on the classic wisdom that whiskeys pair with stone fruits. It was balanced and drinkable, without lacking so much structure that you'd want to knock it back in one go. Almost a perfect cocktail.  

The Polar Bear didn't win me over as well. I think it's super clever and I'll go in on a super clever cocktail. Unfortunately it didn't taste all that great. I thought the mixture of cool mint and warm mezcal would be interesting (I'm also on a mezcal kick in general), and interesting it was...plus the minty white "Polar Bear" is cute. It just didn't taste very good. 

Further note; bad door experience: The adage "always keep a line" should be amended to "never keep a line of only two." I can respect a bar that doesn't want to be too crowded, but if you literally keep only two people waiting outside, you're pissing two people off and not really doing anything for the people inside. Cocktail culture shouldn't mix with technocrats. And since I was one of those two people, you really just stuck me out there to spend two minutes with the part of your bar I like the least.
author: Luke M.

description: I like this place! I haven't been able to sit down upstairs and eat BUT I did order a burger at the bar. Honestly, one of the best burgers I have had. Served on a brioche hot dog bun (burger shaped to fit the bun) and they buttered that puppy up. Added thousand island (its like a gourmet in-and-out). Cooked to a perfect medium rare, it tasted like popcorn....no joke. I was sipping on a negroni (with 209, on the rocks) and I was a happy happy camper.
author: Alex C.

description: i love you
author: Susy C.

description: POTENT cocktails that you order out of an old record catalogue. I almost tried the Louie Louie to get the pineapple mug, but went with something that looked like cough syrup but tasted money. Shame we could only stay for one drink, will be back for more and food!
author: Ian W.

description: It's the epitome of Mission gentrification but I liked it. No signage indicates where the place is but you can figure it out. Their drink menu is a pantone booklet which is creative. I really liked their Gypsy Tan drink. It was BUSY on a Saturday night. A lot of stylish people in a stylish bar. It's a winner if that is your scene. PS: Parking is tricky in that neighborhood.
author: Carlos A.

description: Nice place for cocktails and small bites. Ordered the kelp salad and it was really special. Perfectly dressed. I ordered this whiskey cocktail concoction and it was the best whiskey cocktail I ever had.
author: Anthony B.

description:
I don't know what hipster really is... but i'm pretty sure this place defines it. 

The drink menu is on records and named after songs.

The place is very dimly lit.

Very unique and tasty appetizers.

The decor goes along with the records theme.

Overall I'd definitely recommend it just for the experience. Isn't too pricey either.

MUST HAVES:
I have no idea what the name of our drinks were... so good luck and try everything. 
Fried green tomatoes
author: William L.

description:
The main level bar is a little rowdy. It was also the Saturday night of the World Series, so it could be a little less rowdy in ordinary times. My friend and I opted for the overly-intimate upstairs dining level because commotion ruins my appetite. Speaking of appetite:

- cocktails: well-balanced and not too heavy on the mixers, as it should be
- Kale Salad: I can say this is the best kale salad I ever had. It was just well-chopped, well topped and well-dressed from beginning to end. A great chew even for kale.
- Manimal Style Fries: It started out great - ultra crisp potato job with good stuff on top, but I soon discovered the ratio was a little off and then it became a salty bowl of fries, possibly because we paired it with...
- Crispy Duck Egg: A wonderful deep-fried egg surrounded by a sea of... oversalted beans. Maybe its the beans or maybe its the chorizo, but something about it made it unbearable for my salt sensors. It just made for an unsettling appetizer in my book. It's a shame because that egg had so much potential.

Would I come here again? Yes, because I think I'll forgive salty beans one day and try other things on the menu. Plus I'd definitely want to see kale salad again. Until then, this place will be just okay for me until further notice.
author: Tam N.

description:
Interesting atmosphere, with just a handful of tables in a small loft area above the very busy bar on the ground floor. 

Everything sounded good but was not memorable or worth returning for.

This place gets tons of hype, but it's a lot of noise for fluff. For the price, I'd prefer solid food and fewer tricks.
author: M B.

description: GREAT restaurant and bar. The food is very easily shared but you can also choose not to share. Prices are great and the cocktails are lovely as well. Bonus points for the menu being presented in a dog-themed calendar!
author: Nina A.

description:
Who says you can't teach a new dog old tricks?

I tend to set a bar with a place based on how well they mix up a whiskey sour. Why? Because almost any bar/lounge/restaurant you will ever find yourself will carry the ingredients to make said cocktail. And though, decisively simple in nature, if you can mix up a sour that stands out from the crowd - bonus points & a tip of the hat to you. But if you hand me a sour without the egg white... well... i've already decided on the kind of place i've landed in.

Plus, from many MANY test drives on this first impression theory, i've found that with the whiskey sour, a great bartender will always have a twist on it which gets the personality of service staff across pretty darn quick.  For example: "Do you want a whiskey sour? Or would you like a vanilla bean, camomile & Jamesons sour? I call it The Unicorn." ... excuse me while I climb over the bar to bear hug you...

So did Trick Dog pass the test? They were ROCKIN busy the night we went in (well done for a Wednesday) and though there were no fun twists on the original, the sour I started off with came out in beautiful glassware and balanced just perfectly. One of those sours that you can down FAR too quickly and yet, are sorry when it's over. I kept having to remind myself I was with co-workers and not to get carried away. (pppffttt)

The bar list was obviously well thought out and the "research related" sips I stole from my cocktail buddies proved that the minds behind these mixes know what they're doing. Everything was pleasantly boozy, without being too harsh. A nice balance and throw back to my well loved classics.

The ambiance is nice - though I wish I had the sense to check out the space upstairs. But I would have much preferred it on a slower evening where I could curl into the bar. Getting bumped into every 3 seconds whilst holding a $12 doesn't really jive well with me.

However, I could curl into those bar seats just about any day. And though we were only in for a quickie, I peeked Yamazaki behind the bar, which happens to be my new favourite whiskey and a pain in the butt to get in Vancouver, so I wager I could have spent a grand deal of time here if scheduling served.

The post-manager in me is screaming to make note of the menus - which were printed as Pantone swatches. Nice touch guys.

All in all? I'd be back. This is a solid cocktail haunt and worth the stop in.
author: Jody B.

description:
What's the point? What's the point of anything you, me or anyone does, unless it's exactly right? I am certainly not here to say that what I do is exactly right; in fact, I'm here to say that *most* of what I do is not exactly right. Trick Dog's exactitude -- the bonsai clipping, Le Mot Juste, Daniel Day Lewis-styled precision -- is the craftsmanship that has me inspired to do things right. It has Tom Ford floored when he walks in the door with Martin Scorsese and they look at one another and feel miserable that they haven't crafted a completely immersive experience like this. 

Movies can emote, mirror, reflect and project our lives. The perfect suit can cloak us from what we're afraid of or what we look forward to. A bar. What does a bar do? A bar is where you come alive, where you -- and many others -- have died. A bar is a place where strangers can mourn that loss, can celebrate a new beginning. A bar is where I've fallen in love, where I've seen others do so to. Where ideas bound as ceaselessly as the clang of rinsed spoons. A bar is an opportunity for a talented set of individuals to come together to craft a complete evening for one person to experience the full range of human emotion who walks in the door alone (like myself), and that they have done here In Full.

And a bar like this... with everything so delicately cared for, from the many times mentioned color-coordinated stool set, Pantone menu and cocktail blush... a bar like this with its care is like walking on a film set, and on this set someone called "Action!" to see one man look at another man to say "I don't even give a damn about the cocktails." The other man replied: "It's not about giving a damn about the cocktails, the lighting, the food, the stools, the location or anything else. It's about giving a damn." That's what Trick Dog is doing here: it's about giving a damn.
author: Jon A.

description: After being suggested Trick Dog by a coworker I decided to check it out; I was not impressed. While I think it fits a certain demographic, I found it oddly themed, overpriced, and not an inviting environment.
author: Marcus T.

description: The best food and th best cocktails! I didn't know that the food was going to be this amazing! We had the kale salad, trick dog, fries with the sauce and fish tacos and all were superb!! Small upstairs dinner area- cute n cozy interior and nice crowd. Will be back!
author: C A.

description:
Pros: Pretty space, great food menu - we've come for the kale salad and vietnamese pork twice this week because they were AWESOME

Cons: Slow service, bartenders strangely clueless and inexperienced 

Not sure what the owners were thinking putting together a creative drink menu then hiring such oblivious (and douchey to be honest) staff...

Also, can be INSANELY loud and crowded (but damn, that kale salad is good!)
author: chloe w.

description:
Trick Dog has been surrounded with a lot of hype as of late.  Naturally, it being the newest watering hole in San Francisco, I had to check it out.  

I was not disappointed!  I wish I could knock off just half a star, due to the fact that there was a LINE to get in.  At 8:00PM on a Friday night. And I don't do lines...But I digress...

The beverages are artfully crafted--not just thrown together.  I saw one of the mixologists measuring with a beacon, another with an eye dropper.  It was something straight out of Chemistry 101.  These boys are skilled.  Loved their attire, also: dapper, sharp, and pleasing on the eye.  

I enjoyed the 'Pantone'- a bourbon based cocktail, mixed with fresh pressed beet juice, ginger, combier, kummel, and lemon, served up.  Also, the bartender overheard me inquiring about the 'Baby Turtle'- a mixture of tequila, campari, fresh pressed grapefruit juice, lime, egg white, and a dash of cinnamon.  Next thing you know, POOF, one showed up in front of me.  He had 'accidentally' made an extra. ;)  Nice folks there.

The industrial- chic decor is refreshing, and the crowd is filled with beautiful people.  Fantastic for a pre-or post-dinner drink.  Enjoy!
author: Christina H.

description: Such a cute gem! Love the decor and the specialty drinks. The drink menu is also awesome as it's written on old records. Would definitely return for food one day as the pictures look great too. Happy to know that there was no cover and it wasn't super crowded on a Saturday night. Prices are a little high, but I guess overall the experience is better than your average bar. Great for special occasions or for a classy drink after dinner.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
You know 'that bar' you cannot stand? 

Walked out of TrickDog in the mission. Washing the smug off me now surrounded by the next wannabe Mark Zuckerberg ( I know the irony) but they make you wait in line... Bar tenders call themselves mixologists... 

This is that bar.

Pretentious 
Smug
Lousy
Pompous 
Muggy
Lousy

Only went there to meet friends then we bounced and went to the Jay N Bee club.
Skip it.
author: M P.

description:
Fun cocktail bar in the middle of Potrero/mission border. Awesomely designed space with dim lights. 

Their wannabe piña colada in the pineapple cup is yums.
author: Joy A.

description: Yep. Kale salad - amazing. Duck egg - good. Tasy Dog 'burger' - excellent. Waitress - fabulous. So happy!
author: Laura O.

description:
This dog needs to be put down ... or at least taught to make a good drink.

One morning, someone woke up and decided to replicate Bourbon & Branch, Tradition, RickHouse, etc, but ... wait for it ... in the Mission!  Brilliant! That same person clearly had no bartending experience because the drinks at Trick Dog not only show a complete lack of understanding what mixology is, but are disgustingly sweet.  They taste like someone took a cup of sugar, poured some cough syrup over it, then stirred some bitters in to make it fancy.  I understand a rum and pineapple  concoction is going to be on the sweet side, but when your tequila and mezcal cocktails induce diabetes it's time to revise your drink menu.  Also, the buttermilk punch tastes like vomit.  Whoever thought of that should be fired. 

+1 For the ambience and friendly bartenders.

+1 For the food.
author: Lara O.

description:
My new neighborhood spot.  Yummy drinks, and I mean amazing!  I had the Witchwood for $11, which was a mix of the following:
Torres ten year brandy
Pamperino anniversario rum
Manzanilla sherry
Pedro ximenez sherry
Ron Miel honey rum
Alhambra bitters
The drink was so damn smooth that I couldn't believe it had alcohol.  I actually think that the drinks here are better than Bourbon and Branch.  The presentation is also amazing, they mix everything in beakers, so rad.

The lighting is perfect and they even have a second floor balcony which has some tables.  I really want to come by here and try some of the food, it looks amazing too!
I went on the 3rd day after they opened and it was fairly crowded.  I'm guessing that over time it might get hard to get into, which I won't be happy with :)
author: Mitch A.

description: Good cocktails in a small bar. I came here on a Sunday evening and enjoyed my cocktails, though seating was pretty tight and limited. The bartender was great at his craft, though I found him to be a little off putting and unfriendly. I probably won't go here again, but it's worth checking out.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: I heard about this spot...drive all the way to try out their cocktail. Not easy to find the parking or get a seat at the bat but it was worth it. Love the cocktail and the detail put into the drink. Kudos to the bartender!!
author: Kalyana K.

description:
It's a bit of a trek to get out to Trick Dog's hood, but once you make it, everything you need is right there. A beautiful restaurant next door that supplies you with food all night, fancy tables upstairs for good conversations, a crowd of late-twenties to early-thirties downstairs by the bar, and tricked out cocktails. The cocktails tended towards the strong and heavy pour, but there were some lighter choices for the ladies. 

Some notable tastes of the night:

Fernet ice cream with cocoa nibs, wow
McNuggets with amazing spices
Witchwood - Honey rum, sherry, etc. Strong(!) but with the aftertaste of maple. This was a favorite with the guys.
Baby Turtle - Cinnamon-scented frothy egg whites
Night Moves (my favorite) - Spiked coffee with cream and the surprising kick of curry. This one will keep you up all night.

TIP: If there's a line, you can get in through the back by going through the restaurant next door... ;) Just find the path to the restrooms to the left of the restaurant's entrance.
author: Fawn B.

description:
Central Cinema.

It took me a while to work out why this place felt familiar. So here's the experiment:

Walk into Trick Dog, close your eyes, and then imagine you are at Laszlo but they've taken away the propaganda paraphernalia.

Open your eyes: Voila!

I don't know why, but this looks, smells and feels just like Laszlo, right down to the balcony and being 'semi attached' to a fancy restaurant with the whole indoor-outoor feel (but the cocktails are probably better).

So, other than feeling like somewhere else, this place ain't bad. The cocktails are great, the food, while being just small plates are worth the price, and if you want that nice, dark "don't want to know what time it is outside" feel, this place might just pull it off. Oh and they have Hangar One as the well vodka, which earns karma points (but you aren't getting a $4 shot of well here.)

Really it was a good place to have an adult beverage, but i kinda feel like it needs a dark brown chesterfield or something to hide all the metal and concrete and take some of the edge of the upmarket crowd. But this was opening week, so the vibe may change, (but the architecture won't).

Go for at least one drink. Try to Imagine if it needs a mural of Lenin on the wall.
author: Geoff H.

description:
I came here last night to meet a friend who suggested the bar.  It's a little off the beaten path, but easily accessible from the Mission.  We arrived around 9 PM on a Thursday night and there was a good crowd!  Not so crowded I wanted to run away but enough people to feel like I had found the cool spot to be :P.  My friend told me that they are know for their great cocktails and I would have to agree!  With an adorable paint color- type menu, Pantone colors assigned to each drink and unique, fresh ingredients - you can't go wrong.  

First, I tried "Grandma's Sweater," which I loved!  It was sweet but decently strong and the fresh mint really added to the drink.  I also had a "Baby Turtle" which wins for most adorable name.  This drink was less sweet but still delicious with grapefruit and hints of cinnamon.  I'm usually more of a wine/beer girl but I'll definitely keep Trick Dog in the rotation of bars to frequent in the Mission!
author: Liz H.

description:
Stop #7 was at a bar here in the Mission that is apparently owned by the same people who own Flour + Water.  I hope I got that right.  Somebody please correct me if this information is incorrect.

This bar is interesting because of the drinks.  There are many strange and interesting combinations of flavors going on.  The bartenders are mixologists here mixing together beakers of this and that with eyedroppers of that and the other thing.  Basically drinks here will set you back around a minimum of $10 each.  This is a place that I might enjoy going to once in a while if I lived in this town and neighborhood, but certainly wouldn't be my go to place for drinks out on the town.

I had the St. Elmo's Fire (I'm a fan of the movie) which was a combination of Denizen White Rum, Amaro Averna (an Italian liqueur), pineapple, coconut, allspice and lime.  It was a really refreshing drink, but before the woman finished the drink with a ton of ice there was maybe enough for 2 shots at the bottom. 

Hopefully this doesn't sound like I'm trashing the place.  I did have a good time, but a place like this on a daily basis might be a bit out of my price range.  I enjoy a good cocktail now and then, but I'm more of a beer drinker and I know what I'm getting with a good beer.  I know I'm not getting a glassful of ice.
author: Dan H.

description:
Meh.  The food and drinks were good, but did not live up to the hype I had heard about this place.  I had saved up for a night here (I work at a nonprofit, whatever) and felt disappointed upon leaving $30 poorer and not having experienced a truly great meal.

The one thing of note and sole reason for going back would be the Pantone cocktail.  It was so flavorful, with notes that just kept going.  But I'm still not sure I can justify paying so much for a drink...
author: Amanda L.

description:
Let me guess, you read about this new cool Mission bar in Daily Candy/Thrillist/7x7/SF Eater/your Mission friend's Facebook? Yeah, so did everyone else.

This place is getting a lot of buzz and it completely deserves it. The drinks are not only awesomely named with a Pantone menu, they're also stellar! The Baby Turtle and Patone should be at the top of your to-try list. Don't pass up on the small plates either, the crackling is almost to die for. Get there early if you want a spot at the bar or even a table upstairs. Be patient and nice with the staff, they're just as amazing as the drinks! :)
author: Ashley M.

description:
I'm not sure what all the fuss is about. We arrived around 5:30 thinking we'd beat the crowd - well we did but being that there's only maybe 10 bar stools in the entire place. Of course they were all taken even by 5:30. We decided to head upstairs, eat and enjoy a beverage while sitting down. First off we had to wait a minimum of 20 minutes for the waitress to seat us, the entire 20 minutes we were staring at the 3 open tables waiting for us. Next, it took another 20 min for someone to ask us if we'd like a drink. Then once the drinks arrived and the food - it was just Meh - nothing to right home about. The drinks were tasty but unbelievably small - especially after what was now about an hour wait if you include, the table wait, the order wait, then the wait for the beverages themselves. 

Honestly - I won't be returning to Trick Dog - there are too many decent bars within a few blocks of it. Asiento & Blowfish to name just a couple.
author: Teresa J.

description:
This was a pretty cool bar that my friends from SF took me to while I was visiting from Florida. While the cocktail menu looked pretty interesting, and the drink menu in general was cool how it was in binder of 45's (records), I'm a beer guy so I wanted to sample some California brews. First I had a Mission Shipwrecked IPA, which is actually from San Diego. It was a solid IPA but at 9+%, I wasn't going to have too many of those. I switched to a Biere de Chocolat by SF's own Almanac Brewery. Those were pretty sweet and tasty. I was expecting to pay $8-$10 per beer being in SF, but they were actually only $6-$7 apiece.

We also sampled some appetizers: the pork cracklins ($6) were deliciously crispy and not too greasy. Also had some fries and the pickle board, which was good even though I don't really like pickles so it must be good. They seem to have a nice restaurant upstairs, the decor is pretty cool and bartenders were friendly. I'd go back if in the Mission District of the city again.
author: Jeremy B.

description: The downstairs is often crowded and noisy, often with the new-mission-money types that often seem to take more from a scene than they give, but the food and drinks are really good, the staff is nice, and - while the drinks are kinda pricy - they keep the food prices reasonable. If you go in on off-hours and can catch a seat upstairs for dinner, it's a nice place. Friday/Saturday nights it's a crowded gentrification party, which may or may not be your thing.
author: squeak s.

description: Fantastic service, great cocktails, fine food.  We went early (4:30 hh!) on a Friday and left early, just as it was getting really packed.  Sat at the bar and had 4 different cocktails between the two of us, all masterfully crafted.  Tried the chicken nuggets (don't bother) and the manimal fries (yum!).
author: e w.

description: We really enjoyed Trick Dog it was a cute bar and good post-dinner spot. We ate an awesome late dinner at Foreign Cinema and headed to Trick Dog. The ambiance was pleasant and the crowd was attractive ! They have these random pineapple drinks. Overall cute bar!
author: Priya S.

description:
I went there on a Saturday afternoon... was amazing!  Take my review of the drink with a grain of salt--- I am on a no sugar/no alcohol cleanse, but I got a mocktail. It was a delish version of one of their alcoholic beverages.  

I hear that the menu changes every few months.  Right now it's the zodiac and you pick your drink off of an astrological calendar; all the drinks are named for your sign.  Mocktails are named for the Chinese astrological calendar.  I had "Year of the Dragon". 

Would definitely come back next time I'm in SF.
author: Lauren W.

description:
Go simple or be prepared to studio the menu.  It was my first experience with a true "cocktail bar" and I wasn't disappointed.  Generally speaking, I like my bourbon drinks brown and mixed with only ice.  This was a great chance to watch some real professionals make out of this world complicated, yet delicious drinks.  It's beyond me how they learned, not only what each ingredient was, but every little detail about the recipe and process.  

The servers didn't just impress with their skills, but they killed with their kindness as well.  This place was running like a well oiled machine, so I was shocked to find out that Trick Dog opened only eight days ago.  It usually takes places months to work out all of the kinks.

Good boy, Trick Dog.
author: Will L.

description: A friend from Wisconsin recommended this place. Had an awesome pisco cocktail and the Kale Salad. Both were so so good! Highly recommended.
author: Taryn G.

description:
I think this bar will be one that people either love or loathe. Don't come in here expecting it to be a dive bar full of character, grizzled locals or a jukebox-friendly environment. It is none of those things. 

More than just being a bar, Trick Dog makes mouthwatering cocktails they've perfected down to a science. Literally, they make their own licorice/cinnamon flavored bitters on site! Their dedication to the purity and sophistication of every ingredient is evidenced in their paint-swatch themed menu. Not only is it a clever touch, but a great way to remember what the hell you actually ordered.

I'm sure this bar will be disparaged as pretentious. It is very pretentious, of course, right down to the ultra-modern interior and "mixologist" bartenders who probably inspired that sketch on Portlandia. But really, this is a great spot if you just want a delicious and well-made cocktail.
author: David P.

description:
I finally came here w/ the boyfriend after he kept telling me I should try it. I have to say the drinks are pretty good! I had the "Grandma's sweater" and I really liked it! 

A mix of gin, zucca rabarbaro, blood orage, lime, mint, and bitter lemon soda made a really good drink! 

Trick Dog is definitely a chill bar. I like.
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
This spot is amazing.  Once again the Bon Vivants have outdone themselves.  The drinks are of the highest grade with a type of artists creativity while the food is beyond delicious and like a party in your mouth. 

Every time I have been in it is busy but I have had no problems with catching a bartender and watching the magic happen.

Did I mention the space?  Top notch carpentry and design all the way around.  It feels old while new, classy while welcoming and homey.

New favorite spot without a doubt.
author: Daniel B.

description:
There's not much original or unique about Trick Dog.

The drinks are great, and where trick dog stands out the most, making better than average use of spices and the occasional savory element in cocktails. Yet in San Francisco there are already many places where drinks of such high quality are served.

The nibbles I had were just fine: the charcuterie plate was nice, but its "twist" was dill pickle gelée. That's a fancy way of saying dill pickle jelly. It tasted like dill pickle jelly. But that aside, it was a standard issue charcuterie plate. The fried brussels sprouts are fine, but I've had that same execution (with crispy sunchokes and bacon) elsewhere. 

As far as decor, Trick Dog features most of the standard modern design cues: Edison bulbs, cement floors, as well as exposed wood and structural elements. But I do like how it has mezzanine seating.

There seems to be a lot of hype surrounding this place, at least early on, as all the seats were full at 8:30pm on a Sunday.

Indeed, a trick dog. But this dog was born old and the tricks it has been taught aren't all that new either.
author: Suo L.

description:
This is an absolutely great little cocktail bar. We were walking around the Mission and got really sick of the trashy bars that make up most of the area. Then we walked by Trick Dog and spotted a smart, sharp-looking group of people walking in. We decided to follow and wow... we were not disappointed. Good looking people. Nice, friendly, PROFESSIONAL bartenders. And the drinks... absolutely meticulously made. Delicious!

If you want your can of PRB, please go elsewhere.

Will be back to Trick Dog whenever I'm in the area.
author: James S.

description:
Really enjoyed coming in to see this new venue in the Inner Mission. I know that its opening has been a long time coming and, for me, well worth the wait. 

I met Josh Harris, one of three partners at Trick Dog, at The Hideout in the Mission while he was bar tending about 3 years ago. I had always admired Josh's skills behind the bar and had heard him speak about his concept for a bar that he wanted to open in the lower Mission with his friends/partners Jason Henton and Scott Baird (aka The Bon Vivants). 

The interior is rustic and warm with a great mix of hand made light fixtures and furnishings. It also offers a bit of the industrial touch with its high ceilings and exposed beams. The vibe is very welcoming with a good sized bar on the lower level and tables on the loft level upstairs which are designated for eating. A very attractive and clever use of space was made part of their bar by having sliding walls that hold a great selection of spirits within them. The food menu offers some great comfort foods and a selection of healthier options like their kale salad which I love.

The service here is great and I'm always a huge fan of places that have the "personal touch'. This place is a stand out in this category and I hope it continues during its lifetime. 

This is a great addition to a great part of town and I hope to be there often.

Salute!
author: Gabriel R.

description:
There is nothing about this place that I don't LOVE. I'm even getting used to the crazy crowds that are sure to be a permanent fixture from here to eternity - but alas everything here is SO GOOD that they are warranted. Crowds of smart people, if you will - which I don't mind.

It is true that the cocktails are world-class and truly eye-opening, but don't miss out on the well orchestrated food offerings too. The 'dog', pickle plate, kale salad are all excellent - I only wish that we'd ordered more from the menu. Next time!

I can't wait to go back and this time I'll go early!
author: Clint B.

description:
When I think "best cocktails in town," I think Trick Dog. This bar is new, so I found my way to it is by asking the bartenders at another bar that shows up at the top of the list in Google when you search "best cocktails in San Francisco" (Alembic) where else to go for fantastic cocktails. Without hesitation, the bartenders all said Trick Dog! Their relentless praise of Trick Dog's bartenders and drinks convinced me and I'm glad it did because that's how I found my new favorite place. The drinks are pure art and always exceed expectations. They juice all their veggies on the spot too - so yummy!

MUST TRY Buttermilk Punch (it's actually a clear liquid because the milk gets extracted; best drink I've ever had!) and the Panetone (with freshly extracted beet juice!).                                            

The drinks do have a tendency to be a bit on the sweet side, so make sure to mention to one of the mixologists if sweet is not your thing and they'll take care of you properly.
author: Sabina U.

description:
I've been here many times and it consistently delivers delicious cocktails and far better-than-average bar food. I've even been upstairs for dinner and tried a significant portion of the menu and it's at the right price point and portion.

It gets crowded really early on a Fri/Sat and by the end of the night, the music can be deafening. Trying to balance food on the too few "ledge as a table" is also a trick in itself. The layout is a bit of a pain as well when people are sitting right at the bar and you have to shout over them and their friends to order anything. Not the worst problem to have, and the bartenders do their best, but Churchill has a better layout for those trying to order.

The best time to come is after 9pm on a weeknight: you can pretty much have the rule of the roost and the quality in output from the kitchen and bar is at its best. I secretly miss their record menu, but it's been replaced by an almost as cool horoscope wheel.
author: Brandon K.

description:
Probably one of the most capable bar tending staff I've seen. Good recommendations, helpful advice and capable of juggling multiple orders from varying party sizes at once (including an unexpected group of about 15-20 tourists). Handled without disturbing the flow of drink orders from the rest of the bar. 

Drinks were well executed and delicious.
author: Tracey S.

description:
Oh Trick Dog, what a tricky review this feels to write. If I had written this review after my first visit, this would probably be a 4 star review. However, after my 2nd visit for a friend's birthday party, I'm feeling a little less generous and going to round down to 3 stars.

The drinks are certainly the strong point of this establishment. The bartenders take their time to make them properly, and they've got some unique ones on the menu. However, I've definitely had hits and misses with them. Yes, drinks are largely a personal preference thing, but bottom line is that I'm still not happy if I'm paying $10+ for a drink I feel is "meh." 

There's also a small dining area upstairs, but if you don't get in during the first round, expect to wait a long time to get a table, or don't expect to get one at all. Plus side is that you can order your food downstairs and they'll bring it out to you. However, I feel a large portion of the food falls into the meh category as well. The Trick Dog especially so. I like how their signature namesake dish is unique in that it's a hamburger shaped to fit in a hot dog bun, but I honestly don't think I understand the practical purpose or benefit to this. The flavors and textures reminded of a fancy big mac. Not a bad thing in itself, but I'd rather pay big mac prices instead of Trick Dog prices then! :P A friend ordered the scotch egg, and after I tried a bite I agreed with their once again "meh" consensus. Thrice-cooked manimal style fries weren't bad, but not stand out either. Cracklins were definitely my favorite out of all the food I tried, which unfortunately isn't saying that much.

Luckily the few times I've been here I haven't had to wait in line, but the line here can get long, and this small space gets pretty crowded. Cool joint, friendly staff, and I like the vibe here. However, I'm going to give this review 3 stars, largely due to the value I feel I'm getting for the food, drink, and overall experience.
author: Morris C.

description:
What a treat to live two blocks from here! I always wondered what the fuss was about--lines out the door and all--and glad to know this place is reliable for amazing food and drinks. Yayyyy.

Love the hipster "pantone" drink menu. Straw hat was my fave.

Scotch egg is an ABSOLUTE MUST. Oh dear god it was delicious. 

Kale salad was a nice balance to all the greasy food we ate (fries, etc.)

Tip: It gets reeeeeallly hot upstairs. Line can be long, so be prepared to wait.
author: Annie L.

description:
Amazing drinks. I wish they didn't replace the Mr Big Stuff, but I understand menus must change :( Bar staff is exceptionally courteous.

Almost always crazy crowded, which is the only thing I don't love.
author: Ian S.

description:
From the moment I (easily) parked my car in Trick Dogs neighborhood to stepping outside feeling fulfilled and satisfied, this was a great experience.  Now for everything in between:
I like where this bar is nestled in.  Its the city, but its a friendly neighborhood with decent parking. Very easy to get to from the freeway. My friends and I arrived about 4:00 and it was already steady. We found a nook at the bar and were immediately acknowledged by our bartender. Having drooled over the drink menu online for the past 5 days I knew where I wanted to start. 

First up:

-Baby Turtle
-Gypsy Tan
-Pennies from Heaven

All of which were delicious, however the gold was claimed by the Gypsy Tan.  

Second:

-Polar Bear
-Night Moves
-Pantone

All three of these will blow you away.  The way the Bon Vivants have figured out balance of flavor is astounding to me.  They have one of the best grasps on the subject. Not one of the six drinks was "too" anything (sweet, bitter, strong, etc).  Every one of these cocktails was balanced perfectly.  And very thoughtful in every aspect (smell, taste, color, presentation).  

The food:

The Burger: Perfection.  Nothing else to say about it other than make sure you order one. Perfect size, perfectly cooked, perfect secret sauce. Just perfect. 

Cracklins: Little delicious crispy bites of pork belly amazing. 

Brussels Sprouts: These were cooked just the way I love them.  Not oily, not dry, not hard, not soggy.  The sunchoke chips and bacon round this dish out.  So tasty!

Fernet Ice Cream:  I'll admit I was a bit stand offish about this dessert choice thinking it was going to be some bitter tasting novelty. ORDER THIS.  The flavor of this ice cream is beyond and it is so silky smooth.  Hands down this is the best scoop of ice cream I have ever had.

Right along with the Bon Vivants cocktails their food is the same: Balanced.  Pleasing to all the senses.

The overall experience was extremely pleasing.  Thank you so much to every member of the staff of Trick Dog for making that happen.  Every one of them sincerely thanked us when leaving and wished us a good night.  

Obviously going back again and again and again.
author: Amber D.

description:
Beautiful converted industrial space, Fancy-doo drinks, full of trendsters with some coin, Great addition to the mini restaurant row forming steps from home. Flour and Water, Central Kitchen, Universal Cafe,yada..
Gentrification rules!!
author: G K.

description:
good drinks. good atmosphere. friendly staff.

love when you can give a bartender a general "flavor" of what you want and they provide you with exactly what you want...and it taste GOOD.

we each wanted something different - refreshing, fruity/delicious and whisky.  the guy did good and we were all pleased and left with a nice buzz after just 1 drink.

will have to go back and grab a table upstairs for some drink AND food.

also, creative "records" menu and trick dog decor will have you busting out your phone for instagram worthy pics. just sayin'..
author: Melody T.

description:
I don't write reviews anymore, but the compulsion hit. I went a few weeks back, back in the pantone-menu days. It was a pleasant kick, caressed my throat to three or four licks. Days later a public announcement to friends colored the place as pretty neat, "except for that damned menu, yo". 

Then a friend emailed me a link, "check it, brother --- Trick Dog has a new menu!"

Reassured, thinking they'd addressed the design deficiencies in their old list, I went back. Here's where I get mind blown: they inconceivably made it worse. They've created, quite possibly, the worst menu in existence. There was a line of 6 people across the bar, and each group was going through the menu --- at a rough count I'd say it took the average group a good ten minutes to make a decision. Hell, a friend of mine was so befuddled he was dropping discs out of the sleeve, and struggling to keep the entire thing together.

To the dearly beloved owners: you make amazing drinks, that's all the flourish you need.
author: Marc M.

description:
I finally made it here last night for drinks to cap off date night and have to say that I'm a huge fan!  Given the fact it was a Tuesday evening, there wasn't a line at the door (thank goodness) and we found a seat at the bar rather quickly, which was a huge plus.  

It must be stated that the drink "menu" is too cute! I was seriously obsessed.  I ordered the Pantone drink, also referred to as the "beet drink," which was excellent.  The hubs ordered the Alligator Alley because he thought it would be close to a gin martini.  Much to his disappointment, aside from the gin and vermouth, it didn't taste like a martini.

The bartenders here are serious!  It seems that they love what they do and that the cocktails are an art form for them.  It was fun to have a bar seat to watch the alcoholic concoctions being whipped up.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Awesome places with a vintage feel. The decor throws you back into a saloon at the turn of the century. The staff are amazing and are quite helpful. Being that it is in the city, the prices are out of this world. The food - chicken nuggets and sandwiches are really good and definitely worth trying out. If you and your coworkers want to pick a good afterwork watering hole - look no further. I do, however, have to warn you: this place is small, it gets packed quick. And you will be smashed up against your friends or coworkers really quick. If you want to find a place - walk a few blocks away to Southern Pacific if you need more space.
author: Jane E.

description: Awesome drinks, cool vibe. The bartenders are very savvy for sure. I have tried to go here a few times and it has been way too crowded, but this time it was a really great mix of people and the music was good.
author: Emily P.

description:
Went here for late night drinks for a friend's birthday. What a fantastic drink menu and friendly/knowledgeable staff hard at work. 

There's a bit of a line, so I would get there early (i.e. before 10 pm). Inside will be crowded as well, and not a lot of space to sit. But all in all, it' s a great place meet up for a nice drink. 

Will have to come back to try the food with all the great reviews :)
author: Winny F.

description: Trick Dog is your cure for Monday night. Dinner with a lively happy hour downstairs = escape the hum drum. Keisha gave lovely service and payed such close attention to my table for one. Had a glass of cab and the skirt steak ... delicious!
author: Kristen B.

description:
What a nice new spot to hit up that's pretty much different that your usual "normal" bar.

Don't call the guys bartenders here at Trick Dog, they're mix-ologists. I like to call them the Baristas of the bar business. They put their heart and soul into every drink you order. Actually, they're NOT even drinks, they're MASTERPIECES. I like the fact that they put a lot of pride into every drink and they dont skim on anything either. It's quality out here!

There was a small line on a friday night and I wasn't complaining at all. It maybe gets 10 deep at most? Also, keep in mind this place has NO SIGN. So make sure you yelp it and google map it or else you'll pass it just like i did! 

Bouncer at the door is not your usual bouncer. This guy is super chill. Well of course, dont mess around like a dumb drunk and you'll be fine

What's also great is that they don't over pack it and there's no cover. The reason is that the drinks are such a master piece that it does take a bit of time to make so they want to make sure the place is not over-crowded and that theres breathing room for the guys making the drinks one by one. 

They also serve food! some nice starts / appetizers. I was able to try the pork belly and it was pretty good. Deep fried and seasoned along w/ some nice buffalo / crystal hot sauce for dipping. It was so good but so bad for you though. Kale salad was a nice light snack especially because those shots of Makers Mark from yelper Winnie H. and Braden K. got. 

This is a GREAT spot to chill and mingle on any given night. DONT expect this to be a bar to go binge drink and take shots til you black out and cant remember a thing and leaves you grasping for water at 6am in bed next to someone you dont even know. There is barely any music in here, so if you're looking to get smashed and chocolate-henny wasted while getting ratchet to some 2 Chainz, go hit up polk.
author: Kenny L.

description:
Great Drinks!!! The venue is cute too, and the staff is really friendly ( thumbs up to the  hot blond bartender with a hair bun!) 

Its a cool place to have a drink with some friends, but the crowd is not good looking at alllllll!!!! Very alternative Mission weird people. It's still fun though.

PS: really love their fries!
author: Paula C.

description:
The boyfriend and I came here around 5pm on a Tuesday night. It was pretty crowded in the bar area, but having heard about how great the food was, we headed upstairs to for an early dinner. We ordered:

Food:
The Scotch Egg- I liked the idea, but I think many people are fooled by the plating. Plus, the egg has a very fishy tasting layer between the egg and the breading. Nothing should every be fishy tasting. Even fish. Yuck. 
The Trick Dog-A pretty solid burger, but it wasn't good enough to make me want to return here just for this one dish.
Cracklins- very good, but fried fat is not so hard to get wrong. 

Drinks:
Pennies from Heaven- interesting, but I only had one sip because it was too alcohol-tasting for me, but I am really not a big drinker, so I always feel very biased whenever I give a drink review.
Grandma's Sweater- This was pretty good and balanced with the right amount of sweet, sour, and alcohol flavor. It didn't have the alcohol taste as much, but it was still a very strong drink! I drank about half and had to stop. 

Our food came out before the drinks, which no one ever likes, but I know the bar was busy downstairs. The service was okay, not really much to discuss there. Although, the waitress did apologize for the drinks coming out slowly. Overall, I thought this meal was disappointing and overpriced for what we had. I think if I had out of town guests who were more into scene and ambiance, I would bring them here, but this wouldn't be a place for me to return any time soon.
author: Victoria J.

description: Go big or go home: I'm sick of all these San Fran places trying to be the newest, coolest, crafty, organic, pretentious, overpriced, "another moscow mule" type bar.  On the flipsdie, this place is new, cool, crafty, BUT amazing AND done right!!!!! Craft cocktails are epic.  Food is surprisingly awesome. .. if you walk in not knowing this place has got the hugest ratings right now (I think top ten food in country or something crazy).  Service is great (you would almost imagin the bartenders front attitudes like they usually do at hipster places, however, they are ALL REALLY KNOWLEDGEABLE & COOL. . . .especially Matt.  We definitely recommend the fried chicken!
author: Karin E.

description: An awesome craft cocktail place. The bar food that they have is also one of the best I've had. The Kale salad and the scotch egg!
author: Petter B.

description:
Excellent cocktails and nice decor at this small new bar. Great to see a bar in the Mission (especially this far east of Mission) doing nice cocktails instead of just another beer bar.

The Mission has some excellent beers bars like Shotwell's and the Sycamore, and some great restaurants that do good cocktails (Beretta, etc.), but this place fills a niche that was somewhat lacking in the neighborhood, and it does it with class.
author: Joe S.

description:
Come for the drinks, go elsewhere forfood...

After hearing all the hype, we decided to trek over to check this place out one warm Saturday afternoon. After walking about a mile, we realized we had actually walked right by the place... Of course, just like any good little hipster bar, there is no sign to indicate it's presence.

After our somewhat long jaunt, we ordered a few drinks and were led upstairs to cozy into a table (we were also given no fuss for transferring our bar tab to our table +cool points to the staff!). We started with the Lion Heart cocktail... which was delicious, but a tad sweet for our liking.

Then moved on to the Polar Bear and the Pantone (both of which we liked much more than the Lion Heart). Herby, refreshing, complex... Who would have thunk Beet Juice and Ginger would taste so good with Bourbon? (I'm hereby making some excitingly alcoholic revisions to my summer juice cleanse...)

With our second round of drinks, we also ordered the cheese spread and a Scottish egg. The cheese spread wasn't great and the veggies didn't look particularly fresh, however, the Scottish Egg was pretty tasty and was served quickly.

All in all, I think the atmosphere is nice, the wait staff was great, the drinks rocked...but the food can be easily beat in that neighborhood.

With 4 drinks and 2 appetizers, our bill came to $60.
author: Julia T.

description: This place is solid.  I went after work for drinks and a snack while waiting for a table down the street at Flour + Water, and it was a great spot to hang out and have some really good drinks.  I had the Painted Ladies which was was pretty sweet, but not cloyingly so.  We also tried their Chickpea Falafel Sticks which were amaazing.  Very light and airy for something that's usually so heavy.  The place is also spacious, so it's a perfect place to hang out with a group of friends.  Highly recommend!
author: Nicole R.

description: The drinks here are amazing!  (does that make me a sf specialty drink snob?).  They recently changed their drink menu and the drinks are listed on records now.  I'm so impressed by the creativity of them.  Recently I finally tried some of the food.  Too full for a full meal, but got the manimal style fries, which were really good.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Jim was our bartender. He misheard an order, when we told him we didn't order it he threw a fit. I ended up buying the drink to not make a scene. Later when I ordered a drink he said if I give a drink to one of the people who had told him we didn't order it he would kick us out. Should never have tipped him. Hope the manager reads this cause that's absolutely ridiculous.
author: Cameron K.

description:
Trick Dog, to me, is what I think of if I had to describe a type of bar you might not see outside of SF.  From the outside, it looks like a dilapidated building without any signs or indications there's a bar inside ... except for the sounds of the raucous crowd inside at 5pm.

People have clearly discovered this place and yet it still it feels like a discovery.  The clever pantone drink menu is varied and populated with specialty cocktails.

Our favorities:
- Pennies from Heaven (Templeton Rye with sour apple liqueur and sherry) - complex and crisp.  
- Pantone - (Four Roses Bourbon, Combier, Kummel, beet, ginger and lemon) - looks like a smoothie but also pleasantly complex with a taste of pepper that travels from your tongue to your throat.

Good but a notch below:
- Gypsy Tan (Rittenhouse rye with fernet, ginger and Erdinger Weissbier) - light and clean taste with some carbonation)
- Baby Turtle (Tequila Ocho resposado tequila with grapefruit, cinnamon and egg white) - also nice but a little too sweet for my personal preference

Skip:
- Alligator Alley (Olive oil-infused bourbon) - way overpowering.  Felt like I was drinking diluted olive oil
- Vintage Photo (Flor de Cana rum with banana liqueur) - tasted like medicine

After a few hours, we actually decided to eat dinner upstairs, where there is waiter service and a few tables.

Standouts in terms of food were the cracklins (fried pork belly pieces), the thrice-cooked fries and the Brawn tacos (with crispy headcheese which added a nice creamy and buttery texture).  The tartare was also good (not really raw but cooked sous-vide).

Things that sounded better than they tasted were the kale salad (I love kale in general but thought it could have been more seasoned here or made in to kale chips instead), the scotch eggs (also love these in general but the version here was somewhat bland) and the trick dog (just ok).

Even though it gets packed, I thought the service here was pretty friendly and attentive.
author: F. P.

description:
I've gone here multiple times for drinks, and my goal is to try everything on that damn placard. Everything is excellent so far. I have really enjoyed the grandma's sweater and the vintage photo. The environment and ambiance are awesome, and I love it when a place near me just hits the spot.

This place is a double thumbs up for me, and I recommend reading through the placard and finding your drink. Highly recommend this place.
author: Howard J.

description: This review is for the restaurant upstairs. Downstairs bar area was very full, so we decided to eat and drink upstairs. First of all, it was freezing. The large windows behind our table were open, and even though I put my winter jacket on I was very cold. We asked to change our table, and noticed that many other patrons were complaining about the low temperatures (and some changed their seats as well). Secondly, our waitress. I do not want to smile more than the wait stuff in an attempt to get some warmness, when I spend tons of money to eat outside. Come on! You may have a hard day, but smile a little. Thirdly, The rose I ordered was served in a tiny glass, and it was less than 4 oz. for sure. Maybe they want to sell hard alcohol mainly; but, when you pay 14$ for a glass of wine, you are expecting a decent amount of wine. On the other hand, food was good. Kale salad was huge, tomatoes were delicious. Fish tacos were yummy. If you are planning to visit, bring your ski jackets, and order cocktails :)
author: Kristin S.

description: Come for the drinks not the food. Every drink was amazing! The manimal fries were ok but the tacos were really bad.
author: Tiger T.

description: Place is kind of in the middle of no where, but the drinks are good. Ordered the straw hat and baby turtle. Drinks tend to be sweet here.  Wish they had the ingredients for the polar bear drink, which was the reason I came here. Kind of weird that they were already out of the ingredients so early in the evening. Crowd comes in waves, but the bouncer starts a line outside if it gets too crowded, which is good.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Went to the Trick Dog for happy hour the other day and I didn't know what I was getting into.....

I love it. Drinks were amazing. The owner served me and he couldn't be nicer. The menu was adorable. I loved the grandma's sweater drink. Now I only wish it was bigger because it's going to be packed all the time....
author: Casper D.

description:
came here with 2 others on a thursday around 6pm.

i had drink #4 on the chinatown menu. i think it was coconut-infused something with other tasty things in it. anyway, it was great. definitely boozy.

for food, we had the trick dog, chicken tricknuggets, and thrice-cooked fries.

hoo man. everything was delicious. like, crazy delicious.

super friendly bar staff. they're obviously very busy but nice to chat with if you can get a minute with them.

will definitely be back.
author: Shawn C.

description:
I came here with a couple of friends on a Friday night. We tried to sit at a table but the place was super crowded; so we ended up sitting at the bar. the cocktails were great: Capricorn was good but strong, Leo was delicious! Libra was also very good if you're in the mood for some tequila. The only drink I'd probably stay away from next time is Cancer. It was too strong for me to taste all the flavors that was in it. Their other alcoholic beverages are worth trying out as well.

Overall, the bar here is great! The awesome bartender who served us, Caitlin, is the best! Definitely coming back here again to try the food here as well.
author: Amy B.

description: Gem. Good cocktails, delicious food (we sampled some appetizers at the bar). Perfect waiting spot for Flour + Water
author: Dimple B.

description: Fantastic cocktails with clever, revolving menus.  No idea what the food is like, because who needs food when your drink is that delicious?!
author: Valerie T.

description: Finally made it out to Trick Dog last weekend for after-dinner drinks for a friend's birthday. The bar itself is cool, but as it was a Saturday night it was packed. Difficult to make your way up to the bar to order. Once you did, the wait was long (complex drinks) and then it was even harder to navigate your way out of the crowd without spilling. The menu is always rotating, but the one we experienced was great! Solid drinks with twists that make them unique. I would come back for drinks and appetizers (the food looked good!) but would consider trying a weekday night to avoid the larger crowds.
author: Lauren C.

description:
The entire experience just drives conversation.

From the menu being on old records, the making of the drinks, figuring out which drink is yours, and tasting what everyone else ordered. We went pretty early around 5 or so, and it was packed by 6. I'm guessing it's a zoo at night, but I highly recommend it :)
author: Kevi L.

description:
Fun place to hang out with friends ...drinks were really good and authentic! 
Loved the spring rolls and seems like a cute place to take a date.
The asian cups the use are unique and a nice touch.
Will come back for sure :)
author: Todd J.

description: didnt have the food, came for drinks, it was ok.
author: Denise F.

description:
excellent place for drinks and appetizers...

Bartenders are great and food is pretty good. 

Pennies from Heaven: interesting flavors...mix of savory and sweet
Gypsy Tan: A bit more fruity with a savory finish. 
Lion Heart: tart and sweet. 

Scotch egg: very good. perfectly soft boiled egg. Is a bit rich, so if you're looking for something lighter, this isn't it

Cracklins: very good. again, if you're counting calories, or you want something light, this isn't it

The Trick Dog: Juicy and well seasoned. a buger with an upgrade.

I would definitely come back for a pre-dinner snack and drink
author: Christine N.
